PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Mr Cohen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this morning the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill 1986. The purpose of establishing this museum in Sydney is to provide the basis of a collection and exhibition centre for the national maritime collection and to preserve historical maritime material. We are told that the Commonwealth Government approved a grant of $30m in October 1985 for the construction of the National Maritime Museum. The Commonwealth has accepted the offer from the New South Wales Government of a 4.5 hectare site for the Museum on the western side of the Darling Harbour redevelopment area. The legislation before the House today will establish the museum as a Commonwealth statutory authority, with staff employed under the Commonwealth Public Service Act. It is hoped that the museum will be opened to the public in early 1988, but, of course, the New South Wales Minister for Public Works and Ports, Mr Brereton, has made it quite clear publicly that is nothing more than a pipe dream.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has given very serious consideration to this legislation. There is quite a wide range of issues about which we are very concerned and in the public interest we believe it is necessary that we should move an amendment to the second reading of the Bill. I therefore move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its failure to protect the public interest through its failure to-
(1) refer the proposed construction of the Australian National Maritime Museum to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works;
(2) offer a full explanation as to why alternative accommodation suggested in the Pigott report was not acceptable;
(3) ensure that there are no significant cost overruns that might arise as a result of union pressure due to the Government's commitment to complete the project by 1988;

(4) restrict the open-ended nature of the total cost of the project, which does not include purchase, preservation and exhibition of a collection or administrative, educational and promotional costs of the Museum;

(5) disclose details of the arrangement with the N.S.W. Government to construct the Museum in the Darling Harbour redevelopment site, and the impact of the Wran Government's decision to grant the Builders Labourers' Federation a monopoly over construction jobs in Darling Harbour, and
(6) utilise the existing facilities, resources and expertise of the Sydney Maritime Museum which have been offered to the Government.

Those six points are the essential reasons why the Opposition is most concerned about the manner in which the Government has gone about the negotiation and final decision to construct in this manner the Australian Maritime Museum at Darling Harbour. It is no secret to any member of this House, certainly not members from New South Wales, that the whole Darling Harbour complex is seen by the Wran Government as its contribution to the Bicentennial, and it sees the development as its means of ensuring its re-election at the next State election to be held in 1988. The reality is that many Australians, not just those living in New South Wales, are genuinely concerned about projects such as Darling Harbour, and the Federal involvement in that project specifically through the Australian National Maritime Museum. At a time such as this, when the nation is facing major economic difficulties, the Government continues with the belief that somehow or other we can construct magnificent buildings for future generations to marvel at-though I doubt they will-when they will be facing the reality of having to carry the bill.

Across the nation in the context of the Bicentenary, there has been far too much emphasis on the construction of memorials, and far too little emphasis on the essential ingredient of the Bicentenary which should be to make Australia a better country in which to live, to give Australians of all backgrounds, of all ages, a sense of pride in and respect for their nation and a belief in its future. In a State such as New South Wales, which has, to put it mildly, an appalling record over the last decade in areas such as hospitals, roads, education and so forth, it is extraordinary that the New South Wales State Government is prepared to fund hundreds of millions of dollars for a project such as Darling Harbour, and is able to get the co-operation and support of the Federal Government as a party to that activity.

How can one explain this approach to people in a State such as New South Wales who do not have the benefit of living in the capital city of Sydney, the citizens of which will be virtually exclusively those who may gain something from the Darling Harbour project, or how can you explain to people in a place such as Gulargambone, Guyra or Byrock who have to drink their water out of a dirty old dam in time of drought because they have no water reticulation system? How can one explain what is proposed to people in the country such as those in parts of the far west whose local councils today are now so bereft of funds that serious consideration is being given to ploughing up asphalt roads and going back to dirt because they can no longer maintain the capital costs?

Yet, in the face of all that, the New South Wales State Government is prepared to enter into an arrangement with the private sector on the one hand-we have no objection to that in principle-involving its commitment of hundreds of millions of dollars to develop the Darling Harbour project at a time when we seriously ask the question: Are the priorities right?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. The House is dealing with the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill. It is not talking about the New South Wales Government project at the Darling Harbour development. It has nothing to do with this Bill.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Bradfield is developing his argument.
—I sympathise with your difficulty, Madam Speaker. The realities are that the national museum project is part of the Darling Harbour project, and that is the essential ingredient.
—It is not.
—I am sorry that the honourable member says that it is not. Read the second reading speech of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen).
—Order! I would point out to the honourable member for Throsby that the second reading amendment has considerably widened the debate.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. As I was pointing out for the benefit of the honourable member, if he had bothered to read the Minister's second reading speech, he would have noted that the land on which this project is being constructed is a grant from the New South Wales Government as part of its development of the Darling Harbour project. To seriously suggest that there is no link between the two is absurd. The point I have made, and I make yet again, is that the whole question of priorities in terms of the expenditure of public funds at this time and in this manner is a matter of the gravest concern to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections, which is the basis on which this decision was made, contained a whole range of alternative propositions about which this Parliament has not heard a word. Why has it not heard a word? I will tell honourable members why. It is because this Government decided that it was an urgent project. Contrary to the principles on which all public works projects are meant to be reviewed by this Parliament, it was determined at the time that the Public Works Committee which the Government controls would not have the opportunity to ask these pertinent questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they hiding?

—What are they hiding? I will tell the honourable member what they are hiding-the deal that they entered into with the Wran Government, a sordid deal involving a piece of land which otherwise probably would have remained empty and therefore a possible focus for complaint and concern from the Opposition in the State Parliament. For all of those reasons this Federal Government became a party to a sordid deal, a deal which will cost the Australian people overall, as well as the people of New South Wales, substantial sums in future years. The projected cost of $30m, which has been allocated by the Parliament because of the request of the Government, is obviously not going to be enough to cover the cost of constructing this building. So little has been done, and the Estimates committees of the Senate, which have conducted a review of this matter, have raised a whole range of issues which were never satisfactorily answered in terms of the preliminary planning of this particular project.

SPEECH.PARA: For all of those reasons, the Opposition now has no alternative but to bring into this Parliament our concerns, to let the Australian people know that this Government has been prepared to bypass all the normal review mechanisms of the Parliament to get this project through. It has left this so late, less than two years before the Bicentennial, that the prospect of construction in that time is virtually zero. The New South Wales Minister for Public Works, Mr Brereton, has gone on record publicly and made that point himself. He has gone further; he has tried to dissociate himself from the whole thing. It is a bit late, having obviously entered into this deal with the Federal Government in the first place, to now argue that the project will not be finished, but to say `I am not responsible' is absurd, because the construction contract rests essentially with the New South Wales Government. In our amendment to the second reading motion I have made the point that we are most concerned about the details of these contractual arrangements because they involve, the Wran Government being prepared to enter into deals with the Builders Labourers Federation by which very generous site allowances have been made available to that union at a time when, in our own Parliament only a few weeks ago, we passed legislation to outlaw that particular union.

It would be interesting to see what the Wran Government has been up to in this whole matter. Why did it enter into a deal to give selective site allowances to that particular union-in fact, to give that union a monopoly situation in the construction not only of this particular project but of the Darling Harbour project overall? We want those details. We want full disclosure of the arrangements with the New South Wales Government for the construction of this museum in the Darling Harbour redevelopment site, and we want to know what was the impact of the Wran Government's decision at that time to give the Builders Labourers Federation a monopoly interest over construction jobs in Darling Harbour.

We want to understand why the existing facilities of the Sydney Maritime Museum were not better utilised. Why is it that in Sydney-not far from the very site of the Australian National Maritime Museum-there is probably Australia's most successful private museum, the Sydney Maritime Museum? This museum has an excellent record. It has a substantial base in the community. It has many volunteers who work regularly for it. We were told initially that the two museums were going to work side by side; that there were going to be projects that they would work on together, for example some of the ships, four of which are held by the private museum-including the famous James Craig, which was brought up from Tasmania some years ago and is being rebuilt, primarily with private sector funding and public donations, with little support from the respective governments. That particular museum could have been used as the basis of the Australian collection. At this time, because of our serious financial problems, surely greater thought should have been given to whether a combination of a national museum and the Sydney Maritime Museum might not have been a more cost-effective route to follow. I am reliably informed by the management of the Sydney Maritime Museum that, despite its offers of co-operation and assistance, it has been spurned.

Once again we see the typical bureaucratic position of the Commonwealth-in this case an instrumentality-taking the view: `We do not have to work with you. We will go it alone'. Those who are involved in the Sydney Maritime Museum are less than impressed and certainly the Opposition is less than impressed with the way in which the administration of the National Maritime Museum has been prepared virtually to ignore the obvious contribution which the Sydney Maritime Museum ought to be allowed to make.

Whatever way one looks at this matter, it is a shonky operation. It has been put together in a very short period to try to complete construction in a time frame which is virtually impossible. Yet this legislation has been forced upon the Parliament at this time. In the Senate Estimates Committee hearing not a single one of the issues raised by our colleagues in the Senate was satisfactorily answered. On top of that we have the greater embarrassment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), a few months ago, going to America with a proposition that perhaps we could get the Americans to pay our Bicentennial bills.

I recall that a few months ago the Japanese were told somewhat arrogantly that they would be expected to carry the cost of the National Science Centre. Of course, the Japanese had other ideas; they politely refused, although I gather negotiations are still in train. The same principle applied to the Maritime Museum. It was decided that the United States should be prepared to pay the bill, so when the Prime Minister went there he took with him a very expensive brochure. This matter was raised on and off in the Estimates Committee debate in the Senate but for the benefit of honourable members let me go through the facts once again. I am quoting from the National Times of 2 May this year; The Department has spent $22,000 on 300 four-page promotional brochures with colour covers at a cost of $70 each, and `the Museum Director has refused to answer questions about thousands of dollars paid as consultancy fees'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth noting.

—It is worth noting. Our colleague Senator Michael Baume, who has done some excellent work on the Waste Watch Committee, obtained a quotation on this brochure. He showed it to a firm and asked how much it would cost to produce 300. The quote he received from Micro-Data Pty Ltd was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Maritime Museum two leaf, A3 folder, 10 colours-
Ten colours, note, including gold.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gold?

—Yes, including gold, would have cost $8,925. That is the price quoted by a private sector printer compared with the enormous price of some $22,000 which was paid for these particular pamphlets by the Government. It is an extraordinary situation because, as was revealed in debate in the Senate, apparently the enemy of the Maritime Museum administration was none other than the Department of Finance. Whatever truth or falsity may lie in that line of reasoning, I do not know because this House has never been given a serious explanation by any Minister, including the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, who is responsible, for what is going on.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, a range of other consultancies has been entered into. For example, one cost $100,000 and was for the services of television film maker Peter Luck, who incidentally made a very good television film on the museum. I am not in any sense denigrating Mr Luck's contribution to this project but I make the point that $100,000 for a very short television film to be shown in America is significant because we have not been told whether the efforts to get American finance have been successful. If they have I think Mr Luck's film can be justified. If the funds have not been forthcoming from the United States, this House has reason to be concerned about the basis upon which those decisions were made in the first place.

In addition, there was a $20,000 consultancy to see whether this museum would be commercially viable. Is it not extraordinary that we go to the extent of forcing through the Parliament expenditure of over $30m without such an assessment? If this project is completed for less than $50m I will be very surprised. Yet there is a fundamental question as to whether the museum is commercially viable. A study was to be carried out at a cost of $20,000. We understand it has not been completed. No cost benefit analysis was done. The Government simply said: `We want this money so we can support Neville Wran and his little exercise at Darling Harbour because it is important to the Australian Labor Party, the Labor Party's Federal National President and the centre of the right wing of the Labor Party machine in Australia that they win the next State election'. Everybody knows that the circumstances pertaining in New South Wales in recent years would seriously suggest that time is running out for the Wran Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened in Pittwater?

—The honourable member mentions Pittwater. His Party did not even have the courage to stand a candidate in Pittwater. It is very easy to have a Premier who says that he never lost a by-election, if he does not run ALP candidates.
—He would not face up to a fight.
—That is absolutely right.
—Let us not digress.

—For all these reasons there has been very deep concern about the manner in which this project has been conceived. Dr Marinov, a specialist on Sydney Harbour and its potential, who is also a senior lecturer in architecture at the University of New South Wales, has made the point that any international project on a similar scale to Darling Harbour-he mentions, for example, Amsterdam's east harbour development area, the London dockyard redevelopment back in the 1970s and development in various other countries such as Switzerland and France-would usually have a planning and gestation period of up to 10 years towards completion. The whole Darling Harbour project, including the Maritime Museum element, is a rush job. There is no doubt about that.

SPEECH.PARA: As a Party, we have no objection, nor do our colleagues in New South Wales, for the need to better utilise land resources. Certainly Darling Harbour has potential in that respect. But it is important that the private sector be prepared to run the risks and carry the costs wherever possible. We know that there are at least three projects for Darling Harbour, including this one funded by the Commonwealth, which are the responsibility of the governments, both State and Federal, and as a result, are a cost to the Australian taxpayer-a cost which I emphasise is not necessary because we could have gone to the private sector and said: `Build a museum-type complex. You can use elements of the building for other purposes and we will enter into a lease-back arrangement for one section which could be used as a national museum'. That is one alternative. We heard nothing of it. Nobody has made any such suggestion. I seriously put it to the Minister that such a proposition probably was not even considered.

Getting back to the Pigott report, which is the very basis upon which these decisions were allegedly made, I point out that Pigott made a number of observations. He suggested, for example, that the centre of the museum could be in the old Customs House near Circular Quay, only feet-or metres-from the very site where Captain Arthur Phillip raised the flag for the first settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—I am sorry. Just around the corner from there the honourable member will see a sign on the street saying: `This is the site where Governor Phillip of the First Fleet put up the flag'.
—He knows his bus stops.

—The honourable member for Lowe should stick to his bus stops and I will stick to my historical sites. Clearly, the concept of using the old Customs House for the Maritime Museum was a very real option. Again, the Parliament heard nothing of that. That is a Commonwealth building. Costs would have been involved in internal redevelopment and so forth, but no one has suggested to the House that this proposition was even seriously considered. Sydney Harbour also has some excellent facilities dating back to the early nineteenth century from the days of the Royal Navy. Those facilities are still there. In fact, the Royal Australian Navy uses them as a museum store for maintaining collections. What association is there between those facilities and this new project?

SPEECH.PARA: Again, we hear nothing. I emphasise once again that a range of serious questions relating to the establishment of the National Maritime Museum have not been answered. This is virtually the last chance. The Government probably does not want to answer these questions. If it does, why did it ignore the Joint Committee on Public Works in the first place? Why did it deliberately choose to have a Bill to spend over $30m of taxpayers' money through the Parliament so that it would have to answer as few questions as possible? To say that it smells would be too delicate, to put it bluntly.

The fact is that there are issues of public concern and of public money that the Government has a fundamental responsibility to face. If it does not do so here or in the other place, it will be held accountable. In two years time when the Bicentennial comes, some people especially Australian Labor Party politicians will be pleased to see the projects that are completed and all of us will be left to carry the bill.

In New South Wales we have a government which has an edifice complex. It reminds me very much of Rameses of ancient Egypt, who was more interested in building bigger pyramids than his predecessors than in solving the serious economic problems of the nation. New South Wales, the State which has the largest population in Australia and the largest economic base, today faces a whole range of serious issues in education, health and so forth which I mentioned earlier. How can we say to people: `You have to send your children to hospital in Victoria because we cannot look after them in New South Wales'? How can we say to somebody: `We cannot give you access to an operating theatre to have your hernia fixed because that is seen as elective surgery and we do not have the beds or the nurses and we have constant difficulties with doctors'? How can we seriously have a State with that standard of public health care and public service while at the same time having a government that trumpets from high the glories of Darling Harbour and how it will build these glorious monuments for the future without worrying about the present?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a Marmaduke pyramid?

—Yes, it is a Marmaduke pyramid; there is no doubt about that. We do not mind having Chinese gardens or anything else that the Government wants to put there. That is fine. But I wonder why the taxpayers have to carry the bill. They are the same taxpayers who for months have been telling us and the Government day by day that they have had enough, and rightly so. They cannot see how one can talk about a society in which some standard of equality ought to be the basis of government services, when in my State of New South Wales the Government is prepared to spend millions, if not billions, to win seats and votes in the main cities, and it does not care a damn about anybody else. It is these issues for which the Australian people will hold the Government responsible because people are concerned about a `fair go'. They are not impressed to see circumstances in their State in which, if one does not live in Sydney, Wollongong or Newcastle, one is virtually a second class citizen.
—That is rubbish, and you know it.

—The honourable member for Throsby should know it because he lives on the edge of Wollongong. Newcastle and Wollongong are in the same position as Sydney on these issues. The reality, therefore, is that the Opposition looks upon this whole proposal with considerable doubt. Before I finalise my observations for the benefit of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), who is at the table, I will put to him a series of questions-I will give him a copy of them-which I ask him to try to answer in his summing up.

SPEECH.PARA: The questions are these: What is the projected budget for establishing a collection for the National Maritime Museum? What is the projected cost for designing and exhibiting the National Maritime Museum collection? What is the projected annual budget for the Maritime Museum? On what basis was the proposed Darling Harbour site for the National Maritime Museum agreed? Was a detailed examination carried out of all available sites before a final decision was made? What were the findings of that examination? Has any consideration been given to the suggestion in the report of the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections that Spectacle Island could become a valuable adjunct of the National Maritime Museum? Have there been any discussions with the Navy about historical material and sites, and what agreements have been reached? What discussions have there been with other government departments and bodies in an effort to access historical maritime material? What discussions have there been between the Sydney Maritime Museum and the National Maritime Museum in regard to an association between the two bodies? What proposals have been put by either group, and on what grounds were they accepted or rejected? What is the proposed relationship between the two bodies?

I regard those as being the essential questions to which this Parliament deserves to have answers. There are many other aspects which have not been adequately covered, but at a time such as this, when money is short and when we have to look most carefully at a cost benefit analysis of every dollar that is spent by this Parliament, it is the responsibility of the Opposition to hold the Government responsible in this matter. It is for that reason that I have moved the amendment circulated in my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, Madam Speaker; I have pleasure in seconding the amendment and reserve my right to speak later in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess it is best to describe the speech of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), which we have just had the misfortune to listen to, as one of the most whingeing, moaning statements we have heard in this House. I thought that we were talking about the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill, but we had a diatribe ranging from internal New South Wales politics to discussion about the need to protect the Australian dollar, and how each dollar must be spent carefully-this from an Opposition which has promised over $10 billion worth of expenditure should it ever be returned to government, a disastrous prospect. This is the Opposition which sits here daily bleating about the way the country is being run but which every day adds more expenditure to the promises it makes. Members of the Opposition are very difficult people to follow indeed. Look at the Opposition's amendment. It indicates the lack of depth and the lack of ability the Opposition has to tackle these important issues.

SPEECH.PARA: We should not forget that the proposal to construct the National Maritime Museum was put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the 1983 election campaign. It does not involve just the National Maritime Museum; it involves also building a national aviation museum. These joint proposals recognise the fact that this country's whole history is based on transport. The first settlers arrived by ship and, once they were established, our growth was dependent upon maritime merchant trade and naval protection. In later years, of course, we established the aviation system, and our country is still largely operated and managed by our aviation and maritime sectors.

The Opposition has moved this wonderful amendment. The first part suggests that the proposed construction of the Australian National Maritime Museum should have been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. Quite frankly, it is up to that Committee to make that decision. The Committee has the option, it has the power and it has the ability to take that matter on as a matter of course and to examine the proposed expenditure. So the first part of the amendment is a lot of absolute nonsense. The second part of the amendment claims the Government failed to offer a full explanation of why the alternative accommodation suggested in the report of the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections was not acceptable. The facts of the matter are that the Pigott report was examined by a series of intergovernmental committees. It was fully examined by Cabinet; the options were fully discussed-that is no secret-and a recommendation was made as a result of the Pigott recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't tell the Parliament.

—The honourable member can sit back and bleat all he likes, but that is the fact. It is an absolute myth to suggest that the Pigott recommendations were not properly examined and that due consideration was not given to them. So the second part of the amendment is also a joke; it does not mean a darned thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The third part of the amendment claims that the Government failed to `ensure that there are no significant cost overruns that might arise as a result of union pressure'. Here we go-a union bash in anticipation. Honourable members opposite do not even wait for an industrial dispute to arise now; they sit back here and move amendments in anticipation of industrial disputes. How bad can the Opposition get? The honourable member for Bradfield moved paragraph (3) as a serious amendment. We are talking about the establishment of a primary museum, a national maritime museum, and the Opposition comes into the chamber with an amendment which is nothing more than a joke. Paragraph (4) reads:
restrict the open-ended nature of the total cost of the project. . .

What does that mean? I listened to the honourable member's speech. I did not once hear him raise any suggestion that there would be a cost overrun. He had no evidence. He just puts forward mealy-mouthed proposals to knock anything this Government does. Paragraph (5) reads:
disclose details of the arrangement with the New South Wales Government . . .

The honourable member has had a chance for months now to put questions about this matter on notice, and he has not done so. Again it is disclosed that these amendments are just mealy-mouthed amendments simply to knock an exciting project and get political mileage from it. Paragraph (6) reads:
utilise the existing facilities, resources and expertise of the Sydney Maritime Museum . . .

As the honourable member went crook about the Government not adopting the recommendations of the Pigott report, paragraph (6) becomes an absolute joke. It is an absolute conundrum for the honourable member to say in paragraph (2) that the Government did not examine the Pigott report and then in paragraph (6) say that we should have utilised the existing facilities of the Sydney Maritime Museum. Opposition members should stop and think about their own amendments and how silly they obviously are. The honourable member talked about internal New South Wales politics. We had the great example of the fascist Liberal Party in New South Wales using this House and Liberal speakers in this House for the purpose of its internal New South Wales political debate. I find that tragic.

This proposal is important. It recognises the prime importance of the maritime history of Australia to our overall growth and development. It recognises the fact that throughout our long history we have survived only because of our maritime forces, both merchant and naval. It is a nonsense to suggest, as the Opposition has today, that any collection of artefacts should be fragmented and put in different locations. There is already a vast collection of maritime artefacts reposed in different sites throughout Australia. We have the Polly Woodside in Melbourne. Ships are being restored in Queensland and New South Wales. It seems to me that if we are serious about putting together a history of maritime activities it has to be in one location. It has to be a whole history-not just ships but maps, the way of life of the early sailors, the types of vessels, the types of constructions, the types of engines, the type of navigation and so on. It is wrong to suggest that we have a fragmentation in different locations. It is in our national interest that all the various aspects of our maritime history be located on one site so that there is a point of reference for all the people in Australia who have individual bits and pieces. Whether they have just a map from an old sailing ship, a barometer from one of our early historical ships or other paraphernalia collected from many shipwrecks around Australia, these items should be put together on one site so that our entire maritime history is presented as a sequence of events and future generations can come along and see it.

I am not at all enthralled by the suggestion of the honourable member for Bradfield that our maritime history could be split and shared and that the proposed Australian National Maritime Museum is not a proposal that deserves support. The Opposition amendments are really a means for Opposition members to get up in the House and have a slight dig at the Government when in fact they generally support the proposal. It is a pity Opposition members do not come into the chamber and say: `It is a damn good proposal. It is an exciting proposal. We should get behind it, and stop the absolute rubbish we go on with sometimes, having a little knock every time the Government does something'.

More important, perhaps, than the marine history of this country is the proposed national aviation museum, which I am personally more excited about. The national aviation museum is supposed to be located in Victoria, where it should go. In my electorate is the Mangalore Airport, which is a historical airport because it is the airport through which many migrants entered this country. Even today, it has a complete history in its own right. It has the original hangars and the original airport buildings. I believe that in the long term it should be the site chosen for the future aviation museum. It can land jumbos and all large aircraft, and it is an excellent site for the proposed aviation museum.

TALK.START.PARA: —It can still be used today, can't it?

—It is still being used today. Last Easter the Sport Aircraft Association of Australia had an annual meet weekend at Mangalore Airfield, and 40,000 people, from all over Victoria and from elsewhere, turned up. That just proves its ideal location, its closeness to metropolitan Melbourne, Shepparton and the major regional centres in Victoria. That proves it can attract a crowd and handle the 700 aircraft which actually turned up. But that is a matter for the future, and I will certainly do what I can to ensure that Mangalore becomes the site of the national aviation museum and that that becomes a reality in the near future.
—It ought to be there. It is the best site in Australia.

—It is the best aviation site in Australia. I suggest that Sydney Harbour is the best site in Australia for a maritime museum. That is where the First Fleet arrived. It is a natural harbour of great beauty and capacity, and I am more than confident that the National Maritime Museum will go very well there.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed, frankly, that the Opposition has adopted the tactic it has today to try to get political mileage out of internal New South Wales politics rather than to tackle this as a national museum and as a national issue. I am sorry that the House has had to hear the mealy-mouthed approach we have heard. But I look forward to the speech of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I know he will tackle the issues more on a national basis, with a slight favour of Tasmania no doubt thrown in. Nevertheless, I look forward to his speech. I recommend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) for his remarks. He was correct in anticipating that I will be saying something about Tasmania. I particularly note the presence in the chamber of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). I start by commending the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), on a most forthright, courageous and persuasive speech in which he set out a number of matters which concern not only him and this side of the House but also all Australians. I think we can start on a basic premise that there would be bipartisan support for the proposition that Australia must have a national maritime museum, but nobody in his wildest dreams could have anticipated the chain of circumstances, which were described by the shadow Minister, which involved a sordid deal and a shonky transaction-a chain of events which gives me no pleasure and I am certain gives no other Australian pleasure because, quite frankly, this is what comes about when one has political considerations determining matters which ought to have been determined in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn immediately to the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield, which I had the honour to second, and I refer specifically to paragraph (1) of the amendment, where it states:
. . . the House condemns the-
Hawke socialist-
Government for its failure to protect the public interest through its failure to-
(1) refer the proposed construction of the Australian National Maritime Museum to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: The honourable member for Denison said that he was quoting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield. I have the amendment in front of me and I do not see anything about the `Hawke socialist Government'.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—By the device of preventing this matter going before the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, the State of Tasmania was denied natural justice in that it was denied the opportunity to put the case that the National Maritime Museum should be built in Australia's maritime State, Australia's only island State-the State of Tasmania. Whilst it is unlikely that the Hawke-Wran agreement, whereby a $50m rort will take place, would have been set aside, at least before the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works a very carefully prepared case for the State of Tasmania could have been put, and it would have been within the power of the Public Works Committee to look at alternative sites. Together with my colleagues the honourable member for Franklin, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who has shown a particular interest in this matter also because the Australian Maritime College is in his electorate, the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), I protest on behalf of all Tasmanians that we were denied the opportunity of going before the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. This is not a sour grapes speech. Tasmanians would not be complaining if we felt that we had been beaten fairly and squarely.
—Right.
—The honourable member for Franklin says `Right'. He is correct. Our complaint is that we now believe, and the evidence is overwhelming, that we took part in a race which was rigged.
—We could not win it.

—We took part in a race which we could not win. I draw attention to the fact that the proposal was supported in Tasmania by the Premier and by members on both sides of the House. The proposal was also supported very strongly by the then Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. Ken Wriedt, who has a strong maritime background. It had the support of the Hobart City Council. A site was available in the magnificent and historic Hobart waterfront area. The money was available, the people were there, the opportunity was there, but we were robbed and cheated. As the honourable member for Bradfield has said, and I adopt his words, this has come about as a result of a sordid deal and one that does no credit to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or Premier Wran. The second part of the amendment to which I wish to refer is that the project is open-ended. I refer specifically to paragraph 4 of the amendment, where we are condemning the Hawke socialist Government for its failure to `restrict the open-ended nature of the total cost of the project, which does not include purchase, preservation and exhibition of a collection, or administrative, educational and promotional costs of the museum'. By this legislation $30m of taxpayers' money will go towards the establishment of the National Maritime Museum. However, I have to agree with the honourable member for Bradfield that it will be an absolute miracle if the thing is completed for less than $50m. That is why Tasmania has fifty million reasons for feeling that it has been very, very badly treated-disgracefully treated-on this issue by Prime Minister Hawke and Premier Wran.
—He hates Tasmania.

—As the honourable member for Franklin correctly says, he hates Tasmania. They both hate Tasmania. Sydney already has so much going for it in this area. There is the Sydney Maritime Museum. I join with the honourable member for Bradfield in saying: `Why were not those already established facilities utilised?'
—The old Customs House.

—The old Customs House is a classic example. The former Royal Navy base is another example. Why were these not utilised? The plain fact is that this is a Marmaduke pyramid and the reference to Rameses is correct. This is a Marmaduke pyramid, a present from Bob to Marmaduke-from the Prime Minister to the current Premier of New South Wales--
— Order!
—From `the Prime Minister to Marmaduke' is all right.
—who hopefully will be replaced.
—On the Pittwater result, he won't be.

—Do not worry about that, comrade. We won, and if the Minister does not believe that, he should read the result in the paper. The Liberal Party held the seat and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, know that they pay out on the Melbourne Cup whether the winner wins by a short half head or 25 lengths. The prize money is the same and the gold cup is the same. I think the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), was correct in saying that it was not unparliamentary for me to refer to Marmaduke, but I certainly should have referred to the Prime Minister as such, as he is a member of this House.
—The honourable member for Mackellar will not encourage the honourable member for Denison.

—I am always grateful for his help. It is a rort-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) repeatedly talks in this place about rorts-and I have to say that we in Tasmania are feeling very sore about this particular rort. The point I make, as the honourable member for Bradfield has pointed out, is that if the museum had to be in Sydney, if Tasmania had been beaten fairly and squarely, that would have been a different matter, but why is it that we were denied the opportunity of going before the Public Works Committee and putting our case?
—It has already promised all these new industries.
—The honourable member for Franklin refers to all these promises, and the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) is in the chamber. He has promised all these magnificent sunrise industries.
—The sun has set, I think.

—I think the sun has set. They have not come. It must be the longest sunrise in the history of the world. Why is it that the matters raised in the Senate Estimates Committee have not been responded to? Is it that the Government is determined not to answer these questions, to clam up and not provide the Parliament with the information the Parliament is seeking? I think the thing is fishy and, further, I think there is a prima facie case for a royal commission into this entire sordid affair. I love the sea. Most members of parliament have had some connection with the sea. The honourable member for Franklin comes from a seafaring family.
—Ha, ha, ha!

—A substantial portion of my family has served in the Royal Australian Navy and I am proud that I have served in the Royal Australian Naval Reserve. There is a tremendous interest in the sea. A constituent of mine and the honourable member for Franklin, Mr Bernie Cuthbertson, completed earlier this year a most historic re-enactment of the circumnavigation of Tasmania by Captain James Kelly. In the whaler Eliza, beautifully built, strictly according to specifications, Captain Bernie Cuthbertson and his gallant crew circumnavigated Tasmania and re-enacted precisely the voyage of Captain James Kelly. Now Captain Cuthbertson, in pursuing his appreciation of Australian maritime history, is planning a voyage from Tasmania right up the eastern coast of Australia to Botany Bay. That will be a most magnificent historic achievement. In view of the lighthearted interjection that my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) made when I talked about the seafaring background of the honourable member for Franklin, I point out that to my knowledge he is the only member of parliament who holds a Royal Humane Society medal for saving another person from drowning. Not only has he a seafaring background but he has actually saved the life of a person and has been decorated for it, and they do not give away Royal Humane Society medals lightly.
-I think the honourable member might come back to the legislation.

—Yes. The failure of the Government to disclose the details of the arrangement with the New South Wales Government to construct the Museum at Darling Harbour redevelopment site and the impact of the Wran Government's decision to grant the Builders Labourers Federation monopoly over construction jobs at Darling Harbour have occurred at the time when the Wran Government has moved to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation, and at a time when this Parliament has passed legislation to outlaw the Builders Labourers Federation. Yet, as part of this sordid, shonky deal the Builders Labourers Federation, pursuant to the patronage of the Wran Government, gets a total monopoly over the construction jobs at Darling Harbour. Finally, as the honourable member for Bradfield so eloquently pointed out, why has the Sydney Maritime Museum been spurned? It is because it is to the Sydney Maritime Museum that the James Craig was taken. It ran aground at Recherche Bay in southern Tasmania, in the electorate of the honourable member for Franklin. It has been taken all the way up to Sydney after work was done in Tasmania to reconstruct it, and it is one of the features at the Sydney Maritime Museum.
—You helped with that, too.

—In a way I did, but honestly, one wonders. The decision to place the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney is, with respect, wrong. It was not a fair race, the State of Tasmania did not get a fair hearing from either this Prime Minister or that Premier of New South Wales. The State of Tasmania was denied natural justice. If we had had the chance to put our case and we had been beaten fairly and squarely before the Public Works Committee, there would be no complaint. But we have been robbed and we have had to sit by and watch a $50m rort arranged by a conspiracy, which will lead to the production of a Marmaduke pyramid which should have been in our State.

SPEECH.PARA: We challenge the fact that this Government has covered up, that it will not answer questions in the Estimates Committee and will not respond to the matters raised by the honourable member for Bradfield. We believe that what has been done is a travesty of justice and we support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield. I would like to have had the opportunity to add a paragraph (7) to his amendment that `in justice and equity the National Maritime Museum should have been built in Tasmania'. It is a great tragedy that political decisions, insider deals, and all these other sordid aspects to which I have referred have led to what has now happened. Tasmania will never forget and will never forgive the Hawke socialist Government for what it has done on this issue. I conclude by saying that I support the remarks of the honourable member for McEwen that the Australian Aviation Museum should be built at Mangalore in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Tasmania wanted that, too.
—Keep quiet, Molotov.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison knows that he must refer to other members by their titles.

—The honourable member for Throsby. I have campaigned for Mangalore because it so happens that Mangalore is the proper site. I would like to record the support of Mr Ian Bayles and others in Victoria committed to the preservation of Australian aviation history, but in fairness and propriety that is where the Australian aviation museum should be. I wish the honourable member for McEwen every success in getting it there. I hope that he gets a fairer hearing with his submissions for Mangalore than Tasmania got for its submissions for the Australian Maritime Museum. We are bitter, we are disappointed, we have been robbed, and I repeat that the Hawke socialist Government's actions in this whole sordid affair will be neither forgotten or forgiven.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill and, equally naturally, reject the amendments moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I have listened to the speeches made by the two Opposition members in this debate. I was wondering what the honourable member for Bradfield was talking about. We had a whole litany of the so-called sins of the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales-everything ranging from not supplying water to some outback towns to various other sins. But in talking about this Bill and this museum, what the honourable member for Bradfield seems to overlook or cannot understand is that this basically is not a New South Wales project, it is not a Sydney project; it is something for the people of Australia. It is a national project, not a New South Wales State project, and that is why we are talking about it in the national Parliament. That is why the legislation is being dealt with here. It is not a State matter; it just so happens that it is in Sydney. We heard from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) the big whinge, `We was robbed'.
—We were, too.

—Yes, you were robbed. Let us get one thing straight. The honourable member for Bradfield and the honourable member for Denison kept referring to the Public Works Committee. I would have thought that those honourable members, with their long standing and many years' service in this Parliament, would know the role of that Committee. I happen to be a member of that Committee, and I say in all honesty that I would have preferred-and my views are quite well known on the Public Works Committee on this matter-this project to have been referred to that Committee, to which I believe all projects should be referred. But having said that, I point out that members of the Committee have visited the site once; we have visited the offices once; we were briefed by the respective Ministers on the fact that the project was a matter of urgency. I refer honourable members to page 3958 of Hansard of 28 November, which contains the Minister's speech and also the views of the Committee put by the Acting Chairman of the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar).

SPEECH.PARA: Let us face it, this is not the first project that will be dealt with as a matter of urgency before the Public Works Committee and it will not be the last. The honourable member for Denison said that the Tasmanian Government wanted an opportunity to appear before the Public Works Committee and put us into some sort of arbitral situation in deciding where the museum was to go. That is not the role of the Public Works Committee at all. References are made to us on the Committee, and I would have thought that people who have served in this Parliament for many years would be aware of this. We look at government expenditure. We do not decide and we would not have decided between Tasmania and New South Wales as to where the project was to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is a valid point of order. The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works decided--
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Sir, would you hear me until I finish? He is misrepresenting the law--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—I suggest that the honourable member for Denison should read the guidelines of the Public Works Committee anyway. I turn to the other point both Opposition members were making about the site. Much has been said about the Sydney Maritime Museum being spurned by the National Maritime Museum. We should get our facts straight. A couple of approaches were made by the National Maritime Museum to the Sydney Maritime Museum. One approach was an offer of $1m to buy it out, which it rejected. The second approach was an arrangement to lease its vessels on a commercial basis. Both were rejected by the Sydney Maritime Museum. They were rejected, I suppose, because it wanted to remain independent and separate.

SPEECH.PARA: Originally it wanted the Commonwealth-people opposite who talk about the Waste Watch Committee and so on should listen to this-to give free accommodation on the museum site and $1m a year-and what would Senator Michael Baume make of that-and for the museum to retain control of its collection. This Government-this Hawke socialist Government, as the honourable member for Denison loves to say-will not spend money to maintain a private collection, nor should it. If it did, Opposition members would be jumping up and down screaming and running to their famous Waste Watch Committee about it. They should not be hypocritical and if they make speeches in this House they should make sure they get all their facts right first.

We have heard about the James Craig, a good project; I am all for restoring ships and all the rest of it. That is a $7m project and it is already $5m in the red, in debt. Does the honourable member for Denison want the Government to pick up that as well? I suppose he does. There is no way it will be finished by 1988 and it probably will never be finished.

Now I come to the best of them all. I am more surprised at the attitude of the honourable member for Bradfield than at the attitude of his colleague the member for Denison on this, because I thought that the honourable member for Bradfield would know Sydney. They talked of the site recommended by the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections. The site recommended by Pigott is used as a Navy ammunition dump and it is still in use. Eventually it will be moved to the electorate of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) down to Jervis Bay, but at the moment it is being used as an ammunition dump. What did the Opposition members want? Do they want the whole collection to go there among all the ammunition? That would be a great tourist attraction, would it not? The only way one can get there at the moment is by navy boat. That would be good! It would be another case for the Waste Watch Committee-the Australian Navy conveying passengers to the National Maritime Museum, where people then pick their way among the bombs and other ammunition to look at our national collection. Really! If honourable members opposite want to talk about this matter they might make a case that it could have eventually been the site, but it will be 20 years before the ammunition is moved out of there to Jervis Bay. If honourable members opposite want to wait for 20 years, they could have had the museum there, but at the moment I am afraid that the bombs and other ammunition are taking priority over the national collection.

As I said before, we had the usual whinge from the honourable member for Denison that they were robbed. I do not accept that. It will be good for a few lines, I guess, in the Hobart Mercury, but it does not carry much weight in this place. As we all know, the National Maritime Museum was one of a number of projects for which individual States put in a bid. It was allocated to New South Wales, as the air museum will be allocated to Victoria. I believe that the Tasmanians were talking about an arctic museum or a national aquarium, but they could not get their act together and get their submission in and correct. If there is any criticism, if they feel they have dipped out, they have no one to blame but the present Tasmanian Government, whose members were too slack to get their act together and put in a proper submission.

I must say that it is with particular pleasure that I speak on this Australian National Maritime Museum Bill. What we are talking about here is not just the siting of a museum and setting it up under the legislation; we are talking also about the museum building at Darling Harbour in Sydney.

It is planned that the building will be completed and open to the public by early 1988. I have no reason to doubt that that will occur. I think honourable members should be aware that this museum is important to Australia's cultural, historic, educational and, indeed, tourist development. I stress, it will be a national museum. That is a point that the Opposition seems to be overlooking. It will be a national museum, not a State museum, and it will be a museum in which all Australians will be able to take pride.

As the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) said in his second reading speech, possibly no other country has relied more on the sea and acknowledged the debt it owes less than has Australia. The legislation now being debated, and what will flow from it, will redress that. This Bill will establish the museum as a body corporate. Its function will be to develop an Australian national maritime collection, to preserve, acquire, recover and maintain maritime historical material, and to exhibit that material which is in the national maritime collection or otherwise, both in Australia and overseas. The museum will also be able to conduct and assist in research and disseminate information relating to Australian maritime history. This is very important.

I looked early this morning at a copy of a research paper, which I have here and which I got last year when in England visiting the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich. The difference, I suppose, between the National Maritime Museum at Greenwich and the one that we are setting up is that the Greenwich museum is basically a naval museum. It is important to recognise that the museum that we are setting up will not be a basic naval museum; it will be a social history museum-a museum not for one part of Australia or one aspect of the armed forces but for all Australians.

As I have just said, it will be a social history museum and will reflect the interaction of all Australians with the sea; it will deal with all aspects, including recreational and commercial aspects. The museum, I am pleased to say, will focus on people; it will be a people-orientated museum, not an object one. For too long museums throughout the world have had exhibits behind glass cases and things like that, but this will be a people-based museum. When one thinks of Australia's image abroad one tends to overlook the role that the sea has played in Australia. There is a poem by Dorothea Mackellar which runs:
I love a sunburnt country, a land of sweeping plains . . .

This is the image sometimes portrayed of Australia-the outback of Australia, the Australia of Chipps Rafferty or, indeed, of Crocodile Dundee. Yet Australia is, more than most countries, a maritime nation. We are an island continent. This is a land discovered and rediscovered, not by overland travellers but by seafarers. The Aboriginal people came here 40,000 to 50,000 years ago during the ice age. Although sea levels were well down, they still had to cross reaches of water, sometimes up to 40 or 50 miles wide. Presumably, they did this on very simple rafts. There is an Aboriginal dreamtime story which refers to an area in my electorate called Windang Island, or Canoe Island, which is named after the mythological canoe in which the dreamtime heroes arrived in this land from across the sea.

We have had navigators visit the shores of Australia from South East Asia, especially from Malacca. For hundreds of years these people made seasonal visits to the north shore of Australia when winds were favourable. They came there to fish for trepang, beche-de-mer, in our shallow tropical waters. Then there were the European navigators, the ones we learnt about in school-Hartog, Van Diemen, Torres, Cook, and La Perouse-who all visited these shores in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. We have had European settlement with the first fleet-all this by sea. We must not concentrate just on the sea, because there was early exploration throughout Australia, on the land-and indeed around Australia-by people such as Bass and Flinders, who also came ashore near Windang or Canoe Island in my electorate and met the local Aborigines. There were the journeys of Charles Sturt by inland waters.

Popular travel, as recently as during the first part of this century, was by steamship along the coastline from Kiama. One could only go by sea from there to Woollon. One could only get from Bulli in the electorate of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) by sea before road and rail were built. It was by sea along the south coast that the mighty Illawarra was first opened up. Recently we have had refugees come here by sea. This is what the museum will deal with. It is all part of Australia's social history as it relates to the sea, or to inland exploration. I point out that, although we talk about `a sunburnt country, a land of sweeping plains', the vast percentage of Australia's population lives not in the outback, not in the electorate of Maranoa and places such as that, but by the seashore-they live along the coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been driven off the land.

—Many people who do not live by the sea, people such as the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), are drawn to the sea on their annual pilgrimage. I will bet the honourable member goes to Surfers Paradise every year for his holiday. People are drawn to the sea for their holidays.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have a very strong affinity with the sea. Much of our history and culture is intimately connected with the sea and water, yet our people pay scant attention to this keystone of our tradition. The establishment of the National Maritime Museum will, I believe, do much to redress the imbalance in our perception of our past, present and future. In conclusion, I have visited the site twice now, and I have visited the office of the museum as well. I have seen and studied a model of the proposed museum building, which architecturally is very exciting. It will be a credit to Australia. The situation on the water is an ideal one, because people will see not only the museum but also a busy harbour at work. It will be a stunning setting. I am sure that under the Director it will have a commercial element-for example, meals, films and so on. What a beautiful setting for a meal. It would be rivalled only by a meal on the forecourt of the Opera House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Belmore Basin.
—Or Belmore Basin. It will be a stunning setting. This is an exciting project, a project for all Australians. Where is the Opposition's pride in Australia, where is its pride in our social history?
—They haven't got any.

—As the honourable member for Macarthur says, the Opposition does not have any. The Opposition comes into this place and it whinges and whines. I thought that at least this Bill would be one on which we would have bipartisan support. The Australian National Maritime Museum is something for Australia and something of which every Australian can be proud. I say to the Opposition: For once in its life it should forget its parochialism, forget its narrowness and selfishness and for once think of Australia and get behind this project. It is a project that every Australian can take pride in. The Opposition should reject, as I do, the silly amendment and support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to address the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill and to add my voice to its general support by supporting the amendment moved by the Opposition. Mr Deputy Speaker, being a man of sensitivity and delicacy of thought, you would understand that when I listened to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), I shed a furtive tear or two. I am extremely disappointed that he mentioned the poem of the great Australian Dorothea Mackellar and the line `I love a sunburnt country'. It was disappointing to me to listen to the way he developed that magnificent poem by criticising people who live in the outback of Australia. I think it ill becomes him and the party he represents to speak about that poem, those most magnificent people of outback Australia and the wonderful Australian poet, Dorothea Mackellar.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I did not criticise the outback people of Australia; I have never criticised them.
-There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you quite rightly dismissed the honourable member's rather senseless objection of a meaningful interpretation of what he had said. It is disappointing that he denigrated rural Australia. I suggest to him that when he has nothing else to do-judging from the type of speech he has just delivered obviously he has plenty of time because it was not very well prepared-he go to the Parliamentary Library and ask--
—I spoke from the heart, though.

—He should just listen and he will see what speaking from the heart is when I develop the point. Just be patient, young fellow. I suggest that he go to the Library and ask the many excellent people who work so hard for us in the Library whether he can be given access to the recent writings of Dame Leonie Kramer, who benefited Australia enormously by compiling in her works some of the wonderful poems and pieces of literature of this great nation of ours. Unlike the honourable member I am very proud of our literature. If the honourable member goes to that trouble and makes meaningful use of his time he will find attached to the works of Dame Leonie Kramer a cassette which records a recital by Dorothea Mackellar at 73 years of age of her poem beginning `I love a sunburnt country'.
—What has this got to do with the Bill.
—The honourable member commented on Dorothea Mackellar's words `I love a sunburnt country'.
-While this is very interesting, the honourable member might come back to the point of the legislation.

—The point I was making was that Dorothea Mackellar loved a sunburnt country. As a young girl of 19 she went to the Continent, composed the poem and at 73 years of age actually recited it. Her recital is attached to the works of Dame Leonie Kramer. The sincerity of Dorothea Mackellar's love of Australia contrasts starkly with the contempt of the honourable member for rural Australia. I suggest that, if the honourable member wants to absorb a bit of the real spirit of Australia, he go to the Library, ask for those works and, in particular, get the cassette. If he has trouble understanding it, I will explain Dorothea Mackellar's words to him and I will not even charge him. I am just disappointed that I had to speak in that tone but his disparaging remarks upset me.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) said in his second reading speech, the need for an institution to provide Australians with a central and comprehensive record of their past and present dependence on the sea has been needed for some time. The Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections report recognised this over a decade ago when it called for the establishment of this type of museum to reflect the significance of maritime activity in the history and cultural life of our nation. We have always been known as the country of the bronzed Aussie, which echoes our close affiliation with the sea. We are now associated with the America's Cup and the world has recognised our ability to sail the waters with precision and skill. As an island continent we will always be dependent on the oceans in transport and commercial trade. The bulk of that trade will come from the people and the areas which were so denigrated by the honourable member for Throsby. Hence, there will continue to be a focus on the maritime aspects of our culture and economic activities. The establishment of the Australian National Maritime Museum reflects this awareness and recognises the need to preserve valuable artefacts of significance to us as a seafaring nation.

This Bill, when read with the protection of movable cultures and shipwrecks Bills, provides protection for our historic artefacts. Interest in Australia's maritime relics and remnants has been slow developing and has had to follow a national interest in vintage cars, steam trains and buildings of the past. However, this interest is now firmly established and is reflected in the number of maritime museums dotted across the country in our cities and small towns.

It is interesting to note the establishment of this national museum in the seventy-fifth anniversary of our Royal Australian Navy. From the earliest days of European contact and settlement the Navy has played a major part in the history of Australia. During the period of colonisation four naval officers were successive governors of New South Wales-Captains Arthur Phillip, John Hunter, Philip King and William Bligh. In 1865 an act of Parliament gave all States official powers to establish State navies. However, by 1901 all State and British ships were placed under Federal control when the Australian Government was proclaimed. It is interesting to note that when discussions were held by various leaders of the State parliaments, further to the finalisation of Australia's Federation, they were usually held on a ship from the Navy of Queensland. Even in that era Queensland was obviously a leader and it has still retained leadership, particularly in protecting the democratic rights of Australians. The Royal Australian Navy was established by King George V in 1911. The Navy and all those associated with seafaring activities can be justifiably proud that in this the Navy's seventy-fifth anniversary year plans have been unveiled for a museum and memorial that will honour its contribution to protecting and preserving our national heritage.

Australia, as a trading nation, has about 25 per cent of its gross domestic product in the foreign sector, more than 1,000 overseas shipping movements each month and 20,000 kilometres of coastline. Needless to say, we are dependent on the seas for our commercial and defence needs. During World War I-I am disappointed that the Opposition has not seen fit to pay tribute to the wonderful work of our Navy personnel during that era-our men and their horses were transported by steamships to their final destination. To accommodate men and beast certain methods had to be devised in order to provide safe passage at minimum risk. This historic effort was re-created in the Australian feature film Forty Thousand Horsemen. Only last week, people at the National Film and Sound Archive saw fit to get that film out of the archives and show it to some of my friends and me. The reason was that I had had a close association with the late Mrs Charles Chauvel, who, with her late husband, had created that film in the early and dim dark days of the Second World War. The Navy's contribution is faithfully recorded in that film. It was a magnificent contribution by the Navy to the successful conclusion of World War I.

Concern about transport of live animals is still reflected in our sheep ships, which transport hundreds of thousands of sheep a year to far destinations. I hope that the museum will accurately record the tremendous contribution to the live sheep export trade of the ships and the people who man them.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing sheepish about that at all.

—It always worries me that the Government never seems to be concerned about jobs of Australian transport workers, increased economic activity on sheep stations or jobs on ships through the provision of supplies for the live sheep export trade. This trade has made an enormous contribution to Australian agriculture. I note as an aside that the live sheep export trade has extended to trade from New Zealand, which is under the control of a Labour government. Live sheep exports were not allowed from New Zealand under Prime Minister Muldoon, but when a Labour government came in it realised the contribution that live sheep exports can make-so exports from New Zealand are now allowed. We want reference to the live sheep export trade to be recorded in the National Maritime Museum, because the ships, though not now of historic significance, reflect our dependence on this form of transport.

SPEECH.PARA: Our farm communities also rely on ships to carry millions of tonnes of grain which are exported each year. However, again the Government glossed over the canvas when talking about these issues. It seems very sensitive when it does not want recorded in the National Maritime Museum the fact that exports are quite often held up by stupid demarcation strikes at terminals-senseless strikes which occur primarily during harvest. The attitude is: `Don't worry about the rest of Australia; let's just featherbed ourselves'. It is promising to learn that at least the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has recognised the need for an investigation into the handling, storage and transport of grain.

TALK.START.PARA: -I hope that the honourable member for Groom will ultimately come back to the Bill, which is the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill.
—I was laying the foundation, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the next point that I want to raise.
—We do not want too much mortar on it.

—I hope that in the National Maritime Museum recognition will be given to the feats of sailing ships in transporting grain. Grain trading ships made a great contribution to the development of the agricultural industry. That fact will be acknowledged in a re-creation in the Gulf in South Australia. That brings me to the point that, irrespective of what the honourable member for Throsby said, we can have transport ships only if we have something to put in them. Those products come from the areas that he denigrated.

SPEECH.PARA: I very rarely disagree with the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I understand the enormous fight he has put up to have this museum placed in Tasmania. Unfortunately, I disagree with him in this instance. My support goes to placing the Maritime Museum in Sydney. After all, that is the birthplace of our nation. I can understand the feeling of outrage of the honourable member for Denison-who is normally a very placid soul-because he is upset by what your Government, Mr Deputy Speaker, has done by cutting funding to Port Arthur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!
—As the honourable member for Mallee says, it is shameful.
—Half finished.

—It is half finished. He is a Victorian and he understands the difficulties of Tasmanians. When a person such as the honourable member for Denison is inflamed, he gets upset. I would like to say to the Tasmanian people that they can thank heaven that they have a representative such as him and all the other representatives from the Liberal Party in that State who have all put up a fight.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that generally my support for the placement of the national monuments and museums would be to have them here in Canberra, but unfortunately this time it would not be suitable because of Canberra's geographic situation. It is interesting to note that Darling Harbour in 1988 will be the focal point of our Bicentennial activities. In placing the Maritime Museum there, at the gateway to Australia, millions of tourists will be able to appreciate our seafaring history. they will also be able to view a range of artefacts, from sailing ships of yesteryear-I have spoken about them-all types of ships, to Ken Warby's world water speed record boat, the Spirit of Australia. The establishment of this museum will also enable the preservation of valuable historic artefacts which no doubt would be lost or sold off if such a national collection were not instigated. Too often we hear of valuable relics of our history being auctioned off in London or New York. It is encouraging to read that the museum's director will have some latitude in purchasing such historic pieces.

As a free enterprise person, I am pleased to see that the museum will be encouraged to adopt an entrepreneurial outlook in organising its activities. While such activities as a book store and souvenir shop will not be able to sustain the complete running of the museum, they will provide some revenue which will meet part of the running costs. I anticipate that the establishment of a maritime museum will also rekindle an interest in our past involvement with the sea and our aquatic areas throughout the whole of Australia. As I said earlier, Australians have always associated themselves with the coast and its environs, perhaps without fully understanding or appreciating why. Now, with the establishment of this Maritime Museum, we will be able to witness the progression in importance of the sea and its relationship with the settlement of our island continent. I see it as a very fitting gift to the nation in our Bicentennial year, for we have more to be thankful for in the waters surrounding us than many Australians are aware. I look forward to the opening of another institution immortalising the growth and development of Australia as a sovereign nation in the world community of nations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the establishment of the Australian National Maritime Museum. It will be an adjunct to the National Library, the Australian National Gallery and the National Museum of Australia, which are all located in the Australian Capital Territory. This museum will be located in Sydney, as recommended in 1975 in the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections in Australia. The report quite specifically recommends that the museum be located in Sydney. It mentions that it might have as its central building the old Customs House at Circular Quay but points out that there are many problems in converting old buildings into museums. The costs are often prohibitive and the result is often unsatisfactory. Whole floors may have to be removed.

SPEECH.PARA: The claims of Sydney for locating it there, rather than in any other city, are quite clear. Sydney has an historic claim.
