It was the base of all maritime activity and trade in the early days of settlement. It is also a centre of sporting history associated with the harbour and the sea. Sydney has a number of museums devoted to maritime matters. There is the Sydney Maritime Museum, the Spectacle Island collection which was mentioned earlier, and a unique collection and maritime museum on Snapper Island which commemorates the sinking of the German cruiser the Emden by HMAS Sydney during the First World War, on 9 November 1914. The late Captain Len Forsythe, who lived in my electorate in Drummoyne, spent his whole life gathering artefacts and memorabilia relating to the sinking of the Emden by the Sydney. Each year on Snapper Island, a tiny little island off Drummoyne, a service is held to commemorate all who died in the battle off the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The Emden was actually beached at North Keeling Island. It would be of interest to anyone who is concerned about museums to go and see the collection on Snapper Island to see just what can be developed by diligent searching out, gathering and collecting. As I understand it, it is not on show on a regular basis; special arrangements have to be made because nobody lives on the island. Nearby is Spectacle Island and there is an enormous collection of naval historical items there. There are some of the sleds that were taken to the Antarctic for the first expedition and a great range of historical objects.

I went out to Spectacle Island when the late John Blunt was the curator, and I am sorry that I could not go there for the last open day. There is an annual open day on Spectacle Island and the public is admitted, but it means travelling to the island by barge or boat. The Pigott Committee has quite firmly recommended that any maritime museum that is established should be accessible by land and sea. That would rule out Spectacle Island as anything but an annex. I commend to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) the notion of creating an annex on Spectacle Island. During World War II the island had an enormous work force but now only a small number of people are employed there. It is quite possible that there could also be an annex in Hobart or some other city that has important items or infrastructure to contribute to a maritime museum.

Sydney has other claims for this great centre. The work done by the Wran Government on the preservation of historical items and the development of museums has been quite extraordinary. What has been done to the old Mint Building in Macquarie Street, Sydney, is really world class. It had been tragically neglected by the previous Askin-Willis Government. The forecourt was used as a carpark and the building was used for registries, court offices and the like. To the credit of the Wran Government, it recognised the important historical significance of the building and the educational role of museums for young people and for adult education. The New South Wales Government has developed the Hyde Park Barracks, which is the adjoining building, and restored it to its original state. It resisted the planners who wanted to put a lift in the building. It is quite an outstanding centre for tourists in Sydney.

We must remember that we are attracting one million tourists a year to Australia and most of them visit the big cities. The Powerhouse Museum is another development that is of great interest to me. The State Government is developing this on the fringe of Darling Harbour. The National Maritime Museum will also be in the Darling Harbour area. I was delighted to note on my last visit to the Power House Museum that it has an Australian six tourer motor car which was the only Australian-made motor car ever produced. About 1,000 of them were built between 1919 and 1923 at the Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia) Ltd site on Parramatta Road, Ashfield, which is in my electorate. I hope that the Minister will see that some monument, some plaque is erected there to commemorate this Australian-made motor vehicle. There is now what I assume to be one working model of it in the Power House Museum. In 1923 the American car manufacturers dropped their prices and destroyed the market for this motor car. Now the Government is moving to assist the American and Japanese car makers in this country to compete against the imported vehicles. I thank the old residents who assisted me in tracking down the location of this site where the motor vehicles were manufactured.

Today we are talking about the Maritime Museum and its importance as an educational centre. Those of us who have had the opportunity to travel have seen the development of museums in other countries, some of which may have bleak winters and wet summers. The Federal Republic of Germany has 2,000 museums that attracted 57 million visitors in 1984. I feel that in a big city like Sydney this great development at Darling Harbour, the National Maritime Museum, will attract an enormous number of visitors. The developments at Darling Harbour will be cheek by jowl. There is to be a $66m exhibition centre and a $55m convention centre. The convention centre will be seven storeys high and will seat 3,500 delegates. Sydney, the largest city in Australia, really has no convention centre that can stage an international convention. I congratulate and praise the Minister for Public Works and Ports, Mr Brereton, for his concept of this whole development at Darling Harbour. Until now it has been a derelict area of unused railway yards. The Sydney Entertainment Centre is also in this area and has been a great success. I point out to the Opposition that its counterparts in New South Wales have not opposed the redevelopment of Darling Harbour; in fact they have endorsed it. They may have criticised and said that this or that should be done. The development will be a tremendous shot in the arm for tourism in New South Wales and for the whole of Australia. There will be a spin-off to other centres besides Sydney.

Tourism produces jobs for young unskilled workers. Young people who have left school and who have no skills can obtain jobs in the tourist industry by waiting on tables, making beds, cleaning and all the things that young people without any training can do and are very much in demand to do.

I make these points because there has been criticism of the Darling Harbour proposal. There has been the rather hysterical talk by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) about people not being able to get into hospitals and children having to go to other States. I say to the honourable member for Bradfield that that is absolute rubbish. Recently I returned home from this House on a Friday night and I had to take my child into the children's hospital. She had severe asthma and was very sick. There was no problem at the hospital. Doctors were on duty waiting in the emergency section to treat children. This notion that children have to be sent interstate for treatment is untrue. I went as a guest to a meeting of the western suburbs medical association, being the member of parliament for the area. The president, who is a good friend of mine and whom I have known all his life, told me about the waiting list at the local hospital and said how extensive it was. When I got home the superintendent of the hospital had been ringing my home to tell me that the allegations were not true, that it was exaggerated, and that nobody had been turned away. Most of these statements and allegations are distorted. From time to time there can be a hiccup in any system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spend 24 hours there and make your own judgment.
— Order! I am sure the honourable member will return very quickly to the Bill, which might enable the honourable member for Bradfield to contain himself.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was simply answering some very silly criticisms of the Bill and of the whole Darling Harbour proposal. We are not here to debate the Darling Harbour proposal, but it is something that will grace this whole nation and be as big an attraction as the Opera House or Ayers Rock.
—It will be even bigger.

—As the honourable member says, it will be a bigger attraction. It will be added to by the development of the National Maritime Museum. There are several other points I want to make. I hope that in the National Maritime Museum there can be incorporated a national memorial to the Australian merchant marine seamen who died in the wars. Nowhere in our nation is there a memorial to the merchant marine seamen who died. In Melbourne there is a memorial to Victorians who served in the merchant marine. I was not aware of this until prior to Anzac Day, when I went to a service at Rookwood Cemetery to commemorate those who served in the merchant marine and who died. As honourable members know, those people become part of the armed forces in the event of war. Sydney would be a wonderful place for such a memorial as it is the major port from which people left by boat to go to war-to the war in South Africa, to the First World War and to the Second World War. Sydney was the major port in time of war and I hope that Sydney can be the centre for this memorial. I have written to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) asking that a memorial be established to the merchant marine, and I will certainly suggest that it be in the Australian Maritime Museum.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that in the Museum there can be recognition of the role that Sydney has played in both amateur and professional sport, and even in developing our rural industries. No members of the National Party of Australia are present to hear this, but in Sydney Harbour there is a tiny island in my electorate called Rodd Island. Louis Pasteur sent his son-in-law to that island to develop a cure for anthrax in sheep. Other research was carried out on this island. In those days, over 100 years ago, research could be carried out there in safety and in isolation in order to develop and protect Australia's rural industry. It was on that island in 1891 that Sarah Bernhardt spent her weekends when she was performing in Sydney because its inhabitants were the only French speaking group she could find. The dogs she brought with her, her small puppies, were kept there in quarantine. Rodd Island is just a few kilometres up the harbour from where the National Maritime Museum is being erected. The buildings constructed for Pasteur's assistants are still on the island. They were used as recreational pavilions until recent times. Fortunately, all this information came out when there was a move by an interested developer in 1980 to develop a restaurant on the island. I was fortunate in that at the time I was in the State Parliament and someone did research and found that Rodd Island is a public recreation reserve.

World championship sculling events have been held on Sydney Harbour, including the area in which the Maritime Museum is to be located and right up the Parramatta River. It is also the area in which the Sydney Rowing Club is located, it having been founded in 1870. The first President of the Club was George Thornton, who was born in Sydney in 1820 and went on to become the Mayor of Sydney and a member of the New South Wales Parliament. The Sydney Rowing Club is now located at Abbotsford, and a number of other historic rowing clubs are also located around Sydney Harbour. It was on Sydney Harbour that many of the earliest international events were held. these events must be commemorated in the Maritime Museum. Australian's first recorded sculling race was in 1818 on Sydney Harbour. John Piper rowed from Bradley's Head to Sydney Cove. The international events held on Sydney Harbour involved men such as Edward Trickett, Edward Hanlan, William Beach and, of course, H. E. Searle. There is a memorial to Searle in the Parramatta River. Having defeated a Canadian for the world championship, he died at the age of 23 upon his return to Australia. His memorial is just a few kilometres from where the National Maritime Museum is to be erected. There is also a memorial to Beach at Cabarita, marking his contribution to world rowing. These men were international scullers and they were the first Australians ever to win an international world sporting championship.

It is important to try to appreciate the support these people received and the enthusiasm they created in Australia at that time. Their following was essentially for rowing on the harbour. The harbour and the Parramatta River were the centre of all recreation and the focus of all attention, and the annual Australia Day rowing regatta was a great event in Sydney in the earliest times. In 1876, when Trickett returned to Australia, there was great excitement and he was presented with a purse of #850. He bought a hotel and in some of the older photos of Sydney one can see Trickett's Hotel in Hunter Street. I have met some members of the Trickett family, who are very involved in the Uniting Church in Sydney. They told me that their great grandfather developed a problem with drink, but then was converted and became a salvationist and forswore drink. But he was a world champion, and he won that championship on the Thames. I feel that an important part of the Museum must be dedicated to those Australians who brought back the first world championships to this nation-the rowers and scullers in the earliest days. Many of them went as amateurs and came back and turned professional. this is an opportunity to recognise what they did. Some of these races in the early days were on the Yarra or up at Grafton; they were not all in Sydney. Often the rowers came from the north coast, where the broad rivers are. This is a part of our history that must be commemorated, and I am sure it will be commemorated in the National Maritime Museum.

I have raised these matters today because the Museum will have a theatre and restaurants; it will be a centre that we will be delighted to visit during the Bicentennial celebrations. It will be an enormous educational centre, not only for the children coming from the government and non-government schools, but also for the adults. It is for adult education, after all, that money is spent on museums, on informing people of their country's history, particularly in a city such as Sydney, where in most electorates a quarter of the population was born overseas. These people have not had a whole lifetime of learning and familiarisation with the events and incidents of this country's past, nor do they have grandparents here to pass on information, ideas and stories. I think this a very important Bill; in fact, it is a very exciting move. The Museum will be a great adjunct to the whole Darling Harbour development and I congratulate the Government for agreeing with the Pigott recommendation that this important National Maritime Museum be built in Sydney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 2 of the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill defines what is meant by `Australian marine environment'. The definition used is perhaps as wide as anyone could imagine. It includes the seven oceans and seas which touch our shores: The Tasman Sea, the Coral Sea-apparently the Pacific Ocean does not touch us-the Indian Ocean, the Arafura Sea, the Timor Sea, Torres Strait and Bass Strait. Apparently the Southern Ocean is technically part of the Indian Ocean. It also includes lakes and rivers, the internal waters of Australia and the seabed of the continental shelf. Even the definition of `Australian marine history' is very broad. It includes geological and biological information, as well as the interaction of human beings and the history of sea travel for every purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: This museum is to be established at Sydney-the first national museum outside the Australian Capital Territory. It would have been nice to see it established at Queanbeyan, which is officially a port. Certainly I can appreciate the argument for having the Maritime Museum there in Sydney. The Bill provides for the Museum to supply liquor. I hope that one will be able to splice the mainbrace with a hot toddy of rum when one visits the Museum. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), in his second reading speech, said that probably no other country has relied more on the sea and acknowledged its debt to the sea less. This has happened on the south coast of New South Wales, in the Eden-Monaro electorate. As an example, like most seaside locations, the Bega Valley region was first visited by Europeans when George Bass entered the mouth of the Bega River during his whaleboat journey to chart the coastline. He remained there for three days.

For many years the major means of transportation to and from the south coast was the Illawarra Steam Navigation Company's boats. The Tathra, Merimbula, Bermagui and Eden districts all benefited from those visits. It is worth mentioning that, were it not for our early coastal shipping, the south coast dairy industry which we have today and south coast life in general would have been quite different. The region would never have progressed as far as it has. One might ask: Where are the marine relics, artefacts et cetera from this period? There are quite a few in the district. I receive regular reports from the whale museum at Eden, which has accumulated a wide range of interesting relics and artefacts. Vic Heffernan runs the Candelo museum-he actually spells it `mooseum' to indicate the area's long association with the dairy industry, although he also has a lot of marine relics and artefacts. The museum has many marine relics and artefacts. One could spend days not just hours, as many tourists do-sometimes only an hour or so-in the `Mooseum'.

Great contributions have been made by people along the coast to the history of the area. I mention Veronica Searle of Milton and Susan Hopgood of Batemans Bay. The Moruya Historical Society, of which I am a member, has made quite a feature in its museum of the Japanese maps and plans for the area drawn up when we were at war with Japan. Quite a lot of interesting memorabilia is on display at the museum. The work of Daisy and Ray Bearlin at Tathra has brought about the preservation and continuation of one of the few remaining timber wharves built by the Illawarra and South Coast Steam Ship Navigation Co.

TALK.START.PARA: —A wonderful thing.

—It is, as the honourable member says, a wonderful thing. It is interesting to see in the House Mr Sergio Sergi, who did some wonderful work along with the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) for the preservation of the Tathra wharf. Another item of great interest in recent days has been the celebrations at Eden concerning the Ly-ee-moon. On the evening of 30 May 1886, 100 years ago, the Ly-ee-moon. was wrecked in very heavy seas on reefs and shoals at Green Cape. A committee of the Parliament made an interesting visit with me to the Green Cape wreck area.
—Not just to see the Ly-ee-moon?

—Not just to see the Ly-ee-moon, but to have a look at the Green Cape lighthouse too. I am glad that the honourable member's interjection has reminded me that subsequent to the committee's visit the Government decided to retain the light station as a manually operated one. I thank the honourable member.
—Due to your representations.

—Certainly I was heavily involved in representations on that matter. I pay tribute to the committee for being willing to listen and make a report recommending the continuance of the light station, which will be a very important tourist attraction in the area. I believe that the higher cost of maintaining the light station at Green Cape as a manual station will be more than paid for by tourist interest and certainly more than paid for by the important historical events that will be commemorated and followed up as people visit the area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ly-ee-moon was built as a paddle steamer in 1859 in Britain especially for the China coast trade. When completed she amazed everyone by reaching 17 knots during a trial down the Thames estuary. She was described as the fastest vessel then afloat. She had a female figurehead with one arm outstretched and one behind her. She was a blockade runner during the American Civil War. On 29 May 1886 she left Melbourne with 45 passengers and 41 crew bound for Sydney. On 30 May 1886, 71 lives were lost. Five passengers and 10 crew were saved and 24 were buried at Green Cape. It is interesting to read of a number of people who were involved in those days such as George Imlay and Ben Boyd. The early south coast built boats, such as the Thetis, built in 1847, the Moruya and the Carnation, built in 1851, and the Clyde and the Shoalhaven, were all important boats, as were the shipbuilding sites of the same names until the 1880s. In fact, the Shoalhaven was named by George Bass. Coolangatta, in the Milton-Ulladulla area, was named after a small vessel which was owned by Alex Berry and which was wrecked in 1846. The Shoalhaven district was also named by George Bass.

I would not like to finish without mentioning the fact that Australia has some Aboriginal marine history. After all, our National Maritime Museum is about the interaction of humans and the sea environment. I hope that we will have some Aboriginal marine history in the Museum. I am told by departmental representatives that Aboriginal marine history will be included in the Museum. No archeological evidence of Pleistocene watercraft has been found, nor is it likely to be found in Australia because perishable artefacts are most unlikely to survive. The Tasmanian Aboriginals used simple driftwood logs for crossing rivers or bundles of paperbark of stringy-bark which were lashed together. Rarely were these craft taken more than a few kilometres off the coast because the bark became waterlogged after a few hours. Early northern area migration is thought to have occurred by riding the tide. Bamboo, a water impervious timber, was plentiful at least as far south as Java. But once in Australia, there was no suitable timber for any return voyage. Stone fish traps on inland rivers and tidal creeks probably would be worth displaying in the Museum. Bark canoes were used for fishing. Ann Gash, the solo round the world sailor, talking about keeping her Stella Ilimo in Sydney with the hope that she can take it to her home for the memories she wants to have from her sailing days is something I believe we can all associate with, Australians old and new, when we visit a maritime museum. We can all associate with the words she expressed then:

At the moment I keep Stella Ilimo in Sydney because there's nowhere to keep her up near the commune. This means I have to travel up and down to keep an eye on her. I'm trying to work out a way of keeping her up near me. Making all this happen, building my house, I find just as much of an adventure as sailing around the world by myself.
I believe that is the real value of a museum. A maritime museum will be a reminder of something we all too often forget. For many people, it will be an adventure as good as sailing around the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that a project of this nature, the Australian Maritime Museum, should have been the subject of the sort of speech we heard from the Opposition spokesman on Arts, Heritage and Environment, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). Australia is a nation which in two years time will celebrate 200 years of European settlement. It owes that 200 years to its connection with the sea. It is a maritime nation. To hear a speech which, as is unfortunately the wont of the honourable member for Bradley--
—Bradfield.

—My apologies to Harry Turner. The honourable member's speech was filled with snide remarks, unsubstantiated allegations of corruption and money wasting and the usual claim-if one has no argument-that the money could have been better spent somewhere else. That is always the case. There has never been a case that, when a national monument, an important social or civic project, has been put forward, one could not have found more urgent projects on which the money could have been spent. The argument was used when Lake Burley Griffin was built. It was used when Canberra was chosen as the site for the national capital. It was used against the National Gallery of Australia, and the High Court of Australia-the last of which was not exactly a monument to the efficiency of the Opposition's ability to construct and manage a public work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National Maritime Museum Bill 1986, quite appropriately, brings about the establishment, 200 years on, of a museum which will collect for the nation and display the important elements of Australia's maritime history-a history of which we all ought to be proud, or at least acknowledge, as some parts of it are not our proudest moments. The Opposition's amendment is full of half truths, innuendoes and simple incorrect statements, as indeed was the speech of the honourable gentleman. To give an example of the type of thing he put before this House, he mentioned a video, to which he attributed a cost of $100,000. If he looked at the public record, he would find out the cost was $28,000. That is only a slight error of 300 per cent! It is typical of the negative and not very honest approach the Opposition takes in this Parliament.

I will deal with some of the matters in the amendment-briefly, because I think brevity is all they really deserve. First, the allegation that the Public Works Committee was bypassed as part of a `cover-up', to use the honourable gentleman's term, is nonsense. That Committee was bypassed with its full and unanimous agreement-including the agreement of members of his Party. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has given a clear undertaking that the Committee will be consulted and kept informed about the project. In fact, it has carried out site inspections on two occasions.

It was alleged that the Commonwealth has gone back on its stance on the Builders Labourers Federation. God knows, the people opposite ought to talk about their record with the BLF. The Opposition talked about it in this Parliament and did nothing for four years while the problem developed. The Opposition is only good at telling people what to do when it knows it will not have to deal with the problem itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get your facts straight. We were in the process of having it deregistered.

—Opposition members were going to go on for another five years with the same process because it enabled them to escape their responsibilities and to escape taking tough action, because they have no guts when the chips are down. The Opposition never does anything hard; it only talks about it. If the honourable member were in the Army, he would have to be a gunner, because he is always `gunna' do something but never actually does it.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that the parliamentary Public Works Committee was fully consulted about the museum because it was considered that this important national project should be finished in time to form part of the Bicentenary. It was necessary to take a fast track in order that the project be completed in time. The honourable gentleman said we bypassed our activities on the BLF. The Government took a hard line, actually deregistering the BLF, rather than talking about it like the Opposition, and it reached agreement with the New South Wales Government. Entrenched in that agreement was a code of conduct which is being rigidly enforced by this Government. The honourable gentleman knows that.

The honourable member said that we should have used Spectacle Island. That is a bomb dump-a great place for a museum and a tourist attraction! He said that some time in the next 20 years-this is not a fait accompli-the museum there will be moved out of Sydney Harbour. This is not practical. Access is not available by land and it is not a suitable site for the construction of this museum. It is an important part of our maritime and naval history.

The honourable gentleman talked about cost overruns. If he took the trouble to look at the information available, he would have found that the Commonwealth has undertaken to provide $30m at end of project prices-1988 prices- for the construction of the Maritime Museum and that the New South Wales Government is responsible for any overruns on that contract.

The honourable gentleman raised a number of other matters. He said that no commercial study was undertaken. That is not true. A commercial study was undertaken. The only study which is outstanding is a study on the type and commercial viability of a restaurant project in the Maritime Museum. He said we did not examine the Sydney Maritime Museum. Extensive negotiations took place, but agreement was not reached because the Sydney Maritime Museum, which is a private collection, wishes to stay that way. It does not wish to be engulfed by the National Maritime Museum. The James Craig is a private project for which some $2m has been provided by the New South Wales Government. It also is a project which will continue as a private project.

The honourable member mentioned a number of alternative sites in addition to Spectacle Island, such as the old Customs House. The cost of alterations and the unsuitable nature of that site for the type of maritime museum envisaged make it impractical and probably more costly than the project which is before us now.

I could go on through every one of the matters raised by the honourable gentleman in his efforts to undermine and downgrade what ought to be a matter of national pride in our achievements and in our past. This Parliament is not well served by an Opposition which sees its only role as whining, accusing and misleading. I commend the Bill to the House and I reject the amendment.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Connolly's amendment) stand part of the question.
