DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND GRANT (JERVIS BAY TERRITORY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Mr Holding;
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the information of the House I indicate that amendments to this legislation have been circulated. I should be gracious enough to indicate that they pick up one of the recommendations that came from members of Her Majesty's Opposition in a briefing session when they legitimately made a point about parliamentary review over further land grants. The Government is happy to take up that suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Bill, which we are debating this afternoon, is of some significance. It represents the decision of the Government to grant a freehold title to probably the last remaining Aboriginal community on the mainland of Australia which to date has not received any form of title or which is not in a State where negotiations are currently being conducted to that end. However, it is a matter of some concern to the Opposition that we are unable to support the Bill in its present form because the proposal is to give a freehold title in the Australian Capital Territory where, to the best of my knowledge, no freehold title has ever been granted since the passage of the appropriate legislation in 1915. For this reason I propose to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for the land described in the Schedule to be granted as a lease in perpetuity to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council'.

I am well aware of the fact that the Minister has entered into negotiations which obviously have reached fruition from his point of view and he is probably unwilling to make this necessary change. That is the reason why we are not supporting the Bill. As the Minister is well aware, negotiations leading to the settlement which has now been reached had a gestation period of at least the last decade. In fact, the Aboriginal community which has been established at Wreck Bay is the remnants of tribes from as far afield as the Monaro and the central south coast of New South Wales. They were brought to a range of small settlements along the coast at various times during the late nineteenth century. One of those communities was established at Wreck Bay well before World War I. The Commonwealth acquired the area as part of a 72-kilometre acquisition under the Jervis Bay Territory Acceptance Act 1908, which was an arrangement entered into with the New South Wales Government, when it was planned at that stage to provide the national capital, Canberra, with a port of its own.

The New South Wales Board for the Protection of Aborigines assumed responsibility for the Aborigines in the Jervis Bay territory and provided housing, schooling and various welfare services. Wreck Bay was treated informally as an Aboriginal reserve or station and its boundaries were not delimited at that time. In 1954 a small area was gazetted, omitting much of the customary land within the boundaries of the reserve. Considerable controversy arose throughout the 1970s over the status and the size of the land claim. The situation was further exacerbated when the old reserve, except for the immediate residential land, was included in the Jervis Bay nature reserve which was proclaimed in 1971.

The Wreck Bay Aboriginal housing company was formed in 1973-74, and in the next year a residential lease was offered by the Government to the community. The housing company assumed that this would cover the entire reserve area. It was, however, an area equivalent only to the gazetted reserve. The boundary of the lease offer was extended to include the Summer Cloud Beach area, which had been developed as a picnic area, boat ramp and public access for people living in the Jervis Bay area and for tourists. In 1980, the then Minister for the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Ellicott, proposed to grant a perpetual lease over the whole area claimed; that included the nature reserve, and also Summer Cloud Bay and Mary Bay, and all sacred traditional sites in the Jervis Bay district. The community rejected the offer and called for a freehold title and fishing rights. Such title, however, did not exist under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act, nor was it the basis for negotiations with the New South Wales Government in 1910.

The Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Bill 1986 which we are currently debating proposes a series of amendments in order to grant a freehold title at Wreck Bay. It has changed the basis of the existing Seat of Government (Administration) Act to make that possible. The Aboriginal community of Jervis Bay comprises 160 people and controls some 21 buildings and, as I have said, has within the area subject to transfer a boat ramp, car park and road access.

The provisions in the legislation seek to grant an inalienable freehold title to 403 hectares of the Jervis Bay territory to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community. Under the Bill there is a provision to establish a community council, to be known as the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Council, which will hold title to the land granted under the Bill. It also provides for an initial grant of land to the community council and allows for future grants of land adjoining the initial grant. I am pleased that the Minister in his opening remarks has accepted the proposed amendment which I discussed with his officers earlier this week. As the Act currently stands, all that was required was for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory to agree to the extension of the original grant-that is, an extension beyond the 403 hectares-and that would automatically come into effect.

For obvious reasons since this is an Act of Parliament, which specifies the land which is to be allocated to the Aboriginal community through the Parliament, it is obviously necessary that the Parliament be the means by which any changes to that title should be conducted. The Minister has proposed in his amendment, which we accept, that the normal 15-day provision will be in place for the disallowance of regulations under the Act.

In addition, the Bill also provides for buildings and amenities on the land granted to become the property of the community council, unless the Commonwealth continues its use of those buildings or amenities. It furthermore establishes an office or registrar of the community council who will be responsible for preparing the original register of members and attempt to resolve disputes between the community council and its members. There will be power for the community council to lease land for a number of purposes, some of which require the consent of the Minister, such as, for example, the development of tourist facilities in the area.

There is also a provision that mining on land granted will take place only with the agreement of the Commonwealth, the community council and the intending miner. In the lead-up to the debate, I learnt, that apparently in the ACT there is now a virtual moratorium on all mining. It is significant to point out that part of the extended area which has been provided to the Wreck Bay community under this legislation contains some old clay pits, which may well in the future be the source of income for the community. I think that the Government should seriously consider the implications of the existing no-mining ordinance in the ACT to see whether perhaps an exception could be made in relation to the Wreck Bay community. It is essential, and is, as I understand it, the basis of current government policy which in this respect is supported by the Opposition, that Aboriginal communities should be given whatever opportunities are available to reach economic self-sufficiency. Opportunities such as this, therefore, should not be ignored.

The final element in the legislation which is worth noting is that it protects significant sites to which the public already has access. This has been the subject of some worry to the Opposition and to various fishermen and people who live in the region who are concerned that, despite the provisions contained in the Act, their access to the road, to the boat ramp and to the beaches may be blocked by some capricious decision of the Aboriginal community council in the future. I ask the Minister in his response at the end of the debate to give a categorical assurance that this issue will be thoroughly settled with the Aboriginal council prior to the transfer of title, so that those other people, who are not members of the community but who nevertheless have retained over many years a community interest in access to the beaches and so on for fishing and for general recreational activities, can be assured that their rights will be fully protected.

It is also worth noting that, unlike similar legislation relating to other parts of Australia, there is no provision here for sacred sites. While there are known to be two bora grounds within the area, the reason for this is possibly to be found in the fact that the community that lives there may not contain members who retain any long term traditional association with that particular piece of land. Therefore, the context of sacred sites as distinct from sites of significance under earlier legislation passed by the Government is possibly the reason why this is not contained in the Bill. Again, the Minister may care to comment.

The Minister has also observed in the legislation that the transfer of assets, will not involve large financial costs to the Commonwealth, and the administration of the land grant and so forth will again be subject to normal negotiations between the Department of Territories, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and, of course, the Wreck Bay community.

The negotiations for the granting of freehold title to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community have taken over a decade. While on the one hand we are pleased to see that negotiations have reached some finality, we are particularly concerned about the actual substance of the title that is being proposed. The subject of land grants, as the Minister is well aware, is sensitive. It is an issue that goes far beyond the question of whether this Parliament, which obviously has a responsibility to look after the interests of the 160 people concerned at Wreck Bay, would want to go down a path once again of creating in the minds of the wider Australian community the belief that a precedent has been set in the ACT which is not available to any other resident of this Territory. I strongly urge the Minister even at this late hour to consider seriously the impact that this can have on the non-Aboriginal communities, not just in the ACT but elsewhere.

It is also worth pointing out that while, on the one hand, he has given up his earlier policy of national land rights legislation which did contain provision for the granting of a freehold title to Aboriginal communities, on the other hand, he has accepted a package in his negotiations with the Western Australian Government which is largely based on the experience of the Queensland Government in relation to the form of title it has given, which is a leasehold in perpetuity, that is now accepted as the basis for land tenure for Aboriginal communities on tribal or community land, much of which was previously Aboriginal reservations around Australia.

The Minister may well respond that, when the Northern Territory Aboriginal land rights legislation was passed through this place by the Fraser Government, the form of title given was different from the title currently held by most people in the NT, particularly graziers and so forth. That is an historical fact; I do not dispute it.

However, I would have to say that community attitudes have obviously changed since 1976. The Minister knows only too well, as the public opinion surveys conducted by the National Opinion Polls and other organisations at the behest of his Department show, that a significant proportion of Australians, in some cases as high as 80 per cent, do not believe that Aboriginal communities should have access to land on a basis different from that available to the wider Australian community. This is a fact of public perception. I do not wish, in this context, to make a major issue of why that happens to be the public perception, but I have said in this House on previous occasions that the Government and the Minister have a joint responsibility.

I fear that to this day there has been no evidence of a desire by the Government to try to explain to the Australian community the substance of its land rights policy, even the arrangements it has now entered into with the various States. I am concerned, as is the Opposition, that while there remains in Australia a significant proportion of people who believe, for one reason or another, that Aborigines are not Australia's most deprived citizens, as generally speaking they have been, but are to be seen as a community that has more rights, more access to public funds, and more advantages than the rest of the Australian community, God knows, we are facing a major problem of how best to encourage the ultimate linkage which must take place between the Australian Aboriginal community and the mainstream of Australian people. I do not believe that anyone in this Parliament would seriously propose that we should endorse indefinitely-either officially or unofficially-a policy directed at making Aboriginals seem to be apart.

A conflict has been created in recent years; there is an element of the Aboriginal community which believes that self-determination means to be apart. However, the reality of living in the last decade of the twentieth century surely means that unless we are able to create a truly united Australian community, which is based on the belief that it has a profound responsibility to help those in need and to give every Australian citizen, including every Aboriginal Australian citizen, the right of equality of opportunity-and unless we can get a wide-based community acceptance that equality of opportunity must be the clear objective of all our policies to encourage Aboriginal advancement, I feel that we have collectively failed. The people who will suffer most from the Government's failure will be the 160,000-odd Aboriginal Australians whom it has encouraged as being a community set apart. For that reason, every step that a government takes along the road of giving Aboriginals that final objective of equality of opportunity must always be predicated by the clearest understanding that whatever one does runs a risk of being misunderstood and misinterpreted.

What the Government has done in this particular Bill stands out like a beacon on a hill-to everybody in the Australian Capital Territory at least, if not to many hundreds of thousands of Australians elsewhere-as yet another example of how the Government has set apart a small community and is offering them a unique freehold title to their land which is, in every respect, different from what is available to the remaining population, both in Jervis Bay and in the Australian Capital Territory as a whole. I warn the Minister that it is his responsibility to get out there and explain to the rest of the people in Canberra, and elsewhere, how he can justify a situation in which there are two types of titles, one for 160 people, and a different leasehold title, on a 99-year lease basis, for everyone else. It may be that the Government ought to give away the 99-year lease altogether and give everybody in the Australian Capital Territory a free- hold title; that is an option-the Government must make these decisions. If it went down that road and were then able to say to the Aboriginal community in Wreck Bay `We are giving you a title that is just as solid and just as legally sound as the rest of the titles in the Australian Capital Territory', I would not have to stand here and move this amendment. Unfortunately, that is not the situation. The Government has chosen, of its own volition, to go on a different road.

As I understand it, when Mr Ellicott conducted his negotiations there was concern in the Aboriginal community about a title which was based on the word `lease' or had a concept such as 99 years. Anything less than the term `freehold' was seen by them to be, somehow, a limitation on their right to hold that land in perpetuity. I understand that. I understand the psychological reasons why they would feel that way. I also believe that it is the Government's responsibility to try to reach an understanding by which those people would have a better appreciation of the land tenure system as it is in the Australian Capital Territory, and for better or worse Wreck Bay is part of the Australian Capital Territory, and also to explain to the community that the title which could have been offered-namely, a title that gave them rights in perpetuity and was based on a similar Australian Capital Territory title-was in fact the most viable basis for negotiation and agreement. However, that is not the case and, unfortunately, we may well have to live with the impact of that. The Aboriginal population of the Australian Capital Territory is, by Australian standards, very small. It largely comprises people who have settled in Canberra because of their employment. I understand that there are now about 4,000 people resident in Canberra who fit that description. The Jervis Bay territory was acquired to ensure that the seat of government had access to the sea. Consequently we have the Wreck Bay community as residents of the Australian Capital Territory.

The Liberal Party's current platform recognises that Aborigines should have the same opportunity as other Australians have to determine their own lifestyles, to retain and develop their own traditions, language and culture if desired; that they should be encouraged to live as independent and self-sustaining citizens; that, as do other citizens, they should have access to community-wide programs, welfare services and all the benefits of being Australians; and that the preservation of the integrity of Aboriginal culture, religion and history should be assured, as well as the encouragement of appreciation of Aboriginal heritage among other Australians. To that effect, we introduced a number of principles. They were: To seek to protect Aboriginal sites of significance in the Australian Capital Territory; to ensure maintenance in the Jervis Bay territory of secure title to land presently occupied by the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community; to recognise the aspirations of the Aboriginal community to have additional areas of the Jervis Bay Nature Reserve, being part of a former Aboriginal reserve, placed under Aboriginal control; and to seek to meet that desire only after consultation with the Aboriginal community as well as with the wider Australian community, utilising the nature reserve in such a way as to provide for continued public access to beaches and recreational areas.

That was the policy that we put to the Australian Capital Territory people at the last election. It is for that reason that I believe the gulf between the Government and the Opposition in terms of the substance of this Bill is essentially limited to the form of the title of transfer, and that is all. We do not disagree with the rights of the Wreck Bay community to have a title to their land; nor do we disagree in any sense that they should have a secure title to their land.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have permission to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.46 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. What additional surveillance or controls over prices will the Treasurer be recommending in his discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions tomorrow?
—The honourable member will be asking me next what I had for lunch. The honourable member will find out tomorrow.

—I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction: What is the attitude of the housing industry to the first home owners scheme and tied grants for public housing? What has been the effect of the first home owners assistance scheme at a regional level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe it is true to say that the industry organisations, including those representing employers, unions and small business, are all in support of the first home owners scheme and the tied grants to the States which, of course, are made under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. This morning I had some discussions with the National Executive of the Master Builders Federation of Australia Inc. It did not surprise me that it offered me and the Government its full support for the first home owners scheme and for the continuance of tied grants under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: I must point out-I am even duty bound to point out; it is incumbent upon me to point out-that the Opposition policy makes it perfectly clear that the Opposition would abolish both the first home owners scheme and tied grants to States for public housing. For instance, its policy says that it will incorporate the funds from the first home owners scheme into general housing grants to the States. The Opposition then says `Therefore this does not mean that the scheme will be abolished'; but it goes on to say that it will abolish tied grants. Thus the Opposition would give away any control that it would have, if it retained tied grants to the States, to tell the States to direct the money into such a scheme as the first home owners scheme. Let us be very clear about it. The Opposition policy is to abolish both the first home owners scheme and the tied grants to the States.

Madam Speaker, let me tell you what the Opposition would abolish. The first home owners scheme directs up to $3,000 as a lump sum towards those who cannot meet the deposit from their own resources for their own home. It also directs an interest subsidy of up to $167 per month to low income borrowers to help them meet their repayments. We are still approving up to 1,000 applications per month under this scheme. I want to let honourable members know the extent of the damage that the Opposition would do. We have already approved over $900m and paid out $650m under this scheme. I have just circulated to all members of this House the aggregate of the pay-outs and approvals under this scheme. Some electorates of members in this House have already received an aggregate of $16m. On a State by State basis, first home buyers in New South Wales have received $106m; in Victoria, $168m; and in Queensland, $124m. I would like to table a list of the aggregate pay-outs and approvals for every electorate represented in this House.

I believe that the Opposition plan to abolish the first home owners scheme is a perfect example of the contradiction and division which exists amongst the ranks of the Opposition front bench. On the one hand, the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the honourable member for Deakin, is saying that he will abolish the first home owners scheme. This will be highly damaging to small business and to the housing industry. On the other hand, the honourable member for O'Connor, who I believe is supposed to be responsible for small business matters, is saying in his policy that the Opposition will assist small business by removing measures which may discriminate against small business opportunity. Of all the things I could think of in the housing industry at a regional level there would be nothing more damaging to small business in the housing industry than the abolition of the first home owners scheme. It would have a very damaging effect on building contractors, building sub-contractors, material suppliers, timber yards, brick yards, tile suppliers and the fit-out and furnishing trade across the nation at a regional level. We have the situation in which one shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin, sets out to do as much damage as one could possibly think of to small business in the housing industry and another shadow Minister, the honourable member for O'Connor, says that the Opposition will set out to assist small business in the housing industry.

Under the record $1.8 billion that this Federal Labor Government and the States will direct to public housing, $137m will go in tied grants to construct houses for Aboriginals and pensioners and to assist the pay-out under the mortgage and rental relief scheme that the Liberal- National Party Government set up. A Liberal- National Party Government would abolish that scheme. Tied grants have assisted, under the CSHA, along with the general grants, in lifting the number of new housing constructions due to Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funding from 10,000-odd in 1982-83 under a Liberal-National Party government to 17,500 under us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I again refer to the points of order raised successfully by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services in an earlier government. The honourable gentleman who is now answering this question has gone way beyond the bounds of matters normally responded to in questions without notice. I suggest that if he wishes to make a statement every opportunity will be given to him by the Opposition to facilitate it.

—I suggest to the Leader of the National Party, as I have before, that the Chair has no authority to limit the length of time a Minister takes to answer a question. The House has recourse to the Procedure Committee if it so desires.

—I was saying that under our record funding levels in public housing-this includes tied grants-the number of new housing commencements due to Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funding has gone up from 10,000 to 17,500 in three years. So it is perfectly obvious that the Australian Labor Party's first home owners scheme and tied grants have had a very positive effect on the industry. It is beyond doubt that industry organisations have given their absolute support to these measures.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. In view of the Treasurer's failure to answer my question earlier and in view of the fact that the Prime Minister has taken over control of economic policy from the Treasurer, I seriously ask: What additional surveillance or controls over prices will he be raising in his discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions tomorrow?

—Equally as seriously as my friend and colleague the Treasurer, let me say that what we say to the business community today and to the ACTU tomorrow we will, as a matter of courtesy and propriety, be first conveying to them rather than wasting our time on an Opposition which has branded itself as the worst in living memory.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. It relates to the tabling yesterday of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities. Has the Minister seen the numerous favourable reports about the Dibb Review in this morning's national Press? Is it true to suggest that the proposed strategy of the report will turn our friends into our enemies? How does the Minister see the so-called Soviet threat that is being pushed by the right honourable member for New England and the honourable member for Kooyong? Is this threat real or is it as fanciful as the good and very funny film entitled The Russians are Coming, the Russians are Coming?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. No, I have not seen all the favourable reports in the Press concerning the tabling yesterday of the report. What was particularly gratifying about those reports was the seriousness with which the Press treated the detail of the Dibb Review. It will always be the misfortune of any consultant to any government, whether of those on this side of the House or, in the very long distant future, if ever, those on the other side of the House, that that professional person will naturally and automatically-and there is no way to complain-be dragged into the argy-bargy of daily debate. What was also gratifying was the consistency and affordability of the recommendations.

ANSWER.PARA: As to other comments from the Opposition during the debate, I am aware of them, but naturally I am disappointed by them. To pick up the first comment, `turning friends into enemies', that is entirely gratuitous. It ought to have been made quite clear both by the remarks I made in this House and by the content of the Dibb Review that we value very highly the fact that we have good relationships in our area and that we see that as an important strategic asset. The contingencies that we operate under are related to what might be called the common-sense approach to the types of situations that we might find. They are not related to what we see as specific developments in the policies of countries in our area.

To start to characterise a common-sense approach to our defence and build up our capabilities in the north as being in some way a threat to somebody else debauches the debate. It is demeaning in that it suggests that we do not have an absolute sovereign right to dispose of our forces around our territories as we see fit. That is a right which all our neighbours take and about which we do not complain. That is a right which we would assume for ourselves. I do not think that any of our neighbours would expect less of us than that we should do so.

Regarding the Soviet Union and what is alleged to be a substantial building military threat which we ought to address, all I can say in military as opposed to political terms is that, if what Peter Young has to say about forthcoming Opposition strategy is correct, we would have forward defence on a self-reliant basis. In other words, we would not be forward with allies but by ourselves so that we would refight the Vietnam war not in association with allies but by ourselves next time. The expense of implementing such a suggestion is quite unbelievable.

We regard the Soviet position in Cam Ranh Bay as a matter of concern. With the United States of America we have developed policies for the south-west Pacific area and South East Asia. It is a political problem which some countries in the region find unnerving and a problem which we take seriously. We take it seriously enough to have Orions deployed through Malaysia and elsewhere which conduct surveillance including, among other things, surveillance of Soviet activity in the area. We regard it seriously enough, as witnessed recently, to deploy our FFG and DDG warships to the area to conduct surveillance. Honourable gentlemen and ladies will recollect that we did that during the deployment recently of a Soviet cruiser through the area.

What is really disappointing about the Opposition's position in this whole debate is its walking away from the essentially common-sense position that it adopted when in government but unfortunately failed to match with force structure proposals. I conclude by pointing out several aspects of a speech which I could take as my own text from the Leader of the National Party when he was Defence Minister. He pointed out something which I pointed out yesterday. He said:
Three threat situations are identifiable-
I should say that these were the only threat situations which he found to be identifiable:
Operations by small raiding parties against important national installations, challenges to the sovereignty of our offshore maritime resources, and harassment of our coastal shipping.
He went on:
Our first priority is to ensure that we possess the capability to respond effectively to these types of threats.

I agree with the right honourable member entirely in that regard. That is what I was saying. When we go to addressing other priorities such as out of area deployments, we draw down from the activities we undertake, the force structure we develop, to deal with our first priorities. Hence the statements that I have been making about how the FFGs would be used. In terms of our co-operation, he also said--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that those opposite do not like this but I think that their defence spokesman and former Defence Minister deserves a decent run in this House. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Rational thinking dictates there would need to be a serious deterioration in our security outlook before we could justify the maintenance of all operational capabilities necessary to defend Australia against major attack.
He went on about the global role:

The Australian Defence Force could have a role in a global conflict but this would be concentrated in the waters and air space of our immediate region, acting both in our national defence and supplementing the efforts of our allies.

It is a tragedy for rational defence planning that the Opposition walks away from the guidance which it accepted for a long time and the positions which it was beginning to adopt when in government. It moves away from that instead of supporting us in at last producing an affordable self-reliant defence strategy that is not in conflict with out allies but is consistent with the absolute obligation on this country and this Government to provide for its own defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence: What are the strategic and military assessments behind the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities that were strongly questioned by the Chief of the Defence Force, Sir Phillip Bennett?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —No strategic and military assessments are strongly questioned.
—Then the Age is wrong?

—Yes, the Age has miscued substantially regarding the comments it made in picking up the statements of the Chief of the Defence Force. The Chief of the Defence Force said that he supports the broad thrust of the Dibb report. Naturally, each of the chiefs retains, as we would expect, the right to disagree with elements at the margin. That came out in the breakfast interview yesterday. For example, Paul Dibb suggested-in a public session, so I am cheerful to deal with it here-that there ought to be a battalion of infantry sent to the Darwin-Tindal area. The Chief of the General Staff disagreed. He said no, not a battalion of infantry; he regarded it as more significant to send a reconnaissance regiment to that area. Paul Dibb suggested that two squadrons of tanks ought to go to the reserves. The CGS disagreed. He said that one squadron of tanks ought to go to the reserve.
—Sir Phillip Bennett?

—General Sir Phillip Bennett said on repeated occasions that he agreed with the broad thrust of the report. When somebody said to Sir Phillip Bennett: `Is this not a report that diminishes our defence capability?', he said: `On the contrary, this report, if implemented, would significantly upgrade readiness'. Naturally, there will be points of disagreement with elements of the Dibb report. One would have to be particularly dumb if one assumed that a man and his team, in the area of defence debate, which happens to be the last repository of old fashioned theology in this society, could come up with a report that secured 100 per cent commitment by absolutely every participant. I reckon it is a pretty considerable tribute to Dibb that he has been able to get the Secretary to the Department, the Chief of the Defence Force and the three Service chiefs to say that they agree with the broad thrust but their disagreement is at the margins.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Sinclair interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—When it comes down to the issue of strategic assessments on which it is based, the report that has been brought forward by Paul Dibb, in accordance with his instructions, is based on the strategic guidance and strategic basis in 1983.
—Sir Phillip Bennett disagrees.
—Order! I warn the Leader of the National Party.

—As the right honourable member will be aware from his own experience, the strategic basis document is a document that ultimately is agreed upon by all sections of the Department of Defence and therefore is the guidance on which any such force structure study has to be based. That strategic guidance, which is not dissimilar from the strategic guidance that was being received by successive Liberal-National Party governments, is common ground. There is no disagreement between the Chief of the Defence Force and anyone else on the validity of that strategic guidance.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is he aware of Opposition claims that bring into question the Government's determination to fight organised crime? In view of the enormity of organised crime in Australia, due largely to the inactivity of the former Government and resulting in an enormous drain on the nation's resources, does he agree that the problem will not be reduced unless and until we have a national frontal attack on the crime syndicates, their money and the launderers of the money, coupled with legislation that requires financial institutions, tax authorities and the accounting and legal professions to join in the attack? When will the Government put in place a multifaceted approach, including the long overdue reform and update of legislation, a restructure of the judiciary, a constructive approach to penalties and, above all, as a matter of priority, a national criminal code?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Opposition has been critical of the Government, stating that we have not taken sufficient action to combat organised crime. Let me say at the outset that, if we look at the record of the previous Government, we find basically that that was when major crime syndicates commenced to flourish.
—Nonsense.

—I notice that the Leader of the Opposition is interjecting, but perhaps he does that out of some nervous reaction to the bottom-of-the-harbour criminal activities which not only affected Australia but also had international links through other agencies. Let us make it clear that there was massive white collar crime in relation to collecting taxation revenue that was due. Whereas in the past in this country there was brutal and physical assault in person to person criminal activity, we now have sophisticated intelligent criminals who cannot readily be detected. They use arrangements, not only inside but also outside Australia, to amass large sums of money as well as to destroy the fabric of our society.

ANSWER.PARA: When we came to office we found deficiencies in a number of areas, not least of which was that of extradition treaties. The honourable member has raised the need for a national effort. There has always been that need. I am pleased to say that at the recent meeting with State Attorneys-General there was consensus that there needs to be uniform activity to attack organised crime. Accordingly, we have prepared uniform legislation in respect of both the drug area and the issue of forfeiture of assets. The States are now adopting legislation that will be to the advantage of the whole nation. Legislation for the forfeiture of assets has already been introduced in New South Wales and Victoria. At the same time we are talking about introducing legislation in similar terms that would deal not only with the forfeiture of assets on conviction but also the forfeiture of assets that might be deemed to have been acquired by illegal means. Those are some of the problems we are facing in dealing with this matter.

The honourable member referred to the need for a national criminal code. Of course, there is such a need, but the best way to achieve it is by the States and the Commonwealth working together to achieve uniformity in this area, not least in the discussions encouraged by our Solicitor-General about a cross-vesting of jurisdiction. That matter is very well advanced.

To return to the issue of extradition, last year we established a task force to deal with extradition treaties. That preceded a conference in Milan which dealt with the need to consider an updated concept throughout the world of the best way to pursue organised crime on an international basis. At that conference Australian sponsored a motion to update the extradition treaties and to talk about mutual assistance treaties. That conference of 125 countries adopted unanimously the Australian resolution. It is not good enough just to look at the resolution. One has to look at what Australia has done since that time. Since the task force was established, we have signed and updated at least eight treaties. At present we are negotiating treaties with the United States of America, Spain, Monaco, the Federal Republic of Germany, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Bolivia, Israel and Paraguay. We also have a good chance of obtaining the extradition of some criminals.

It is very interesting to look at the money trail involved in criminal activity. It is well known that in one case alone there could have been at least $26m transmitted out of this country through organised crime. It runs into massive amounts of money. There has to be a sanction not only in pursuing the individual but also in pursuing the assets. It is also recognised that, regrettably, one bank manager in Australia opened seven different accounts for one person using different names. It is no help when the banking authorities do not co-operate. It is also well recognised in the United States that there is movement of money from bank accounts around the world. It is important to follow the money trail. We will have those matters very much in mind in considering what we will be able to introduce by way of legislative reform.

I thank the honourable gentleman for the question because there is no more serious matter bedevilling Australian society at present than sophisticated organised crime, which is running into billions of dollars. It requires the close co-operation of the State authorities and of the law enforcement agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Are Australian law enforcement agencies still unable to apprehend and hold transiting passengers carrying illegal drugs? Did the Minister last November call for a report on the Taillon case, which highlighted this serious anomaly, with the aim of closing this gap in our drug defences? Why has nothing been done and how does this gross negligence square with the drug offensive and the claims made as recently as yesterday by the Special Minister of State that the Government is doing all it can to fight the drug menace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is doing all it can to fight the drug menace. We were all very much surprised that, as the honourable member has said, when a passenger was in transit in Sydney and his baggage was searched, the Director of Public Prosecutions decided that he could not be deemed to have in his possession that prohibited narcotic. There is a lot of doubt about the interpretation of the words `deemed to be in possession of'--

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Spender interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for North Sydney.

—I understand the concern of the interjector, but in fact nothing was done to remedy this by the previous Government. I accept the view that perhaps the previous Government did not think there was a weakness in the law either. Many people in Australia would not have thought that it was a weakness in the law when one who had narcotics in his own baggage was not deemed to be in possession of them. One must ask in whose possession they might have been deemed to be. I want to be fair to the honourable gentleman who asked the question, as I think it has a lot of merit. The Canadians certainly were mystified when told by the Australian authorities that perhaps they would like to charge this gentleman when he got to Canada. They came back with the answer that they did not think they would have enough evidence to convict him, because it had already been established that it involved Australia. I have sent the matter back to the Department to see whether it would like to get a second opinion on this position.
—Six months later.

—It did not go back just last week, I might add. To make the situation very clear, if the Director of Public Prosecutions is correct in his analysis of the law, the law will be amended. If he is not correct, in future anybody coming through this country with narcotics in his possession-that includes in his baggage-will be prosecuted forthwith.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of widespread criticism in rural communities, as reflected in the recent report of the Prime Minister's country task force, about the lending policies and practices of banks as they affect farmers? Has the Minister taken any action to investigate these criticisms? Can he inform the House of the results of his investigations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be obvious to honourable members that depressed international commodity prices and relatively high interest rates are causing financial difficulties for many primary producers. This has heightened the normal level of farmer criticism of the banks. In addition, it is fair to say that many people, including primary producers, are still in the process of coming to terms with the environment created by financial sector deregulation. I have not sought to blame the banks for all the ills of the rural sector, despite the popularity that that might bring. I have, however, been concerned for some time about the problems of the rural debt situation, and in January I met with representatives of the banks and a number of farm consultants to discuss rural debt problems. The current difficulties of the rural sector were very much in the Government's mind when we prepared our rural and economic policy statement of 15 April. That statement included a major expansion of finance for the rural adjustment scheme, which directly addresses some of the problems of rural debt.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the report of the Prime Minister's country task force, to which the honourable gentleman referred-I might add here that the task force has been extremely useful in improving two-way communication between government and rural communities-I undertook a series of meetings with bank officials specifically to discuss bank policies and practices as they relate to primary producers. The issues discussed included the banks' overall lending margins, allegations of penalty interest rates on rural borrowers, administration and other bank charges, the criteria used in assessing applications for loans, and the banks' treatment of farmers in financial difficulty. As a result of the Prime Minister's commitment in Canowindra last Saturday, I have forwarded to him a report on these discussions. The discussions were comprehensive--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about his commitment on the fringe benefits tax?

—The honourable member is a bit like a whale; he is likely to get harpooned as he comes up to spout. It is my observation that the banks themselves need to improve their communications with the rural sector and possibly the degree to which local managers appreciate and apply their stated policies. For example, the banks denied any allegations of discrimination against the rural sector, particularly in relation to penalty interest rate charges.
—You did a good job up there, Bob.

—I would have thought members of the National Party of Australia would be interested in this. The banks indicated that penalty rates applied only to borrowers who had failed to meet previous commitments and that such penalties applied regardless of the industry in which the borrower was engaged. They expressed the view that their lending policies were well geared to meeting the needs of the rural sector. I believe the assurances that I obtained could go a long way towards dissipating rural concerns in this area. The financial sector deregulation undertaken by the Government is resulting in improved services being provided by the banks, and is ensuring that competitive pressures minimise the scope for excessive margins between lending and borrowing rates.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, I must say that there are remaining areas of concern. One is the ability of rural borrowers, when compared with other borrowers, to bargain for the best available finance package. Another is the extent to which the banks' announced policies are communicated to and applied by local managers. It is very important that the banks provide a full and adequate service to rural clients at minimum cost. The Government will be continuing to gather information on the areas in which the banks' practices could be improved and it will discuss these with the bankers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his claim that the relationship between Australia and China should be a model of successful co-operation between countries of different social and political systems. In view of the assessment in the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities that any substantial threat to Australia would have to come from or through the northern archipelago, can the Prime Minister assure the House that from now on repairing and strengthening Australia's relationship with Indonesia will become a major foreign policy goal of his Government, and is he prepared to invest as much personal energy and zeal in repairing that relationship as he has invested, properly, in Australia's relationship with China?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I draw to the attention of the House and the people of Australia the monumental hypocrisy of the Opposition when it comes to the question of Australia's relations with Indonesia. It will not have escaped the attention of many people in this country that the same group of people in 1963 shamelessly tried to create and manipulate the concept of a threat from Indonesia for the baseless purpose of trying to win an election in that year. People will recall that they sent a dying Minister for Defence to Washington to negotiate the F111 deal and, because at that time they held government in this place by a margin of one seat, they then had B52 aircraft flying over this country, trying to persuade the people of Australia that we were about to be invaded by Indonesia and to come into conflict with it. If there is one group of people in this country that has no mandate to speak about defence and our relations with Indonesia, it is this group of people opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: In the whole sorry pageant of the way in which the conservatives in this country have used foreign affairs, not in terms of trying to understand what Australia's constructive relationship with the region should be but for miserable domestic political purposes, it is the question of Indonesia more than any other which stands as a condemnation of them. They used relations with Indonesia to try to win an election. They did nothing constructive about the relationship. They are no different in 1986 from what they were in 1963. They were hypocrites then; they are hypocrites now.

Having established the total lack of bona fides of the conservatives in this country in relation to this matter, let me make it quite clear, as does the Dibb report and as does my Minister for Defence, that a proper relationship with a stable Indonesia is of fundamental importance to this country. As distinct from its predecessors, who continually played their relations with the region for miserable domestic political purposes, from day one this Government, particularly through the activities of its Foreign Minister, has sought constructively to engage Australia with each of these countries to try to improve the relationship, to try to put it on a basis whereby these countries would understand that the concern of Australia is to have a peaceable, productive relationship in all manner of affairs-not merely commercial but cultural, scientific, sporting and all people to people relationships.

The Government, as I say, particularly through the Minister for Foreign Affairs, has consistently and, I would suggest, very successfully pursued that policy. As far as Indonesia is concerned, the Minister for Foreign Affairs went first to Indonesia within a matter of weeks of this Government being formed. Apart from my visit to New Guinea in June, which was part of the same visit, the first overseas country which I visited was Indonesia. I believe that I established good and warm personal relations with President Suharto. From that beginning in 1983 we have continued, as far as we are concerned, to try to make the Government and the people of Indonesia understand that this Government and, I believe, the people of Australia have warm, positive feelings towards that country. We recognise that there have been difficulties in the past but no government, I believe, could have done more than this Government has done to say: `As far as possible the things of the past should be put behind us and we should look to the future'. That is what we have done. We cannot help it if there are reactions in certain quarters in Indonesia to something that happens in this country beyond the control of this Government.

Although some recent articles in one particular Indonesian newspaper have sought to continue the ruction between our two countries, I do not believe that those articles reflect the opinion of the Government of Indonesia. Indeed, Madam Speaker, I remind you that Ambassador Marpaung has been quoted as saying very recently that he considers his assignment to be to build as many bridges as possible between Indonesia and Australia. The recent articles in the AB newspaper in Indonesia reflect the fact that there is still some misunderstanding in that country about the attitudes of Australia, its people and its Government. It shows that much work has to be done. I take the point from the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition that it is incumbent upon all of us-me, the Prime Minister, all Ministers of this Government, the Leader of the Opposition and all people in positions of responsibility-to take every opportunity to increase the level of understanding between the peoples of Indonesia and Australia. This is not a matter for attempts at cheap political point scoring.

We have at this time a very significant responsibility. Recognising that Indonesia is a country of 160 million people, our most populous and nearest neighbour, the Government and all of us in positions of public life have a responsibility to try to foster good relations between our two countries. I give the people of Australia the solemn undertaking that I and all Ministers of this Government will accept the responsibility we have for continuing to work at building the relationship between Australia and Indonesia. In that respect, I welcome very much the fact that my Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has recently been in Indonesia. I take it as a clear indication that at official Government levels in Indonesia there is a willingness and a preparedness to work in the way that I am talking about, the fact that the Minister had constructive, positive discussions and relations when he was there. That sort of relationship must be continued. I and all members of this Government will continue to do our best. As we do so, the people of this country will draw the very clear and obvious distinction between the positive, constructive approach of this Government and the miserable irrelevancies that are coming from the other side of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether his attention has been drawn to a segment broadcast last week on radio station 5AA in Adelaide, a once respectable station--
—It is owned by the Labor Party.

—That was when it was respectable. The segment dealt with petrol sniffing. Did the segment include a skit in which people purporting to be Aboriginals were portrayed as discussing the various merits of sniffing different grades of petrol? Does material of this kind trivialise serious and tragic instances of drug abuse which is prevalent within the Aboriginal community, particularly amongst young people, but not restricted to it? What action can be taken to persuade the station not to broadcast this kind of racist material in future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true to say that the whole question of drug abuse is a matter of concern to all members of this House, as it is certainly a matter of concern to all Ministers in both State and Federal governments. It is not an issue to be trivialised. I think all honourable members would agree that, if one young Australian is found dead as a result of drug abuse or overuse, it is a matter of concern to all of us. That has been demonstrated by the range of debates that have taken place in the Parliament on the whole question of drug abuse. The particular segment that was broadcast has been accurately described by the honourable member who asked the question. I do not propose to repeat the offensive terms which were used. I will table a copy of the transcript of the broadcast so that any honourable member interested in the matter can acquaint himself with those terms.

ANSWER.PARA: I say quite objectively that I think Mr Paul Makin, the broadcaster concerned, would not, under any circumstances, have tried to trivialise drug abuse by members of the broader community. I do not think he would have trivialised the issue or used the terms he did if he had been dealing with the damage, death and tragedy that can be caused in the broader community. Therefore, when he addresses himself to the question of petrol sniffing, which continues in Aboriginal communities and which unfortunately causes not only brain damage but also death, I believe that it is racist, stupid and insensitive, as it is for any broadcaster, to use the air waves to trivialise such an important matter. It is a matter of concern not merely to me but also-I am certain-to the relevant Ministers in the Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia and all Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs who work in close co-operation in jointly funded projects which are designed to reduce petrol sniffing wherever it occurs in Aboriginal communities.

I condemn without reservation both Mr Makin and the radio station 5AA for allowing this broadcast to take place. On behalf of Aboriginal people I call for an unqualified withdrawal and apology. Nothing less could be regarded as satisfactory. If that does not take place, the proper course is for me to refer the matter to the Attorney-General of South Australia as well as the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to see what action it should properly take with the terms of its Act to ensure that this sort of thing does not occur again in the future.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, I present the report of the Committee on the inquiry into the televising and radio broadcasting of both Houses and their committees, together with a copy of the transcript of evidence and a copy of the Committee's minutes of proceedings relating to the inquiry.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Committee on the televising and radio broadcasting of proceedings inquiry reflects deliberations of the Committee extending over 3 1/2 years and three parliaments. During that time the Committee received evidence and consulted with members of parliament, parliamentary officers, broadcasting officials and organisations, specific interest groups and citizens of Australia. There were changes in the Committee's membership during that time and I thank members of the Committee, past and present, for the effort they devoted to the task of forming recommendations to both Houses on the vital question of the electronic delivery of proceedings. I would like to pay particular tribute in this regard to my predecessor as Speaker and Chairman of the Committee, the Hon. Dr. H. A. Jenkins.

INTERJECT.PARA: Among the principal recommendations of the Committee are that continuous radio broadcasting of the proceedings of the Houses should continue, with the allocation of the broadcast still being determined by the Committee. The Committee also recommends that the broadcast of proceedings be extended to cover adjournment debates-which are available during the trial period for the recording of excerpts. The second report of the Standing Committee on Procedure also included in its recommendations the broadcast of adjournment debates.

The Broadcasting Committee's report also recommends that a parliamentary radio network should be established, and that the proceedings of parliamentary committees meeting when neither House is sitting should be available for radio broadcasting.

The report recommends that broadcasting of excerpts be authorised on a permanent basis if the trial period is satisfactory. When the re-broadcast of excerpts was presented to the Houses, an undertaking was given to inform the Houses of the results of monitoring of television and radio station usage. This is contained in Appendix 3 to the report.

In relation to televising of proceedings, the Committee has recommended that, with specific exceptions, this not be undertaken from the provisional Parliament House but that proceedings of the Houses and their committees be available for televising in the new Parliament House, subject to guidelines adopted for televising the Budget speeches. However, there should be no compulsion to televise proceedings. The Committee has also recommended the establishment of a parliamentary audio-visual unit.

The report contains a number of recommendations relating to protection provided to broadcasters, the impact of access of the electronic media on parliamentary practices or conventions-for example, the sub judice rule-control of access to the sound and vision signals and revision of the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act. I commend the report to the House.

The conditions for granting access to proceedings of the Senate and the House of Representatives for the purpose of recording and broadcasting excerpts as contained in Appendix 2 to the report I have just presented were those in effect when the Committee agreed to the report. On 2 June 1986 the Committee agreed that guidelines 5a and 7 be amended as follows:
Guideline 5a-Excerpts of proceedings which are subsequently withdrawn shall be available for re-broadcast provided the withdrawal is also reported;
Guideline 7-Events in the galleries are not part of the proceedings and excerpts in relation to such events, as far as is practicable, should not be used.
The revised conditions for access are to take effect as from tomorrow and copies are being circulated for the information of members and the media.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed.
That the House take note of the paper.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sinclair) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a draft Parliamentary Privileges Bill 1986 and an explanatory memorandum to that Bill, copies of which were tabled by Mr President in the Senate earlier today.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members may be aware that on 9 April 1986 Mr President made a statement to the Senate concerning the judgment given in the Supreme Court of New South Wales relating to article 9 of the Bill of Rights in its application to the Houses of the Australian Parliament. In the debate that followed, it was suggested that it would be necessary for the Parliament to legislate to avoid the consequences of that judgment and to restore the established interpretation of article 9. It was further suggested that Mr President should take some action to initiate the necessary legislation. It was proposed that any legislation should deal with the changes in the law recommended by the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege in its report in 1984, so that the Senate could consider those recommendations in conjunction with any proposed provisions dealing with the interpretation of article 9. These suggestions were reinforced by requests made to Mr President by senators in discussion.

The Senate has been primarily concerned in this matter because the decision of the court related to the use in proceedings of statements made to Senate committees. Nevertheless, because the matter is of equal concern to members of the House of Representatives, I have been following developments closely. I should also say that many members of the House have voiced to me their concern at the Supreme Court judgment.

In response to the requests, Mr President has had a Bill prepared by one of the Department of the Senate's consultant draftsmen to carry out these two purposes. I was kept informed in the matter and earlier drafts of the Bill were made available for my consideration. The Bill has been tabled in draft form so as to allow senators and members time to make comments on the proposed provisions. Such comments will be considered and it is Mr President's intention to introduce the Bill in the next period of sittings.

It is an unprecedented step for a Presiding Officer to initiate legislation, but Mr President has taken this step because of the fundamental importance to both Houses of the matters involved. On all the advice given to Mr President and to me, the judgments given in the court represent a serious threat to the freedom of speech in Parliament and the capacity of members to speak for their constituents, and an equally serious threat to the protection of witnesses who give evidence to parliamentary committees.

Clause 16 of the draft Bill deals with the interpretation of article 9, and the remaining clauses deal with the recommendations of the Joint Committee. The Bill departs from these recommendations in a number of respects, and these departures and the reasons for them are explained in the explanatory memorandum.

I strongly recommend to honourable members that they become acquainted with the issues involved in this matter and read the draft Bill and explanatory memorandum which I have presented, so that early consideration may be given to the proposed legislation. Mr President and I look forward to receiving any comments from senators or members on the draft Bill.
Mr Spender-Madam Speaker, with your indulgence, may I inquire when it is envisaged that the Bill will be brought into the House of Representatives for debate?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill, having been initiated in the Senate, will first be debated in the Senate and it will then come across to this House. Mr President hopes that will take place reasonably early in the Budget session.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite,Mr Fife,Mr Hawker and Mr Hodges.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag be changed only with the approval of the nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawke and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian Flag as provided in section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the majority of people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth the legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you do not proceed with the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Company Cars
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you do not proceed with the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Karen Refugees in Thailand
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we request that the Government of Australia consider the possibility of giving aid to the Karen civilian refugees at present fleeing from Burma into Thailand as a result of military action in the border areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
In view of the fact that Australian Governments, since the Pearson Report of 1968, have committed themselves to meeting the 0.7% GNP target for overseas aid, which at present is 0.49%, and
because it is an important expression of the humanitarian concerns of the Australian community that at this critical time of shortage, food aid to Africa be continued, and
considering that development programmes in developing countries are difficult to carry out where basic education levels are low, and

mindful of the fact that voluntary aid agencies have an aptitude for grass roots level development, an area which the Government has difficulty in reaching, concluding therefore that official aid could thus be complemented and supported by an increase in the level of funding to these agencies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Australian Government
(1) move to a 0.7% GNP target level for overseas aid funding, and announce a plan to reach this by the year 1991,
(2) continue aid to Africa at an increased level,
(3) make more funds available for development education,
(4) implement the recommendation to the Government that assistance to voluntary overseas aid agencies be doubled.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(a) That Australia's record high interest rates, currently at levels up to four times higher than competitor OECD member countries, are causing severe hardship and damage to this nation's small business and farm sectors,
(b) unless immediately reduced these artificially boosted interest levels will inflict irreparable harm to the national economy,
(c) the individual initiative and job potential of the small business sector is in danger of being permanently crippled.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(1) The Government will immediately reverse its interventionist policy which is artificially boosting interest rates in Australia to their highest level in 50 years.
(2) The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Treasurer, Mr Keating, will honour their 1983 election pledge to bring interest rates down from their then level of 12.5%.
(3) The Australian dollar will be allowed to float to find its own level in accordance with the Government's stated deregulation objectives.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
Reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
(2) That the impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that persistent rumour suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.
