(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygenic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chirita Family
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned your petitioners, as in duty bound will humbly pray that a public inquiry be conducted for the migration of the Chirita family (father) Marin Chirita and (Fiance) Marc Codruta to be allowed into Australia and that the rights of Ion Chirita be recognised in Queensland.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Farming and Small Business
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectively showeth that we, the undersigned women, urge the Government to change social and economic policy which is destroying family farming and small business, and breaking down the fabric of society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour it's commitments. We want to ensure a future for our families, our communities and our country.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That numerous provisions exist in industrial legislation and awards which purport to provide special protection to women workers but which have been shown to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article 11 of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women to which Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to equality be removed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival;

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will: propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the `First International Earth Repair Year' (FIERY) as a vital action to ignite global co-operation for Worldpeace.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
Because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
Because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
Because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
Because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
Because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
Because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
Because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to `the storyline' of a film screened,

Because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the EFFECTS of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,

Because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards, and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association and Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. The Sex Discrimination Act, passed by Parliament in 1984, will automatically make unenforceable from 1st August, 1986 the weightlifting limits applicable to women employees and contained in State laws, regulations and awards.
2. These weight lifting limits have applied throughout Australia for many years and have acted to prevent many injuries at the workplace, thereby avoiding much suffering and loss of working time.
3. The removal of this protective legislation will increase the rate of injury among women employees and lead to greater Workers' Compensation costs for employers.
4. The weight lifting limits do not in any way hamper the achievement of equality and equal opportunity in employment for women employees in the workforce.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament will amend the Sex Discrimination Act to enable the weight lifting limits for women employees to continue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain electors of Dawson shows that the proposed Bill of Rights.
Overlooks basic rights concerning union membership, education, and private property,
Is a basis for massive intrusion into State responsibilities,
Establishes a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with powers similar to a Court but without accepted legal procedures and protections for the accused, and
Provides no avenue of appeal against decisions of the HR&EOC.

The petition further shows that fundamental protection of human rights is already to be found in the Courts, in tolerance, in fair play, belief in democratic institutions, and in support for rule of law.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament will not allow the Australian Bill of Rights Bill to pass into law.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Hail Mary
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the film `Hail Mary' is pornographic and blasphemous and gravely offends our religious beliefs and those of the vast majority of Australian Christians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament will respect the will of the undersigned and have the pornographic and blasphemous film ``Hail Mary'' banned in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Establishment of a Women's Health Centre, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain residents of the Australian Capital Territory draws to the attention of the House the proposal being considered by the A.C.T. Health Authority to establish a Women's Health Centre in the A.C.T. There is grave concern that the proposed centre would:
duplicate existing services;
further reduce such services at hospitals/clinics to provide funding for the new centre;
add to the difficulties faced by the aged/migrant women/mothers of young children, who are now adequately served by decentralised community based health centres;
inevitably lead to increased costs to the taxpayer;
present an opportunity for the establishment of an abortion clinic in the A.C.T.
Your petitioners therefore pray that no further action be taken to establish or set up a discrete health centre for women in the Australian Capital Territory.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and the present justice system in this country or in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers' conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right of Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
That consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
That unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Sutherland Shire New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Coptic Orthodox Church
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned members of the Coptic community resident in New South Wales respectfully showeth:

Whereas the Coptic Orthodox Church, Diocese of Australia, Parish of New South Wales has enjoyed funding under the Grant-In-Aid Scheme since 1980, and has used the funds granted to employ a full-time social worker to assist members of the Coptic community in Sydney in dealing with problems encountered particularly by ethnic minorities in our society.
Whereas the problems of the Coptic community in Sydney are, if anything, greater today than they were in 1980.
Whereas the Church's application for continued funding under the Grant-In-Aid Scheme for 1985-86 has been rejected by the Honourable the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
Whereas the resultant loss of the services of a full-time social worker will cause immense hardship and distress within the Coptic community in Sydney.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the funding of the Coptic Orthodox Church, Diocese of Australia and Parish of New South Wales under the Grant-In-Aid Scheme be restored for 1985-86, and for so long thereafter as may be necessary in order to meet the needs of the Coptic community in Sydney.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SMALL BUSINESS: GOVERNMENT REGULATION AND TAXATION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to remove the excessive burden of Government regulation and taxation from small business, so as to encourage investment and job growth.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the Government has at last woken up to the need for private sector investment and has suddenly realised that something must be done about the matter, although I doubt that the Government will achieve very much by the threats it might use. There is no doubt that, in seeking that private sector investment, the Government will have to turn to the 650,000 Australian employers who employ fewer than five people. Let us consider the reasons why these people are not investing, why they are not helping Australia out of its present economic problems. While I was thinking this matter through, I remembered a circumstance some years ago when early in my business career I visited my bank to discuss finance for a new project to invest money in Australia. I prepared an elaborate cash flow, which indicated that the profits could repay the loan in three years. During our discussions my bank manager indicated that in my calculations I had not included the cost of income tax, and he sent me home to rework my cash flow. The subsequent reworking of that cash flow extended my repayment period for the loan from three years to six years-double the amount of time. That was not only because of the tax burden but also because the extended time added to my interest burden. Of course, if we had had a capital gains tax at that time I would not have bothered to make the investment at all. I would have been like all the smart investors today; I would have lent my money to the Government and taken the high interest rates that the Government offers in competition with the small business sector.

SPEECH.PARA: All this proves is that tax is a cost of production, and business must take account of that in calculating its cash flow. Let us note something else when the Treasurer stands in this place and tells us time and time again that the business profit share is up. In the statistical sense, profit share is calculated before interest, before tax and before depreciation. This is just another example of the philosophy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of saying that two plus two equals any number up to 10-any number that suits his argument at the time when he is trying to sell his ability to Australians. The reality of small business is that those businessmen look at their balance sheets; they do not listen to the Treasurer's rhetoric. They make investments on what they see as the bottom line. When they see brackets down there, they are not too keen for further investment. We saw reported in the Australian on 2 May that Australian Guarantee Corporation, the biggest finance company in Australia, reported a 9.6 per cent fall in profit completely attributable to bankruptcies in the small business sector. The report stated:
The directors blamed the result on the growing number of bankruptcies in the small business sector, caused by high interest rates-
a Government problem-
high levels of unemployment-
a Government problem-
the impact of tax changes-
and who can we blame for that but the Government-
and the low level of economic activity-

which this Government tells us that that does not even exist. Let us look at how this Government came to office and the promises it made to small business. Mr Dawkins, the then shadow Minister, told Australian small business on 13 February 1983:
A Labor government will make a new commitment to revitalise small business and will back that commitment with action-
that is probably affirmative action-
resources and legislation.

It certainly kept the promise about the legislation-625 pages of additional tax legislation. Businessmen got that legislation, and it is now rumoured that they may get price fixing legislation, and they will be grateful for that!
Small businessmen were also told that a Labor government:
. . . will ease the tax burden by legislating to allow small firms full retention of profits where these funds are to be used for genuine business purposes.

What was the Government's reaction to that? It took out the investment allowance-it removed it, it does not exist. It also sought to allow the option of provisional tax to be paid in quarterly instalments. Yes, that has been done, but a fiddle was worked. It actually moved the figure forward three months instead of back three months. It also advocated amending the Sales Tax Act to allow a full month for remittance of tax owing. That has never been done, irrespective of the fact that the tax package gave the Government a tax windfall of $110m per annum, which could have been used for that purpose. It is a matter to which I have drawn the attention of the House on other occasions.

Mr Dawkins also advocated exempting industrial research and development grants from tax. Well, the Government did not do that. It has brought in 150 per cent tax deductibility, but has specially excluded the small business sector. There has to be a threshold of $20,000, and there is encouragement for other investors to send their money off to institutions such as universities and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation instead of investing it in the backyard innovator, who may also wish to invest his own money and claim the deduction. He is pushed out, and there is good reason for all that.

Small business is no longer even a phrase in this Government's criteria. It does not want to know about small business. Since small business defied the Australian Council of Trade Unions ban on Queensland, it has been invisible to this Government. This Government does not even have a Minister representing small business officially. Those are the sorts of things the Government promised and small business did not get them. But the one thing they were told they would not have was a capital gains tax. Small businessmen were told that there would be no such a tax. They trusted this Government and they got a capital gains tax.

Let us look at the record of the Hawke Government on taxation. The last Fraser Budget taxed Australians $44 billion. The present Budget estimate is $64 billion, and we are expecting it to be higher. That figure has risen by $20 billion in three years. It took the previous governments of Australia 83 years to achieve an annual rate of $44 billion of taxation a year and this Government has managed to add 50 per cent to that in three years. Even if we go into more esoteric figures, we find that as a percentage of gross domestic product this Government's tax collections have gone from 23.8 per cent to 25.3 per cent. While the Government has done all that, it has borrowed $20 billion and has been out there scratching and fighting with the small business sector which is trying to borrow money at a reasonable rate to invest in the progress of Australia. The Government has been pushing small business out of the way. Consequently, small business in Australian is paying 18 per cent for its money when 5 per cent is the going rate overseas. One knows how that works, particularly if one has borrowed money at the 10 to 12 per cent rate available when this Government entered office and is locked into a loan. One cannot send it back-it has been spent. And so it goes on. We see government taking a bigger role every day and pushing away small business people.

The tax package is built on the politics of envy of the ACTU. This Government seems to think that it took the initiative on this tax package, but it got its instructions on 3 February 1985 when Bill Kelty made his address to the Socialist Forum. Everything that has happened in the meantime has been a nothing. Let us remember that we were promised no capital gains tax, and now we have just about got one. We are told: `Don't worry about it, it does not mean very much to you. We are only going to collect a little bit of money'.

Let us work out how selective it will be. I must agree that probably the burden on a property owner-a large property with a large capital value-with inflationary discounting will be insignificant in most cases. But a lot of other people are in business. I refer to people who run small businesses in rented property, such as delicatessens, take-away food stores and a myriad of others. There are people who operate trucks on the road, and they will be hit extremely hard by this particular tax. It will tax goodwill, and more particularly the only discount available from that goodwill is a 20 per cent discount in the case of a start-up business. A business with no goodwill, or very little goodwill because it has run down, may be bought by a person who works hard and joins the 21 Club. The 21 Club comprises people who work from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. seven days a week, three times seven. Those people join the 21 Club, they take such a business and build it up. One of them could say: `I have outgrown this business, I have done all I can do with it. I want to sell it and I want to buy a small supermarket'.

Let me give an example of the corner deli proprietor who wants to buy a small supermarket and finds one. Let us say that the price is $100,000; the person concerned still has his own business and organises a sale on sale-a common thing to do. Eventually, he sells the business to someone and is able to arrange the settlement of the new supermarket. So he sells his business for $50,000, plant and stock is written down in that business to $20,000. He has $20,000 worth of savings and wants to buy the supermarket for $100,000. He has already paid tax on the $20,000 of savings, but is still $30,000 short. So he goes to the bank to borrow that sum, and that is the maximum he can service. There he is, he makes his purchase in December and gets on with the work of building up that business, as he did with the previous one.

What happens then? He goes round six months later to his tax accountant and dumps all the receipts and everything on him, and says: `Please work out my tax return'. When he gets the return back, he finds an extra $15,000 on his tax bill. He says: `What's this for?' He is told: `That is your capital gains tax on the previous sale'. He says: `But I haven't got the money'. Well, one never tells the tax commissioner `I haven't got the money', because the commissioner will say `Tough luck, I want the money and I want it now'. What does the businessman do? He is broke, he is finished. He cannot service the additional 50 per cent of borrowing and he has had it; that is, if he did not know-and that will not be so in every case, I know. His second alternative is that he does know about this horrible account because he has gone to his accountant. What does he do then? He does not sell and he does not buy, because suddenly he cannot be viable if he leaves his present business. He is locked in and the growth that Australia needs is denied us.

The person in question has a third alternative-and this will happen and it will not be much help. He will add the $15,000 to the sale price of his deli. It is possible that some early retiring bureaucrat will invest his superannuation lump sum in that overpriced business and go broke. That will be a great help to the economy also, because that retirement money will be lost and that person will be back on the pension.

I could give exactly the same example of a small business truckie who has his truck on lease and finds himself up for huge amounts, probably $20,000 or $30,000 worth of capital gains tax, purely because, having paid his truck out at 20 per cent of its value, he is able to trade it in at 80 per cent. Remember that all these people write down their plant. Let us also remember the tax rate. It will be the maximum marginal rate at which the capital gains tax will be calculated.

Then we have the wonderful fringe benefits tax, and we know what that means. Everybody is now worried about keeping receipts because substantiation goes with the tax. There will be paper work running out of everywhere. We will have a printers-led recovery. But the reality is that there are two sides to that question for small business. There is the person who has to get the receipt and the person who has to write it. Numerous small businesses which generally deal in cash will have to have somebody on the staff hereinafter writing out receipts. We hear that the Government is resolving that. One will not have to sign them. There will be a business in receipts if they do not need to be signed, because everyone will go and buy a cash register that prints receipts; out they will go, and they will put on a spike the ones that people do not take away with them and they will give them to those who want them. People will be back to signing them, because they will find that that is just another form of avoidance. They are the sorts of things that we will have.

Every person who wants to make a proper claim for a car, whether the car is the property of the employer or of someone working for him, will have to have a log book and, in fact, if a person incurs small expenses as he travels around in his employment or business he will have to have a diary. Everything one does will have to be done in that particular fashion. Honourable members should listen to this: If one happens to be giving rent to someone, this is the sort of calculation that one will have to make. One must know that the average mining wage for the November preceding the year of tax was $650, that the dwelling rent factor was 0.20 and that the employee paid $1,000 in rent. This is how one calculates it: 650 by 52 by 0.20 by 0.6 by 182 over 365 minus 1,000. If honourable members think that that is easy they should try to get two of those figures. The average mining wage and the dwelling rent factor are not available from the Australian Statistician; we cannot get them. Although that is an option, it cannot be compared with the others.

This just goes on and on. The butcher who lets his worker take home a little bit of meat has now got to report that and have it taxed. Honourable members opposite would know, if any of them had been in small business, why historically the butcher gave the meat to his employee-it was a better alternative to his stealing it. That used to happen in the hotel industry, too. People will go back to stealing as small business is obliged to withdraw these sorts of privileges. It was bad enough when we had just all the complicated awards provided by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to contend with. Now, when we put on new staff members, we will have to read not only the award but also the 56 pages of the fringe benefits tax booklet to see where they fit in and just what we might be giving them. Imagine people battling and struggling, trying to earn their living, having to contend with that travel diary, log books and employment agreements. With fringe benefits, substantiation rests with the employer. Field auditing and self-assessment are on.

One of my constituents said to me the other day: `I've got it fixed. I'm going to have a new car for business and an old bomb for private purposes'. I said: `That's all right, but don't park that new car, the business car, outside the hotel one night because the field auditor might be staying there and when he goes downstairs he will write down the registration number. He will write down all the numbers because he can check on you later on'. That is the sort of society that this Government is bringing us to. That is what we are confronted with. It goes on: Representatives' cars will be taxed, remote area housing will be taxed and the cost of that will be passed on to consumers, while the really rich fat cats whom the Treasurer complains about will have their tax benefits increased.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important debate here today because it sets the scene of the climate confronting small business in Australia. We ought to go to the heart of the matter right at the outset. When the Opposition talks about small business what it has to do is talk about the framework within which small business operates. The framework is that determined by the level of investment, the level of demand, the level of industrial disputes, the wages and prices pressures that are on and the level of competitiveness in the economy. I think that it is significant that the Opposition has not addressed itself to this matter. It has made a brave attempt, but it is not good enough. The important thing that we have to understand in relation to small business as well as large business is that we must have the economic setting right and we must be sure that the economy is operating healthily and effectively. When we begin to draw comparisons, as I propose doing in a moment, we very quickly begin to see that the sort of framework within which small business operates now is a lot healthier than it was some three or four years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I will address myself to those matters, but before doing so, I make one further point. The Opposition talks about the burden of taxation and the difficulties of taxation. I remind honourable members opposite that when we came to office the former Government had left us with a tax system that did not work. It had also left us with a tax system that had the Australian community very angry indeed, because it was in- equitable and it was not being used properly. Despite the appeals of the Commissioner of Taxation, the former Government did not seek to do anything about removing those inequities or about ensuring that the tax system worked better. We ought to get that clear from the outset. Therefore, when we are talking about taxation, let us get the setting right. That setting is that the former Government did not work the tax system properly, and the electorate understood that very well, so well that it threw the former Government out of office. What we have set about doing is remedying some problems with that tax system, and I will talk about that in a moment.

I will talk now about investment. After that I will talk about the other important setting of the economy. We have to consider not only investment from the point of view of small business but also the level of economic growth and activity. I will talk also about industrial relations and disputations, because they are areas of considerable concern to small business. When one talks about investment it is important to consider the performance of investment in terms of Australia's economy in the recent period and to compare that with the performance of investment in the more recent past. In terms of business fixed investment-I am quoting figures in real terms-in 1982-83, under the previous Government, there was a 13.9 per cent reduction; that is, a reduction of 13.9 per cent in the level of activity coming through from the investment side. It continued on into 1983-84 because, clearly, the expectations of business at the time were such that they were going to continue to reduce their investment activity. Therefore, in 1982-83 we had a 13.9 per cent reduction in small business and in 1983-84 we had a further 10.4 per cent decline in business fixed investment. That is a poor record. When one talks about the settings of business activity and when one has a negative growth in investment activity, I really think one has to look at the performance of government, and at that time it was not good. By 1984-85 it had begun to recover; there was a 4.7 per cent increase in the level of real business fixed investment. What we have here is decisions by investors, not rhetoric.

This is not talk in a general sense but talk about the specifics-what we had in this period, when the Opposition was in government, was investors deciding that it was not worth investing. Why not? Because the Government had made a mess of the economy. It was well known that the previous Government had made a mess of the economy, and I will talk about that further in a moment. Honourable members opposite have to face the facts: When they were in government they made a mess of the economy; investors believed that the former Government had made a mess of the economy, so investment declined. It has recovered during the period that we have been in office. Some of that recovery is due to the levels of expectation of investors and some is due to improved economic conditions, and I propose to talk about those in a moment.

Let me be very clear: When one talks about levels of economic growth and investment one must remember to get the settings right. The first setting, the investment level, was poor-in fact not only was it poor, it was negative-when we came to office. We saw the effect of that running through our first financial year. However, recovery has resumed, and everyone knows that. Everyone also understands that the level of economic growth has improved. That is the next setting I wish to talk about. My colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) knows that in our electorates in Western Australia there has been a substantial increase in the level of economic activity. I could talk specifically about housing, which is of great importance to us in our electorates, but, to talk generally, the level of economic growth has been satisfying because we have seen increases in the level of jobs and business turnover. That is what getting the settings right is about; it is not some vague rhetoric, it is about getting it right so that business feels able to perform in an improved economy.

I mentioned the subject of taxation. I think it is important that we devote just a moment to talking about that subject. The taxation system fell into disrepair under the previous Government; it clearly did. What we are about doing now is repairing that taxation system. Let us look at it from the viewpoint of small business. One of the things that small business will be getting is imputation, which is very important. It is something that needed to be put in place for a long time; it was neglected by the previous Government. In fact, it could not bring in effective tax reforms. One can speculate on why it could not bring them in, but I do not propose to do that. What I do propose to say to members opposite is that they should not come into this place and talk about taxation without remembering, as the Australian community remembers, that their performance on taxation was less than adequate. In fact, the judgment was made by the Australian people. The previous Government did not deliver on taxation reform-it never did-and the Australian people know that. There has been comment in this debate about the fringe benefits tax. The reality is that the fringe benefits tax in the community is supported. Why is it supported? It is because it is seen as being a move towards a more equitable taxation system. I think that that has to be established. We cannot retreat from the fact, so I will keep before the people in this place a recognition that what we are putting in place is a far more effective taxation system.

Opposition members can come into this place and talk about tax, but what we notice is that when it gets down to serious taxation reform members opposite argue about it in this place and then try to knock off that serious taxation reform in the other place. The Opposition has had a record of doing that since the Australian Labor Party came into government, and the Australian community will judge it accordingly. I say to the Opposition: `Do not try to play this game on tax reform continually because the electorate will judge you harshly. It will see you as still being in the same camp as those who are not interested in producing taxation reform'. The Opposition's colours have not changed. Because it cannot win the numbers in this place it king hits decent legislation in the other place. It is to the Opposition's discredit and to the Australian Democrats' discredit that they cannot face up to the reality of tax reform in this country. We on this side have faced up to that reality; it is a difficult business but we have faced up to it.

I say very seriously to honourable members in this place: Tax reform is important in the view of the Australian people because ordinary taxpayers have had enough of the previous tax system that was administered by the previous Government. We are setting about reforming it. The Opposition may well want to king hit things in the other place. I understand it is suggesting this with identification cards. If the Opposition keeps doing that it will be judged accordingly, that is, as being a negative, carping Opposition, and that will not help it at all. One does not have to talk about the opinion polls to make a judgment on that; one simply has to talk to people in the community. The Opposition is judged as being negative and carping and that will not get it anywhere; it will stay where it is. That does not worry the Government very much but it means that there is not a decent debate about these important issues in the Australian community. There is the same old, tired material.

Let me talk about another issue-industrial relations and industrial disputes. We now have a 20-year low in industrial disputes, a substantial turnaround in the level of industrial disputation, and that is very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best for 20 years.

—My colleague the honourable member for Burke is right. I look forward to his joining the debate shortly. The important point I have to make is that, in terms of the level of industrial disputes, small business now knows that it has an industrial relations climate that is being properly managed. That is the first thing. The second point is that the Opposition wanders around with its opting out provision in industrial awards. It really ought to look at the situation because it is already possible to have variations in State industrial awards if small business cannot afford the pressure of award wages being put on it. That provision is already there but the Opposition makes so much out of the opting out arrangements. If the Opposition were to get in place, some day in the future, the sort of industrial relations system that it proposes, we would end up with a two-tiered industrial relations system. We can remember what that was like-the honourable member for Moore remembers what that was like-because that was one of the factors that got us both elected in 1973. The industrial relations climate was appalling. The Liberal and National parties could not manage industrial relations. Industrial disputes got out of hand and people learned to live with industrial stoppages. Under this Government they have learned to expect reasonable, sensible industrial relations. The record is there and it speaks louder than a lot of the noise in this place.
—And a very good Minister is in charge.

—As the honourable member for Moore says, a very good Minister is in charge. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has delivered by setting the scenes. We have to keep saying that we are responsible for getting the economic settings right. One of the other economic settings is the level of inflation. One cannot talk about inflation in this place without comparing what happened under the previous Government with what has happened under us.

SPEECH.PARA: I look at the wage-price pressure. Small business is under substantially less wage-price pressure now than it was some three or four years ago. Again the record speaks for itself and it is very telling. If the Opposition thinks back to what it did not do, if it thinks back to the maladministration it achieved when it was in government, what it should understand is that the climate within which small business operated was not a healthy climate. It was well understood by small business; it was well understood by the community generally. We have been able to set in place a climate for economic activity which is substantially better.

I now turn to a matter which is of great concern to honourable members on this side and that is workers compensation. We are very keen to see established-the legal profession is preventing this-a proper system of no fault workers compensation. One of the great burdens on small business in this country is the workers compensation system. Clearly, many-some are honourable members opposite-have a vested interest in preserving the current common law fault arrangements. This has resulted in high premiums for small business and a rip-off for the legal profession and the medical profession. It does not deliver in terms of the injured worker or improved industrial safety. We on this side will be working towards a comprehensive system of no fault workers compensation. It is very important and it needs to be got in place. We need to say to honourable members opposite: `Do not be conned by the legal profession because it is making a lot of money out of it'. The only people who are being ripped off are the injured worker and the small business community. We on this side of the House are very clear about that and we believe it to be important.

I now turn to housing. The honourable member for Moore, the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen), the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), the honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin), the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) and I, coming from Western Australia, have all had the benefit of a substantial improvement in housing. When we talk about small business-I believe that members in this place should legitimately talk about small business-we should remember that the very important small business in this country has been the housing sector. We have a very large array of small businesses operating within metropolitan Perth, for example, which have seen a substantial increase in the level of activity due to the first home owners scheme and due to improved expenditure on public housing. We have in place a housing policy that has worked. It has succeeded on the job side in terms of employment growth. That is very effective and we ought to recognise it. When we talk about the figure of 670,000 we are talking about people who are getting back into jobs. That is a vast turnaround from the negative performance the Opposition had when in government. In the housing sector we have improved levels of employment. Fortunately-this is an important social goal-we also have people actually getting into homes. That ought to be a goal and I believe that it is a goal that is shared by honourable members opposite but they have not got a housing policy to deliver it. We have a housing policy but I say, without being too partisan, that that is a goal which is jointly shared in this place. We have delivered but the Opposition, when in government, did not and there can be no doubt about that.

I should also point out that the profitability side of small business in housing has been very satisfactory. We have been pleased with the level of profitability. I think honourable members from Western Australia in particular would recognise that the level of profitability in the housing sector has been substantial. We are pleased because that is an important small business activity as far as we are concerned.

It is time to sum up and I conclude by saying that when we are talking about this kind of debate let us get the targets and the setting right. Let us be sure that we know what we are saying. It is all right to carp about some of the issues in relation to small business. However, what we have seen in recent times has been improved levels of economic growth, reduced levels of industrial disputation, an industrial relations system that works, wage-price pressure being substantially reduced on small business and a much improved demand position as far as small business is concerned. The problem the Opposition faced when it was in government was that demand was falling. We have been trying to ensure steady levels of demand. One of the issues we have had to address in the last six months has been higher levels of economic growth and manoeuvring towards easing that back a bit. Clearly the level of demand has been satisfactory. The Government stands on its record and it has been a very satisfactory record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance goes right to the heart of small business. It is no wonder that the growing strength of the rural protest movement has now spread nationally to include small business organisations. This revolt is indicative of the concern small business has for its future, hamstrung as it is by government regulation, excessive union power, interest rates and ever-increasing burdens of taxation. During the past week the full ramifications and complexities of the Australian Labor Party's fringe benefits and capital gains taxes have sunk in. Business today is positively panicking. Common sense and understanding have been deserted by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) talked about the need for a satisfactory economic framework. The balance of payments debacle, inflation and interest rates out of kilter with those in the rest of the world and a massive collapse in investment are all frightening signs. I guess that this is the economic framework the honourable member talked about. The honourable member for Stirling also talked about recovery. Mr Bruce McKenzie of the Warrnambool Institute of Advanced Education recently pointed out that one in four families in the Mallee and Sunraysia regions of Victoria lives in poverty. At the same time the Wimmera community care organisation-the welfare arm of the Uniting Church-based in my electorate advised that 2.8 million Australians, 800,000 children, are in poverty and deprived of adequate food, shelter and clothing. I ask: Is this recovery? I submit to this House that such circumstances are a direct result of government stickybeaks poking their noses into every aspect of business operations, excessive welfare corrupting our society and now the ultimate result-the flight and collapse of sales and investment.

Many small businesses are finding it difficult to survive and in rural areas this is exacerbated by falls in farm spending, the inability of small business to recover outstanding debts and a massive drift in population away from small towns. These problems have not been helped by government services being withdrawn and the out- rageous increase in punitive taxes and regulations. We on this side of the House have taken a strong stand and will knock out these measures I have mentioned.

After months of concern and confusion in the community the Government has now all but got its fringe benefits and capital gains taxes in place, with the collusion and opportunism of the Australian Democrats-shame on them. The people will give them their just deserts at the next poll-and good riddance. The capital gains tax is a time bomb. Let there be no misunderstanding. All assets in time that are owned by Australians, except for the family home, will be subject to capital gains tax. It will hit farms and small businesses-particularly those that make major capital improvements-new buildings and goodwill. It will be a direct penalty on the capital gain which is seen as the only superannuation that small business operators can put together over a lifetime of work and endeavour. The capital gain will now be taxed at marginal rates. This is the most potent capital gains tax in the world.

This is Labor's first foot in the door towards the reintroduction of a fully-fledged Federal death and gift duty. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in the House on 19 September: `Liability for tax in the case of death will be rolled over to successors'. In other words, people who inherit property will also now inherit a capital gains tax. The fringe benefits tax is equally painful. This tax, which is payable by employers, is levied on every imaginable benefit when goods and services at free or concessional rates are made available to employees. Employers are to be taxed at 46c in the dollar but this will rise to 49c after 31 March 1987.

Motor dealerships and machinery firms are laying off long term and highly skilled people in their scores. Many have already shed over half their work force. A machinery firm in my electorate, Ackland and Sons in Rupanyup, has closed. This business, which started 104 years ago, has won Australia-wide recognition for its high quality machinery. The impact of this closure has meant the loss of 15 skilled tradesmen in a town of just 450 people. This trend is being repeated throughout Australia. Yet this Government takes no heed as it argues amongst its various factions on social engineering policies, human rights and affirmative action Bills-more regulation, bureaucracy and control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly.

—The honourable member for Gippsland agrees. The National Party simply will not let this socialist Government get away with these taxes. We led the fight to successfully get rid of death duties. The National and Liberal parties as a coalition in government guarantee that these two taxes also will get the bullet.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last three years the Australian trade union movement has been given an unprecedented position of power and influence in our economy. The Australian Council of Trade Unions determined the result of the 1983 National Economic Summit Conference through the accord. We remember that only one man objected-and I need not say who. The ACTU also undermined the Treasurer's tax package and decided the direction of the National Taxation Summit, resulting in the greatest attack on capital, productivity and thrift ever conceived. Now the ACTU has negotiated a productivity superannuation deal with enormous long term consequences for union power and the direction of Australian society. For the small business sector of 700,000 people, for primary producers supplying 45 per cent of our export income, this is economic madness and must be resisted.

In 1981 the unions signalled their attack and revealed the motives underlying this superannuation scheme-control funds, and leverage to advance the cause of socialism. We know what this deal is all about. It is about a redistribution of wealth and power-sharing in our community. It is about a different approach to economic management and direction and about a disguised pay increase tantamount to a Federal government payroll tax applying to all irrespective of capacity to pay. This is a recipe for disaster. The real question is whether we are prepared to accept that the union movement is able to run everything and control the last cent we have, to control our superannuation funds and nationalise our earnings and savings. Despite the fact that business, small and large, primary producers and self-employed Australians have to foot the bill, no representatives of those groups were asked for their opinion. The views of individual employees were not considered. This was negotiated solely between the ACTU and the Hawke Government. The Government sees the arbitration system as a rubber stamp. It treats that system and employers with contempt.

The profile of the issue can be raised within this Parliament, but the battle on superannuation will be won or lost outside. The public outcry therefore must be strong, credible and continuous. We have to stop the rot and this headlong rush towards a corporate state. This whole issue is clearly an attack on the various values of freedom and concern of so many involved in small business and primary industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! They are socialists.

—I am pleased that the honourable member for Mitchell agrees with me. There is an attack on the depleted capital base, and with the economy falling to bits, interest rates sky high, building groups going broke and home buyers berserk with worry, such a challenge must be defeated. A slogan I saw recently said: `Even crime wouldn't pay if it was run by the present Federal Government'. How true that is. The inefficiencies of government, the burdens of regulation and the ever-growing bureaucracy are killing us. If the assistance that small business operators indicate that they require is not forthcoming in the near future, I fear for the long term viability of many of my small rural towns and some of the larger cities.
—We would have lost them.

—That is true. Traditionally, small business has been a major provider of employment opportunities for our rural youth. If these businesses do not survive, more and more opportunities will be lost, more and more youth will drift away leaving us with an aging population devoid of many basic services. To many people, the loss of two or three families from a town seems of little consequence. However, to a small business person and to our schools and hospitals these are major losses. People in these communities do not wish to see them die. Not only have rural communities in the past contributed a spirit that is of immeasureable value to the nation as a whole, and a valuable part of our Australian culture, but also rural communities are needed for the sake of the nation's economic health.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other problems facing small business in rural areas, including the high cost of telephone calls, freight charges, licence fees, penalty wage rates, annual leave loadings, and so on. The Government must as a first priority immediately change programs that damage employment opportunities, boost inflation and erode our savings and capital base. It must stop shifting an individual's responsibilities on to the taxpayers, who are almost an endangered species. A mere 4.3 million taxpayers are today supporting 5.7 million tax consumers. It is no wonder that the economy is cracking. I ask the Government to take heed of this matter of public importance and remove the excessive burden of regulation and taxation from small business and so encourage job growth and investment. Seven hundred thousand small business people out there are ready to go. I ask the Government to get off their backs and give them a chance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to enter this debate today. I just have to say that those opposite cannot be serious. They, who were shown the door by the Business Council of Australia and who were responsible for the leaked industrial relations policy which has been totally neutralised, attempt to purport to represent the interests of business and talk in terms of encouraging investment and job growth. During the debate we have heard nothing so far from those opposite about the levels of non-productive business investment by their mates, the takeover stuff that has millions of dollars floating around in unproductive investment. There is nothing about the fact that in their period of office, from 1975 to 1982, Australia went through a time of record small business failure and bankruptcy.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite do not seem to understand that the heart and soul of small business revolves around growth and successful economic management. Because of the growth and successful economic management that this Government has been able to bring about, best portrayed by the 675,000 new jobs that have been created, small business is profiting. Small business is taking its slice of the record $8.5 billion operating surplus that has been restored to the domestic economy since 1983. No wonder honourable members opposite talk rhetoric and jargon but no substance. I was recalling during the debate that one of the business whizz kids, one of the new members on the other side, in one of his early speeches in this House said:
. . . attention should be drawn to the hyper-regulation of the Australian economy and businesses of various governments and their labyrinthine bureaucracies.

He went on to talk about all these problems and he pointed to the 50,000 new Acts and regulations put into effect by Australian governments over the last 20 years. Well, he was totally correct. During those 20 years of Liberal government regime in Australia, business was subjected to a record labyrinth of regulation and bureaucracy. Why was that so? Every time a business bleated about some sort of need for protection, some sort of need for assistance, what did the government of the day do? It rushed in with some form of protective legislation. Now, over a period of three years this Government has set about a program of deregulation, of opening up our economy to true market forces.

How can Opposition members come in here with motions such as this one and expect to be taken seriously? I remember once hearing the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who moved the motion today, make a constructive suggestion-I think it was about tractor bounties-and it was picked up as an amendment. Since then there has been nothing. As I said to the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) in response to his first speech-he who came in here and preached the need for deregulation-if this Government were to bring further legislation into the House to deregulate the economy, he would oppose it. He is supposed to be the whizz-kid but he would oppose any move to deregulate. That is what we see constantly-opposition for the sake of opposition, based on rhetoric and without substance. As my colleague the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) said when he spoke so eloquently on this matter earlier, the Opposition's approach is one of total obstructionism.

Let us look at the reality of taxes and the tax base. Opposition members should not need to be reminded that not just the majority but in fact the overwhelming majority of the Government's tax base is paid by ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers. In the Budget estimate figures outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last year for this current financial year, $33 billion was to come from personal income tax, with a further $8 billion from excise duties. That represents $41 billion from the ordinary PAYE taxpayer. How much was the anticipated revenue from the company tax that Opposition members are talking about? It was a total of $6 billion out of an estimated $60-odd billion. Not even 10 per cent of the revenue earned by the Government comes from the business sector. So Opposition members should not come in here and bleat about the unfair burden of taxation on business. They should remember that during their period in office they ran down the tax system. They caused it to be unfair. Their Government moved to increase PAYE taxes, petrol taxes, and so on, in order to make up what was not being paid by the corporate sector. They should not forget that.

The honourable member for O'Connor raved on about the fringe benefits tax, and I will say a little more about that in a moment. He is supposed to be the Opposition spokesman for small business. Let us see just how out of touch he is with the group he purports to represent. On the very day the Treasurer introduced the fringe benefits tax legislation into this House, the Australian Financial Review, the newspaper of business, carried the largest number of job advertisements I have ever seen it carry. I went to the trouble of researching them. There were 90 advertisements for senior executive packages. Of those 90, 81 set out a fringe benefits package, including a company car. So on the day the legislation was introduced business was not discouraged. Business was moving on with supplying fringe benefits, despite its rhetoric and raving. Rhetoric and raving is all we ever hear; we never hear anything of substance on these matters.

I want to pick up a comment made by my colleague the honourable member for Stirling on the political strategy. What we have seen unfold in the last two or three weeks is yet another orchestrated campaign of what I describe as emotional junk aimed at talking down the economy and reducing business confidence. In an economy that is delicately placed, particularly in relation to the rest of the world, I regard that emotional junk as obscene and irresponsible. Let me talk a little about the politics of it. The honourable member for Stirling mentioned the timing of these calls. During the lead-up to the last Federal election, Opposition members raced out with a whole lot of emotional junk, scaring the wits out of pensioners. Yes, I concede that it picked up votes. I have no doubt that many elderly people were scared away from this Government. They were not aware that 97 per cent of pensioners would not have their pensions affected. The point now is that all the research shows that they are coming back to support us.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are more frightened now.

—What my colleague the honourable member for Casey, who is interjecting, fails to realise is that pensioners have now had an opportunity to see that that emotional junk has not been substantiated. If I were to give the Opposition some political advice, it would be that its timing is wrong. The reason it is wrong is that it will not scare us into an early election. We will go our full term. In 18 months time, when the fringe benefits tax is in place and has operated for a year, when the capital gains tax is in place and has operated for a year, when the PAYE tax cuts are through and the ordinary workers see the result, they will also see that the farmers do not pay all the money the Opposition has been bleating about for the last three weeks and that business executives have not lost their company cars; the companies will provide them. In other words, the Opposition's timing is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: If Opposition members expect that in the other place the Australian Democrats will hang in there and produce the goods for them, I am afraid that they are wrong. Opposition members will be on their own in limbo-land as pedlars of emotional junk. They are prepared to talk down the economy and to try to reduce business confidence simply for short term political advantage. Opposition members have painted themselves into a very poor corner. That will be reflected in the polls. The Business Council of Australia will again show them the door, as it has done before. It will be reflected in a continuing series of leaked documents because, even from within their own group, there are people who know that it is junk; they want it leaked and discredited before it becomes official policy. I find this motion, this attempt to--

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 by providing income tax deductions of up to 150 per cent of expenditure, other than expenditure on buildings, incurred by eligible companies on research and development performed in Australia. The proposal was announced on 29 May 1985. Complementary legislation, in the form of the Industry Research and Development Bill 1986, provides for grants for research and development to be directed to companies which cannot derive benefits from this proposed income tax concession. Thus, the two schemes represent a package of support measures for research and development in Australian industry.

The specific objectives of the proposed tax concession are: To provide an incentive for greater levels of research and development in Australia; to concentrate new research and development efforts in industry by greater business investment in, and responsibility for, research and development; to provide positive support for research and development activities in industry, on the basis that significant benefits accrue both to industry and to the wider community through enhanced competitiveness of industry; to provide mechanisms for encouraging effective use of Australia's existing research and development expertise; and to encourage a capacity in industry to be aware of, and exploit, technological developments occurring in other countries. These objectives are part of a broader set of objectives which seek to encourage, through the Government's industry and technology policies, the development in Australia of internationally competitive, export oriented, innovative industries.

To be eligible for the income tax concession, a company must be registered with the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board or its replacement, the proposed Industry Research and Development Board. Research and development activities are defined as activities of a systematic, investigative or experimental nature, involving innovation or technical risk undertaken for the purpose of acquiring new knowledge or for creating new or improved materials, products, processes or services.

Comprehensive detail of the kinds of activities which fall within the definition of research and development activities, and of those which are specifically excluded, is provided in the explanatory memorandum being made available to honourable members. Under the provisions of the Bill, where the Commissioner of Taxation requires advice as to whether activities are within the concept of research and development as defined, he may request determination of the matter by the Industry Research and Development Board. The opinion of the Board on the matter is to be binding on the Commissioner.

Except for contributions to the Coal Research Trust Account and expenditure on research and development activities contracted out to an approved research institute, as already defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act, the 150 per cent rate of deduction will be available only where total annual research and development expenditure in the year of income is $50,000 or more. Where annual expenditure is less than $50,000 but more than $20,000, a deduction will be available at a phased-in rate of between 100 per cent and 150 per cent, determined on a formula basis provided in the Bill.

Expenditure on research and development carried out by an approved research institute on behalf of an eligible company will attract the 150 per cent deduction irrespective of the level of that expenditure, as will contributions to the Coal Research Trust Account for the funding of research and development activities on behalf of an eligible company. Research and development expenditure of a current nature is to be allowable as a deduction at a rate of up to 150 per cent in the year incurred. Expenditure on plant and equipment used exclusively for research and development, including up to $10m of expenditure on a unit of pilot plant, is to be deductible at a rate of up to 150 per cent over three years in three equal amounts. Expenditure on buildings or building extensions, alterations or improvements used exclusively for research and development activities is to be deductible at the rate of 100 per cent over three years in three equal amounts.

The Government is concerned that maximum benefits should accrue to Australia from commercialisation of the research and development work subsidised by the proposed concession. Therefore, no concession will be allowed where the Industry Research and Development Board certifies that any commercialisation of the results of research and development activities is otherwise than on normal commercial terms or otherwise than in a manner for the benefit of the Australian economy.

The Bill also contains safeguarding provisions to prevent abuse of the taxation concession. The Bill provides for this taxation concession to operate in respect of expenditure incurred during the period 1 July 1985 to 30 June 1991. It is the Government's intention that there will be a rigorous cost-effectiveness study of the concession, on broadly based criteria, before decisions are made about its continuation beyond 30 June 1991. In addition to the cost-effectiveness review, there will be a technical review of the concession by mid-1987 to allow consideration of any desirable administrative changes.

The cost of the concession depends primarily on the level of research and development investment by companies. For 1986-87, the cost is estimated at approximately $100m. Costs in later years are less certain but may be of the order of $140m in 1987-88, with annual costs, when the scheme is fully effective, of the order of $160m. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is a step in the process of completing the Government's package to promote technology in industry and the Government's industry policy objectives. These objectives are to encourage the development of internationally competitive, export oriented and innovative industries in Australia. Australia needs to build on its innovative skills and research strengths by lifting the level of research and development undertaken by industry, by improving awareness of technology in industry and by forging strong links between industry and researches. It is imperative that industry should develop a technology culture so that it becomes aware of opportunities resulting from research in Australia and overseas.
