Research and development spending by Australian industry is low-0.29 per cent of gross domestic product compared with a median of 0.98 per cent for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development medium research and development performers. The Australian Science and Technology Council in its recent report on public investment in research and development in Australia said that a substantial increase in innovation and performance of industry research and development is necessary. Despite some improvement over recent years, the present level of research and development is just not good enough if Australian industry is to be internationally competitive. The Government is prepared to give generous assistance to Australian industry to become more competitive. It is now up to industry to take up the opportunities the Government has provided.

Research and development leads to the generation of new and improved products which assists industry in opening up new markets, expanding existing markets and becoming more competitive. It also assists development of new or improved production processes which increase productivity and helps make industry more competitive. Most importantly, performance by industry of research and development raises its awareness of technological development and facilitates better choices in the purchase and introduction of technology. Research and development is only one, albeit significant, input to successful innovation and improved industry performance. Other elements of the innovation process, including production, management, finance and marketing expertise, are also fundamental to success. Policies to promote increased research and development in Australia should therefore be seen as an integral part of our broader industry and technology policies.

The key element in the Government's effort to encourage research and development is the market forces based 150 per cent tax concession. The concession has operated since 1 July 1985 and is estimated to cost around $100m in 1986-87. To date the signs are encouraging. Already some 900 companies have indicated that they intend to make use of the tax concession scheme in 1985-86 and 1986-87. Based on data provided by these companies the anticipated increase in real research and development expenditure in 1985-86 will be in excess of 30 per cent. Further increases are expected in 1986-87.

When announcing the tax concession scheme on 29 May last year, Senator Button indicated the Government's awareness that not all firms could benefit from it. For example, the 150 per cent tax concession would not support worthwhile research and development by start-up firms which are important sources of innovation and wealth creation. Such firms need up front cash to support essential research and development projects and, because in their initial years of operation they do not make profits, they are unable to benefit from the tax concession. No profit, no tax. To this end the Government has decided to introduce measures aimed at filling important gaps in research and development assistance. A new scheme, the grants for industry research and development scheme, with the following major elements will be introduced:

Discretionary grants providing a similar level of effective support as the tax concession does for taxable companies, that is, a taxable grant of 50 per cent of eligible expenditure. These grants will have broadly similar form to the project grants of the present Australian industrial research and development incentives scheme.

Generic technology grants to support new or emerging technologies of fundamental significance for industry competitiveness in the 1990s but unlikely to develop if left to the market alone; these grants would fund development of research in collaboration with industry to a stage where industry would take up further development; and
National interest agreements awarded for projects with significant national benefits which would not be undertaken by industry on a commercial basis.

It might be argued that, as the tax concession is available to all companies which have tax liability, all companies without tax liability should be eligible for discretionary grants. However, in the context of limited funding the Government has opted for a selective approach. Only those enterprises which meet certain criteria will be eligible for discretionary grants. Highest priority for grants will be given to newly established firms needing up front cash to carry out their innovation projects. They would be those adjudged competent to perform or have performed the required research and development and to exploit the results commercially. On commercial viability grounds regular loss makers who cannot demonstrate a plan to become profitable should not generally warrant support. In their case research and development support may not be the main problem. However, there will be instances, for example, where a long-established but consistent loss making firm is involved in industry restructuring for which the discretionary grant may be a very effective form of adjustment assistance.

Grants would be payable for a maximum period of three years in respect of any one project. The definition of research and development which qualifies will be similar to that for the 150 per cent tax concession. Grants will be limited to certain areas initially, including manufacturing, mining, construction and computer software and the development of systems and processes in relation to these activities.

New or emerging technologies with the potential to influence significantly industrial development in the 1990s are unlikely to be fully developed if left to the market alone. The market orientated tax concession would therefore not assist research and development in these areas. Risk is high, the development time frame is often very long and sufficient appropriation of the benefits by the researcher is often not possible. Even with the 150 per cent tax concession, it is doubtful whether firms will be able to diversify adequately the risk involved for optimal investment from a community viewpoint. An element of `technology push' is needed to provide the fundamental support. Yet these technologies have application over a range of industries and can strengthen or extend existing comparative advantages. They can be directed at the creation of new markets through development of new products; and they can revitalise existing industry, increasing its productivity through new and improved process technology. For the purposes of the proposed new research and development incentives these areas of technology have been labelled `generic technologies'.

Some examples of such broad-ranging technology areas are biotechnology, microelectronics and advanced materials. Within such areas there could be numerous technologies. For example, priority application areas for the existing national biotechnology program research grants scheme range from plant agriculture, through veterinary, animal husbandry and pharmaceutical-medical products and processes, biotechnology equipment and instrumentation, and food processing to the chemicals industry. From time to time there will also be research and development projects with significant national benefits for which the researcher is unable to capture sufficient benefits to interest entrepreneurs.

Australia's very good record of scientific research is not reflected in the application of science and technology in industry. Support for these generic and national interest areas of technology could be a mechanism for bridging the gap between researchers and commercial interests, for promoting a research and development culture in which both industry and research institutions participate. The benefit of such interaction is two way. Industry becomes aware of the opportunities research and development presents to provide new products or new and improved processes. Research institutions become aware of opportunities to extend their fields of study and to orient their work toward industry.

Biotechnology has already been identified as having potential benefits for a wide range of industries and will be the first generic technology for the purposes of the scheme. The research grants scheme of the national biotechnology program will be incorporated in the generic technology grants element of the new scheme, which will be modelled on the biotechnology scheme. Other generic technologies, such as advanced materials, may be declared eligible for assistance under the scheme in future.

The GIRD scheme will be administered by the Industry Research and Development Board with responsibility to select projects for support according to guidelines determined by the Minister. The Board will be assisted by committees with expertise in specific areas and supported by a secretariat. Firms wishing to take advantage of the 150 per cent tax concession will register with the Board. The GIRD scheme will operate for five years from 1 July 1986 until the tax concession scheme expires. GIRD and the tax concession scheme will be reviewed at the same time.

Sunset provisions in the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976 mean that no further commencement grants funded under that Act will be made after 30 June 1986. A report by the consultants, Price Waterhouse, has indicated that this element of the previous Australian industrial research and development incentives scheme-AIRDIS-had not been very effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor will GIRD be.
—We will wait and see.
—All you are doing is replacing one thing that is not working with another. That is silly.
—The honourable member is not listening to what we are saying. We have taken into account the Price Waterhouse recommendation and also the report of the AIRDIS Board itself.
—Does Price Waterhouse recommend the establishment of GIRD?
—The honourable member will have an opportunity to put his point of view if he is on the speakers list when the debate comes on.
—And if it is not guillotined.
—That is very unlikely.

SPEECH.PARA: After 30 June, the project grants funded under that scheme would be replaced by the discretionary grants under the new scheme and public interest projects would be replaced by national interest agreements. Commencement grants for eligible research and development expenditure incurred before 1 July 1986 will continue to be paid in accordance with the provisions in the present Act. Project grant agreements entered into prior to 1 July 1986 will be honoured. This will also be the case with public interest projects. With the grants for industry research and development scheme and the 150 per cent taxation concession I believe the Government has got its price subsidy support for industry research and development about right. Some smaller changes may still be required and, of course, we will monitor and, as need be, adjust our policy strategies.

Together, the two schemes will help significantly improve the overall climate for research and development in industry, contributing to the development of more innovative and internationally competitive and export oriented industries in Australia. With other initiatives such as the National Industry Extension Service and revised offsets arrangements they are an integral part of the Government's strategy to make technology work for Australia. There are encouraging signs that the 150 per cent taxation concession has already had a positive impact on industry attitudes to research and development. I am confident that the two schemes will lead to a significant increase in the private sector's commitment to research and development and to the development of a technology culture in Australian industry.
Financial Impact Statement

The cost of the new scheme contained in this Bill in 1986-87 would be $12.5m. In addition, existing forward obligation for AIRDIS would have to be met-$45.2m in 1986-87. The present cost of AIRDIS and the biotechnology grants scheme is about $70m annually. Savings will, therefore, be around $12m in 1986-87.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are cutting the grants down-$70m versus $12.5m. What will it be in 1987-88?

—Broken Hill Pro- prietary Co. Ltd, which is notoriously a profit maker, was able to apply for AIRDIS grants, but under this Bill it would get its research and development money directly from the tax concession. The GIRD scheme is aimed at companies still in a developmental phase. Because they are not into profit there is no point in giving them a tax concession because the tax concession will give them nothing in the circumstances.
—Okay; what will the two figures be in 1987-88?

—The debate will be longer than just this exchange, scintillating though it is. The main form of assistance for research and development in industry will be the 150 per cent tax concession. On the basis of registrations received, this is estimated to cost around $100m in regard to income tax returns for 1985-86. It is not possible to estimate the 1986-87 cost of that measure until registrations are received, and a more precise cost will not be known for 1986-87 until tax claims for that year are made in 1987-88.

SPEECH.PARA: Applicants will be already entitled to the tax concession for what they have done since 1 July last year, but, of course, it is not reflected in the 1985-86 Budget. It will not be until the 1986-87 Budget that we will see any revenue impact. I commend the Bill to the House and I formally present the revised explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Blunt) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: IMPROVEMENT OF INTERNATIONAL TERMINAL FACILITIES, SYDNEY (KINGSFORD-SMITH) AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Improvement of International terminal facilities, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

The proposal reported on by the Public Works Committee involves improvements to various functional areas of the departures, arrivals and basement levels of the international terminal building at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. This will facilitate the movement of passengers and overcome present bottlenecks and other deficiencies. The work will extend and upgrade the arrivals and departure levels, including changes to passenger processing, baggage reclaim, concession and public areas. A new transit lounge will be built and new and increased capacity baggage conveyors provided along with two additional aerobridges.

Honourable members will be aware that the existing terminal was designed and built in the days of narrow-bodied jets and it is now unable to cope satisfactorily with the larger passenger loads from today's wide-bodied jets. Since the building was opened in 1970, no major development work has been undertaken to the building to increase its original handling capacity of 1,000 passengers departing and 1,000 arriving per hour.

The Public Works Committee agreed in its report to Parliament that improvements are required to the terminal to cater for increased passenger numbers during daily peak periods. But it did not endorse the solution put forward by the Government. Instead, the Committee recommended that planning for the provision of a new or substantially expanded terminal building should commence immediately. Preliminary studies by my Department indicate that a new terminal building would cost about $75m.

TALK.START.PARA: —You need another department.

—You will get your chance in a moment, Julian. Support facilities such as an apron for aircraft parking, taxiway and carparks would increase this to about $110m, with a lead time of five to seven years. Given this time lag, the Government cannot agree to the Committee's recommendation that improvements to the existing terminal not proceed. To go along with the recommendation would place intolerable demands on the existing facilities and staff for a further five years, and it would greatly inconvenience future passengers using the airport. The improvement measures proposed will increase terminal capacity by about 80 per cent and enable it to handle per hour approximately 1,800 terminating passengers, 1,600 originating passengers and 600 passengers in transit. The Department of Aviation's projections of future traffic growth indicate this should enable the facility to be operated efficiently without undue congestion until about 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Conditions in the terminal will be progressively improved as the proposed works proceed and as key functional areas are expanded and upgraded. This will be done in close consultation with users to minimise inconvenience to passengers and staff. The Government does not believe that action to alleviate intolerable conditions in the terminal can be deferred until a new facility is designed and constructed. I therefore recommend that it is expedient to proceed with the works as proposed by the Government.

My colleague the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) will speak to the motion and will provide additional detail to the House in due course this afternoon. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning can proceed and work on the improvement program can commence without delay early in the new financial year. Construction is expected to take a maximum of three years. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some regret that the Parliamentary Public Works Committee learns of the Government's decision to put aside the recommendations that the Committee, in pursuit of its function and charter from the House, put before the House. I hasten to say that the Committee has never considered itself other than totally subordinate to the will of the Parliament or, in more practical terms, to the Government, but it does take quite seriously its responsibility to address references from the House, as it did in the case of the Sydney International Airport terminal building alterations. Indeed, there is some 300 pages of transcript of evidence and submissions which invited the Committee's serious address. It is rather significant that Committee members, on considering all the matters appertaining to this referral, were unanimous in the Committee's conclusion, and, indeed, in proceeding towards that conclusion there was not a point on which there was any significant demur, if any demur at all. It may be fairly inquired as to whether or not the Committee has a function to present to the Parliament recommendations that are in accord with the ambitions of the government of the day, of whichever party it may be. If that, in fact, is not to be the case, the Committee would be fully entitled to readdress itself to the functions with which it has been charged.

SPEECH.PARA: I must admit, also, some slight irony in the fact that, within my recollection, two recommendations from the Committee to the House which were rejected both had to do with airport terminal buildings-this one in Sydney and one in Townsville. That seems to suggest that somehow or other there is a death wish on airport terminal buildings. As I say, the Committee has no axe to grind in these matters. As it customarily acts, it approached this matter with a thoroughly open mind and judged it on the facts. It is rather significant that the Committee was influenced, naturally enough, in the main by the submissions of the Department of Aviation, which was virtually carrying the proposal.

I remind the House that the Committee recommended to Parliament that steps be taken immediately to plan for a new, substantially expanded terminal building. The Department of Aviation submission stated:

One alternative which did receive active consideration was the provision of a new building adjacent to the existing terminal in which the processing of all terminating passengers would be conducted. This concept offered many advantages and met with the support of a number of the terminal user organisations, but in view of its high estimated cost, $15m to $19.8m, it was withdrawn from further consideration. It should be noted that works in the order of $14m to cater for departing and transiting passengers would still have been necessary as part of this option.

So, on the evidence presented to the Committee there was a case, on Department of Aviation evidence, that a substantially expanded terminal could be completed for $29m to $32m. The same evidence indicated clearly to the Committee that the Department of Aviation was not planning alterations to the terminal in a manner consistent with what it saw as necessary or desirable. The Department started off from the wrong end, with a strict financial restriction. It had $20m to spend, so it had to tailor this project to be accommodated by that amount. As a consequence we had a number of the aberrations which dissuaded the Committee from supporting the proposal. We are looking at $20m now to produce a result which, on evidence submitted to the Committee, at the end of three years would still be as inefficient as the existing terminal building. Perhaps I should re-phrase that: The congestion three years hence, at the completion of these intrusive alterations on the existing terminal, would be as bad as, if not worse than, it presently is. That seemed an extraordinary exercise in in-built redundancy when, on evidence produced by the Department, a new terminal could be built for some $10m or $12m extra.

As the Sydney Airport, again on evidence, is going to be functional for at least another 20 years it seemed to be a sound investment to get on immediately with a project that Sydney not only requires but is entitled to, as Australia's major international airport. The problem simply was that we had a far from attractive, inadequate option constrained by a sum of money which had been allocated for the purpose. I guess that, in analogous terms, the Department of Aviation was confronted with a situation where it had to build a structure and had the option of having two rooms with a roof or four rooms without a roof, and it decided to take the roof for the lesser amount. To the Committee that seemed to be an extraordinary way of going about spending money.

It must be realised, as well you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, being a member of the Committee yourself, that the Committee is charged to consider and report on a public work, having regard to, first, the stated purpose of the work and its suitability for the purpose; secondly, the necessity for or the advisability of carrying out the work; and thirdly, the most effective use that can be made in carrying out the work of the money to be expended on the work. The Committee's recommendation was not intended to frustrate the ambitions of the Department of Aviation, or of the Government for that matter. It was to give the Department an endorsement to proceed immediately with a project that would meet the requirements not only at the end of three years but also continuing into the future. It is significant that, in the main, the witnesses were substantially lukewarm in their response to the proposal. They accepted that something had to be done, but saw the proposal as being less than what was desired. The Federated Clerks Union was quite insistent that if its members fully manned the service desks for inward passengers the problem could be substantially relieved, even to the point of removing the problem altogether.

The Committee further suggested that a relaxation of the curfew by one hour could help in removing that significant peak period of aircraft arrivals from 7 a.m. through to 8.30 a.m. It is significant that on the example given to the Committee of a typically busy day at that airport, the first aircraft arrived at 5.50 a.m.-I do not quite know how it sneaked in before the curfew but we will allow that there was some circumstance to warrant that-and the next aircraft did not arrive until 7.20 a.m. Then they were bunched, with two 747s actually arriving on the same minute. That raises an interesting question as to runway congestion, but the table showed that the two arrived simultaneously. So a relaxation of the curfew would allow international flights to factor their arrivals. There is some difficulty attaching to scheduling arrival at 6.01 a.m. because of the imponderables in flight-head winds, tail winds, and all the other imponderables that could require aircraft to orbit in the vicinity waiting for the clock to tick over. The suggestion that the curfew be relaxed does not necessarily mean aircraft would be arriving at 5 a.m.; it could mean aircraft arriving at 6.30 a.m. or 7 a.m. They were two positive suggestions from the Committee as to how the stress situation presently prevailing might be relieved to give time to the Department to get ahead with this proposal to build a substantially expanded terminal.

By and large, the Committee was thoroughly satisfied that this was not an effective use of public money. It did not meet the identifiable requirement, and it left the Sydney Airport terminal building in a continuing state of redundancy and, indeed, was even building redundancy into it. It was put that the Federal Airports Corporation on the horizon brought in another factor, that decisions might be deferred to allow the Corporation, which will have responsibility for terminals, to make a decision more consistent with its own thoughts, planning and ambitions. I am not unattracted to that proposition; but to spend $20m in the meantime just to bridge a gap before the Corporation gets to a position of making these substantial decisions seemed to be an injudicious expenditure of public money.

The Committee was not discouraged by the differential in costs between the present project and an expanded project, having in mind the size of the Budget and the sums of money we can find for any number of other government activities or public activities. It firmly adhered to the view that Sydney and Australia would be best served by adopting the Committee's recommendations and proceeding immediately to planning a greatly expanded terminal building, a new project. All I can say, with due respect to the Minister's comments about the time lag in getting these facilities into operation, is that if that time is essential for planning and construction, God help Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my comments about this terminal project by endorsing emphatically all the remarks made by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar). I am appalled at the arrogant and authoritarian manner displayed by the now thoroughly discredited Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) as he attempts to bulldoze through Parliament his plan for a $20m extension to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. By unanimous decision the Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, in a report tabled in the Parliament recently, recommended that the proposed work should not proceed-I repeat, not proceed. The proposal referred to the Committee was inadequate in many respects, and I will touch on some of those areas today. The work proposed was within the existing terminal building complex and included extensions to and upgrading of the arrival and departure levels, including check-in, passenger processing, concession and baggage reclaim areas, provision of a new transit lounge, upgrading of baggage conveyor facilities, and provision of two additional aerobridges.

SPEECH.PARA: Submissions, evidence and plans were received from the Department of Aviation and the Department of Housing and Construction. Additional submissions were received from Qantas Airways Ltd, the Australian Customs Service, the Airline Operators Committee, the Federated Clerks' Union of Australia, Trans Australia Airlines and Inboard Tour Operators of Australia. Communications were also received from the municipalities of Rockdale, Botany and the Sydney City Council.

All in all, the Committee deliberations were extensive, thoroughly professional and in considerable depth. We tried, apparently unsuccessfully, to alert aviation bodies and the Parliament to a growing problem of significance and concern. We tried to sound the alarm to an unresponsive and unreceptive Government. The situation at Australia's leading airport was in jeopardy, and it was apparent that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) was either ignoring or refusing to accept the fiasco that existed.

As a Committee, we decided unanimously that increasing congestion would worsen after completion of the proposed renovations and a completely untenable situation would prevail during the 36 months' construction period. An urgent requirement exists for a completely new terminal building and a new and parallel extension to the airstrip. This, combined with some modifications to existing curfew times, would eliminate the problem for the foreseeable future. As a great majority of aircraft using Mascot terminal these days are late model, high technology aeroplanes with extremely quiet engines, the emotional problem of aircraft noise pollution is considerably smaller, in factual terms, than it was several years ago. Unless urgent action is taken quickly to overcome deficiencies outlined in the Committee's report, the entire tourist potential of the nation will be threatened. Mascot is, and will continue to be, Australia's busiest airport. International travellers, who are increasingly sophisticated in their expectations and tastes, demand adequate and excellent facilities provided with the minimum of personal disruption.

I assure the Minister that the Committee has not been negligent and has met its responsibilities totally in preparation of its report. We met time commitments, expended our and the Secretariat's valuable resources to prepare a detailed and comprehensive series of recommendations, only to have this advice ignored and now, in the light of these recommendations, the Minister intends to oversight the waste of at least $20m of taxpayers' money. It is a pity that this Minister and this Government are so good at ignoring the wishes of the Parliament and its own members. The report looks as though it will now go the same way as the report on the Australia Card, with democracy the principal sufferer. For the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) to press-gang an unwanted and totally inadequate proposal through this place today, in the light of the persuasive and thoroughly well-documented report tabled previously, is a disgrace. The Minister stands condemned by this member of the Committee, whose report, as I mentioned previously, was unanimous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) in their remarks on the tabling of the report of the Public Works Committee hearing that is now before the House. The Public Works Committee in its deliberations on the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport extensions has acted precisely as the Parliament intended it to act. It has acted in the role of watchdog. It has acted in an effort to be good stewards of what are public resources. It is something of an offence to the Committee to hear the Minister so abruptly and arrogantly overturn the Committee's unanimous-I repeat unanimous-recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that I do not stand here, nor I believe do the honourable member for Wide Bay and the honourable member for Casey, making comments in any partisan sense. Our remarks were endorsed unanimously by the Committee. Furthermore, it is somewhat unfortunate that the remarks come solely from this side of the House, but that has eventuated from something that was entirely beyond our control in that the hearing was heard by a large majority of Opposition members. That is no reflection on the Government members who were simply unable to be present, though a quorum had been formed.

We have an exercise before the House where, if the Opposition parties were choosing to be partisan, they would be allowing the proposal to go ahead without debate. If it were our intention to embarrass the Government, we would be allowing the Government unwisely to spend $20m. It is in fact in an effort not to embarrass the Government that we are putting what has been the unanimous view of a bipartisan Committee to the House this afternoon. I stress that we recognise that we are called upon to be wise stewards of what is a finite resource and we are concerned at the expenditure unwisely of this $20m.

What is proposed by the Minister will be in itself disruptive of the tourist traffic that currently goes through Kingsford-Smith Airport. Far from solving the present congestion, the very action of construction will in itself create congestion. Worse than that, the tourist flow will be throttled in some way and congestion will be created with an end result that will be no better, or little better, than the existing facility. It is a matter of real concern to all members of the Public Works Committee that this work should be proposed to go ahead when the end result will not allow traffic flow, tourist flow or passenger flow that will be a great deal better than the flow that currently exists.

The Minister has said: `It is expedient to go ahead with this work'. I challenge that statement. The only thing expedient about going ahead with the work now before the House is political expediency. In fact, what he is proposing neither extends nor upgrades substantially the existing facility. Because the extension is not as extensive as we would like it to be, and because the upgrading will not effectively allow a better traffic flow, we believe that work should not proceed.

The Minister said that the Committee failed to endorse a solution. I put it to the Minister: What sort of solution is the solution before the House which does not allow better traffic flow or better passenger flow through the already congested Kingsford-Smith Airport? I state to this Government, so proud of its tourist record, that what it proposes to do at Kingsford-Smith will only further tarnish the impression that new arrivals will have of Australia as the work going ahead will in itself provide congestion to people who will try to move through the reception halls.

TALK.START.PARA: —Up to three hours.

—As my colleague interjects, up to three hours. We believe, as the honourable member for Wide Bay has documented, that a great deal could be achieved by looking realistically in the short term at the present curfew provisions and allowing aircraft to arrive a little earlier and so relieve some of this congestion. Of course such a move is not popular, but it would be good stewardship of the taxpayers' resources, and that is the motivation behind the Committee. That is the sole motivation behind those of us who stand here on the Opposition benches asking the Government to look again at this ministerial recommendation. It is the sole motivation not of those of us on the Opposition benches alone, but of the other members of the Committee who were unanimous in their support for the Committee's recommendation that this work not go ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to an analogy that I have used in this House before. Since 1913, the Committee has been asked to be a watchdog of the resources spent on public works in Australia. It cannot be, if honourable members will pardon me for saying so, a chihuahua. It is both too substantial and too prestigious for that role. The Committee, in making its recommendation, chooses to be a loyal but an aggressive dobermann pinscher. If the recommendation is to be overthrown as the Minister suggests, and if the Minister's approval is to be placed on this project after the Committee has said it cannot go ahead, the Committee's role of watchdog will be lost and the Committee will become nothing more than a faithful but ineffectual spayed labrador.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making available to me and my colleagues, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), details of the motion that he has just moved. The motion moved by the Minister says in its fourth paragraph that the existing terminal was designed and built in the days of narrow-bodied jets. I do not know who has written this speech for him, because paragraph 17 of the report by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Changes were made in a late stage of development to accommodate wide-body aircraft . . .
He also said that his Department had estimated that a new building at the terminal would cost $110m and that the lead time would be five to seven years. Paragraph 97 of the report states, in part:
Department of Housing and Construction advised that a new terminal could be constructed in three to four years.

I do not know what is going on in the Department of Housing and Construction, but something funny is. It is very interesting that in the observations that the Minister has made on the draft discussion paper of the Opposition's policy on housing and construction he has never once referred to the fact that we think there is an extraordinary duplication of activities going on between that Department and other departments.

The Opposition is deeply concerned that the Minister for Housing and Construction proposes to ignore the recommendations of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works contained in the report relating to the improvement of the international terminal facilities at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I remind the House that there are five government members on that Committee out of a total of nine members; therefore, the Government has the numbers, so to speak, on the Committee. It seems incredible to the Opposition that the Government can, in effect, ignore or overrule the findings of five of its own members in relation to this matter. Presumably, those Government members on the Committee are unhappy with what the Minister for Housing and Construction has decided to do. The Opposition intends to vote against this motion and I call on the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Keogh), the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), all of whom are Government members on the Committee, to join the Opposition in voting against this motion.

I would particularly like to see the honourable member for Aston, who was my predecessor as member for Deakin, join the Opposition in this vote and demonstrate the proud standards of those who have represented the seat of Deakin, named for Australia's second Prime Minister. The Opposition recognises that there is an overwhelming need for something to be done about the international airline facilities at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The Committee recognised this quite clearly in its report and in paragraphs 56 and 57 drew attention to the current situation, which it describes as `lamentable' and `only bearable for the shorter term'. On the question of need, the Committee's conclusion was:

Improvements are required to passenger processing and baggage facilities and public areas in the international terminal at Sydney's (Kingsford-Smith) airport to cater for increased passenger numbers during daily peak periods.

Anybody who has come home to Australia after being abroad, or anyone who has spoken to another person who has come home to Australia after being abroad, is acutely aware of the need for something to be done about Sydney's international Airport. Arriving there after long periods on an aeroplane, frequently having had little sleep, is very aggravating, to say the least. One has to stand in queues for hours and wait at the baggage carousel as it goes round and round and round without disgorging one's luggage.

The Opposition congratulates the Committee for giving such prompt attention to this matter. Our quarrel with the Government is not that we do not acknowledge that there is a need for something to be done at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; rather, it is that the Government's proposals will not resolve the problem. It is almost as if the Minister for Housing and Construction has not even discussed this matter with his colleague the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris). There was hardly an informed person who came before the Committee-the Committee interviewed 19 witnesses-who did not confirm the Committee's view as expressed in paragraph 70, as follows:
. . . the proposed work will not alleviate congestion to a significant extent.

The Committee pointed out that the proposed work would simply cause disruption in other areas; that it was doubtful that the completion date could be achieved; and that the lack of capacity to process passengers and baggage would cause disruption to terminal operations and would compound capacity problems even further. In addition, the Committee found that the proposed removal of the interline conveyor to the arrival hall from the Customs hall would cause further inconvenience to passengers and add to congestion problems in the arrival hall.

Not only is it apparent that the Minister for Housing and Construction has not talked to the Minister for Aviation; it is clear that he has not even talked to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). Why did he not ask that Minister about the possibility of tourist traffic in Australia increasing sharply over the next few years? He has not listened to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, who, in response to a number of dorothy dixers in Question Time over the past year or more, has repeatedly blown his own trumpet and talked up the possibility of sharply increased tourist trade in this country. It is hardly necessary to add that, with terrorism causing a tourist decrease in Europe and with the sharp reduction in the value of the Australian dollar, there is very likely to be an increase in tourism in Australia. It is a shame that this will occur because of the fall in our dollar; the change in our exchange rate is directly attributable to the Government's poor economic policies, which have relied far too heavily on monetary policy to the exclusion of fiscal and wages policies. Its monetary policy has already caused a depression in this country, as the national accounts figures released last week have shown. Thus confidence in the value of our currency has declined and with it the value of the dollar. It is ironic that the difficulty at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport would not be as it is if this Government had not mismanaged our economy. Eventually, this mismanagement will hurt people from all walks of life, but it will particularly hurt the disadvantaged in our community who can only prosper in a well-managed economy.

Why did the Minister for Housing and Construction not discuss this whole question of tourism with the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism? Did he find out from that Minister that the number of tourists in Australia is expected to rise from 1.2 million in 1985 to around 2 million in 1988, an average annual increase of close to 20 per cent? Did he establish with that Minister that 99 per cent of tourists coming to Australia arrive by air? Did he confirm with that Minister that 57 per cent of those tourists come through Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport? Did he ask that Minister to reconcile his figures showing an increase of about 20 per cent with the figures from the Australian Tourist Commission showing that annual passenger numbers will increase by 7 to 9 per cent up to 1988? Did he ask the Minister for Aviation why that Minister's Department forecast an increase of only 1.5 to 3.4 per cent? It is almost as if the Minister for Housing and Construction, who sits mute at the table, is operating in a complete vacuum in relation to this whole matter. He does not seem to have questioned any of the numbers coming from various sources, or to have instructed his Department to attempt to reconcile these figures. This is a case of gross mismanagement by the Minister. One need only turn to paragraph 84 of the Committee's report to confirm this. It states, in part:
. . . it is clear that the terminal will remain severely congested in 1989 when the proposed works are completed.
We are entitled to a further explanation from the Minister for Housing and Construction about that matter. In paragraph 93 of its report the Committee says, in part:

Despite the assurances given by Department of Housing and Construction about steps to be taken to minimise disruptions to terminal operations while the works are carried out, the Committee believes that the magnitude of work involved which will take three years to complete, will cause severe disruptions.

What is going on here? Surely the Minister, when he read that paragraph, would have said to his Department: `Why were the assurances that you gave the Committee not satisfactory? How could it be that you could not satisfy the Committee that the necessary engineering and construction activities could be carried out in such a way as to minimise congestion?' I suggest to the Minister that if his Department is unable to satisfy a committee of the Parliament on a matter such as this he should have a close look at why not.

The Minister has a great deal to answer for in the whole question of the improvement of the international terminal facilities at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Not only will the proposed work not resolve the difficulties at the airport but there will clearly be a waste of money. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are running around, clucking like chooks, about the proposed $1.4 billion of expenditure reductions that are needed for the Budget this year. Fancy the Government allowing the $20m proposed to be spent on this project to be thrown away. It is clear that the Minister for Housing and Construction has not spoken to those colleagues either. It looks as though the Minister does not speak to anybody in the Cabinet, presumably because he is too busy trying to keep his own faction together.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is his preselection going?

—There was a deal. This project is a waste of taxpayers' money. In paragraph 92 of the report the Committee said that it did not believe that the proposed work would be the most effective use of taxpayers' money. Paragraph 95 of the report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Even if the proposed work were to proceed, the lengthy construction period and increased demands will largely negate the value of the proposed investment.

This whole project is shown to be a shocking waste of taxpayers' money and the Minister should be roundly condemned for associating himself with this motion. Furthermore, the Committee, in a most constructive fashion, has drawn attention to a number of things that could be done to alleviate the difficulties experienced at Sydney Airport now. It draws attention to the possibility that additional staffing could be of help and suggests that certain proposals on staffing should be implemented. The Committee also propose changes in the curfew to assist the flow of passengers. In its balanced report the Committee concludes that resolution of the difficulties at Sydney Airport could be achieved only by the construction of a substantially expanded terminal which could, ironically, be constructed, according to the Department of Housing and Construction, in the same time period as the Minister's current proposals would take.

The action of the Minister in seeking to overrule the unanimous conclusions of a parliamentary committee is an arrogant way of by-passing parliamentary procedures. What is the point of having the Committee review these projects if the Government overrules the Committee when its conclusions do not agree with those of the Government? The Opposition may or may not have views about the Committee's activities but the fact of the matter is that the Government is ignoring the Committee's recommendation. Furthermore, in announcing that the Government planned to go ahead with the proposed improvements, as the Minister did last week, before this matter came before the Parliament, the Minister for Aviation is treating the Committee and the Parliament with absolute contempt.

The Opposition is appalled at the way in which the Minister for Housing and Construction is ignoring the recommendations of the Committee on the improvement of the terminal facilities at Sydney's international airport. Although we recognise there is a definite need for changes to be made, what is being proposed by the Minister will not resolve the problems at the airport and will be an absolute waste of taxpayers' money. The Opposition is shocked with this motion and calls on the Minister to withdraw it forthwith. If he does not do so we will vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to participate in this debate for a few moments. I take one point on which I disagree with the recommendations of the Joint Committee on Public Works, namely, its recommendation in paragraph 98 (5) (b) that the curfew at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport should be reduced by one hour in the mornings. I see smiles from certain honourable members in the House. Let us get the smiles right off their faces. When the report was released I made the comment, and I make it again, that the recommendation that the curfew should be lifted was made by nine members none of whom had an airport problem or lived near the Sydney Airport. The solution to complications and crowding at Sydney Airport will not be met by reducing the curfew hour from 6 a.m. to 5 a.m. I am appalled to think that no one has raised this matter in this debate or at another time in this House. I have raised it in public and in the local press in Sydney and had support along these lines.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer to this problem is that the airlines-I know that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) is sympathetic to this position-should be asked to change their timetables of flights into Australia and into Sydney. The glib answer by the Committee that we merely say that planes can arrive at 5 a.m. is a total nonsense and bears no relationship to the problems facing those people who live in the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen)-Kingsford-Smith-or the electorates of St George, Barton or Cook. In case some people who live a little further away from Botany Bay become a little smug about this matter let me remind them that the people who live in Drummoyne and on the North Shore will not be amused when wide-bodied jets to which my friend the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) referred change gear when they come in to land.

If aeroplanes arrive at 5 a.m. that means that they will be circling Sydney at 4.30 a.m. This is an absolute and total nonsense. It happens now before 6 a.m. I am delighted to see that my neighbour across the water, the Deputy Prime Minister, is in the chamber and is nodding his approval of the need for the curfew to remain at 6 a.m. I take issue with this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —The local boy talking.

—One of my colleagues has said that this is the local boy talking and how right he is. I have been representing people for 20 years and I am concerned about the curfew irrespective of which party occupies the government benches. I am appalled to think that consideration has not been given to talking to local members with regard to the lifting of the curfew. I share my colleagues' distress that a report of such strength should be ignored by the Government. I find that a distressing situation and I would like to put this on record: Under no circumstances while I remain a member of this House-I have been a member more or less since 1966-will I ever vote for any suggestion or accept any suggestion, no matter which party is in Government, that the airport curfew should be moved from 6 a.m. to 5 a.m.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that the shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), is in the chamber. What tourists want to arrive in a city at 5 a.m.? What do they think they will see? Arriving in Melbourne now at 5 a.m. and 5.15 a.m. on an international jet does nothing to improve tourism or to improve people's thoughts about Australia. I ask honourable members-as I look around the chamber I see most honourable members have done a fair bit of international travelling-how often they have arrived at an airport before 6 a.m. on a regular flight. Practically never. The point I am making is that this is a nonsense recommendation by the Committee and I want it stated clearly not only for my own sake but also for the sake of everybody who lives in the Botany Bay area of Sydney. To those who live further afield I point out that they too will have problems if the curfew is lifted.

A suggestion has been made by one member who lives in the Botany Bay area that the curfew should be moved from 6 a.m. to 5.30 a.m. That was sneaky: It was even more sneaky when one realises that the planes would fly only over the electorate of Cook. This is hardly the mood of bipartisanship we would want on this issue in our part of Sydney. With some distress I stand to say-I feel it should go into the parliamentary record-that people should be talking about the concern of the people who live near these airports.

As I have another one or two minutes, I will just say that when we talk of breaking the curfew at airports-and all honourable members should be aware of this-we are talking not of passengers but of freight. If honourable members think that lumbering jets thundering into airports at two, three, four or five o'clock in the morning will be bringing passengers they are mistaken; those planes are bringing in freight. Let us not hear nonsense about tourism being improved by freight arriving at 5 a.m. instead of 6 a.m.

I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the opportunity to say these few gentle words, which do not totally support the recommendations by this multi-party parliamentary committee. I heard the honourable member for Deakin say that perhaps the Minister had not spoken to other people in his Government. I recommend to members of the Public Works Committee that next time they come to the Botany Bay area they consider-just consider-talking to local members of all parties who are affected by such statements in a parliamentary document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene in this debate now because I understand that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) will intervene at the conclusion of my few words, and if I waited until he had spoken I would not have the opportunity because the gag will then be moved. That is not my idea of cricket, but if that is the Government's idea one has to get in when one can. I will be very interested to hear what the Minister has to say because unless he can come up with some good information and something far better than what the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) is recommending by proceeding with this very-ill conceived-and now proven to be ill-conceived-proposal for a $20m upgrading, which actually increases congestion both during the construction period and at the conclusion rather than alleviating the problem, the Minister for Aviation will have to go back to his colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction, and they will have to go back to square one and start again. Otherwise the tourist image of Australia and the users of the international terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport will be the losers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister should come up with something new and positive. I was about to say that unless he does so, the Government has its head in the sand, but perhaps it might be more appropriate to say that if he cannot do so it is flying blind. It has not even acknowledged that there is a problem. Everybody else in the industry and every member of the Joint Committee on Public Works who investigated this proposal stated that not only is there a problem but that problem is becoming a crisis. The Government does not even acknowledge the first point, that there is a problem, and therefore is doing nothing to overcome a crisis that is developing. It is a crisis of congestion with aircraft movements at certain times of the day and the associated movement of people through the terminal. The problem is quite complex and multiple, but there are answers which have been recommended for some time by people in industry, people in departments and by the Committee, as we have discovered today.

What has happened with the Government's response to all this very carefully considered advice on how to overcome this growing problem? First is the problem of increasing congestion. The Government's first action was to say that as from the end of September departure tax booths at Kingsford-Smith Airport-and for that matter at the other terminals, but we are just talking of Kingsford-Smith-will be closed. That will increase congestion. Everyone in the airline industry has advised the Minister of that for months and has pleaded with him for those booths to remain open permanently. Secondly, the Government has rejected the advice of the Parliamentary Public Works Committee. Rejection by that Committee, which the Government has rejected, is a reasonably rare occurrence in this place. Therefore, it should have been treated far more seriously than it has. As others have said, that Committee made the point not only that at the conclusion of spending $20m congestion will be worse but also that congestion will be worse during the three-year renovation period and will be worse again because of the new departure tax requirements.

The third point concerning the overcoming of these problems and the Government's reaction is that it has rejected the proposals made by the industry and the Department over the years to develop a parallel runway, to get in ahead and beat the growing congestion problem of airways movements. The next point is that the Government has done nothing to accept the advice of the Aviation Industry Advisory Council or the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise which reported in September 1985, some 10 months ago, on ways of alleviating some of that congestion of aircraft movements not, as the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) said, by completely altering curfew arrangements, but by sensibly looking at types of aircraft, runways and so on to alleviate the problem.

The Government probably will say that a Federal Airports Corporation is about to come into existence and so we should not interfere with any longer term planning and solutions for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The Minister should tell us the latest timing for the establishment and, more importantly, the effective working of the Federal Airports Corporation. It appears to me that it will be some years before that Corporation is really effective. If one waits for the Corporation to be effective and then makes plans, there will be an even longer delay period, far longer than the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) talked about when discussing a sensible alternative of a separate terminal. It is not only Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport that is apparently suffering from the paralysis of the Department. How long have the people of Darwin been waiting for the revised airport terminal? They have been waiting for over 18 months-some six months after the time that was given by the Minister originally by which they would have a revised proposal. They are still waiting and will be waiting several more months.

What is needed? The points have been well made by the Committee and by people in industry. There should be either a far more substantially upgrading, or preferably, a separate terminal which will not create any more congestion in the existing terminal during its construction and will be there not only in the short term but as a long term remedy to this growing problem. I have been advised that offers have been made by the private sector to pay for that terminal. I know by the number of phone calls I have received that other private investors are interested in putting up the money for a new separate terminal. If that were the decision of the Government, one would applaud it. There would be no disruption during the construction period. It would serve both the short and long term interests, and if the Government wanted to accept a private company proposal there would be no cost to the taxpayer.

The answers on runways and varying arrangements, whether by altering the curfew by one hour in the morning, as the Committee suggested or the more flexible arrangement that the Aviation Industry Advisory Council and the House of Representatives Committee have recommended, are there for the Government to act on, if it has the sense to do so. If it does not, as the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the shadow Minister for Tourism and the members of the Committee who have spoken today have already indicated, the loser will be the image of Australia. Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is our major international gateway. Tourists come through it and depart from it. The image of Australia internationally rests very much with that first impression of Australia through that international gateway. Unless the two Ministers present, and behind them the Government, alter the very negative and, I think, stupid intention to proceed-I am quite happy to apologise for the word `stupid' if the Minister for Aviation has some other proposal-it will very much be to the detriment of the future of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the House and I will take only a couple of minutes. I thank the Minister for Aviation (Mr Morris) for making time available. I just want to add my voice, as the shadow Minister for tourism, to the discussion on the importance of improving the facilities at the international terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in Sydney. I visited it a few weeks ago. Those of us involved in air travel, tourism or aviation know of the real problems at Kingsford-Smith Airport international terminal. It is becoming notorious throughout the tourist industry for its congestion, particularly at peak periods.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government quite rightly takes some credit for the increase in tourism in this country. It is our only growth industry, and it is our biggest employer. With the current economic problems in this banana republic, as it was described by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), it is inconceivable that we are not doing everything we possibly can to increase the flow of tourists into this country. Yet our main international airport at Sydney is full to the brim. People have to queue for hours at peak periods-sometimes three to four hours-to get through the Customs, health and immigration checks. That is a great reception for tourists on their arrival in this country. It is imperative that improvements be made. I am told by those who understand these things better than I do that the improvements proposed will be of very marginal significance in improving the traffic flow through Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport international terminal.

I wish just to touch on a major point. I ask the Minister for Aviation whether he will ask his colleagues in this area to look at the introduction of permanent part time work, which has been introduced into the Public Service. As a means of alleviating the congestion at peak periods at this airport, will the Minister and his colleagues look at introducing permanent part time work into the Customs, health and immigration areas? Unfortunately, the great bulk of passengers arrive first thing in the morning and they are queued up for hours. Will those departments look at putting on extra staff at those peak periods and then standing them down at times when they are not required?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed improvement work has the wide support of the people of Sydney, the aviation industry and the travelling public at large. My colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has reminded honourable members that the terminal was built in the 1960s to service passengers travelling on narrow-bodied aircraft. The demands now placed on the terminal's facilities are far in excess of the terminal's capacity to handle comfortably passengers travelling on aircraft such as the Boeing 747.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Joint Committee on Public Works fully endorses the perceived shortcomings of the existing terminal and the need for improvements. The Committee has sought to come to grips with understanding the complexities of the needs and operations of an international terminal. However, I believe that the solution proposed by the Committee, namely, to commence planning immediately for a new or substantially expanded international terminal, is not appropriate. It would be significantly more costly than the proposal referred to the Committee and it would delay any relief from the present intolerable conditions for at least five years.
I make these comments about the Committee's specific conclusions and recommendations. The Committee's first conclusion states:

Improvements are required to passenger processing and baggage facilities in public areas in the international terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to cater for increased passenger numbers during daily peak periods.

This terminal was designed to handle approximately 1,000 arriving and 1,000 departing passengers at peak hours. However, due to market pressures, curfews at other airports and crew utilisation considerations, there exists a peak demand between 6 a.m. and 8 a.m. that frequently results in 1,800 passengers arriving in an hour, some 80 per cent more than the terminal is designed to handle. Likewise, the peak hour traffic of departures is frequently about 1,600 passengers-far above the design capacity. I fully agree with the Committee's conclusion that improvements are required to cater for daily peak traffic. The Committee's second conclusion states:

The Committee believes the proposed work will not alleviate congestion to a significant extent and at the end of the three year construction period the problems now experienced will be even more acute.

The proposed works are planned to cater for an approximate 80 per cent increase in capacity. Expansion of the check-in area, consolidation of the two existing outwards immigration processing areas into one area, the provision of a transit lounge, expansion of the waiting space at the inwards primary line, enlargements of the baggage hall, with larger baggage claim units and the provision of a bus dock with associated lounge, will all serve to reduce congestion and increase capacity.

The forecast of traffic growth shows that traffic in the modified terminal could be accommodated at reasonable levels until about 1991. Speakers from the other side of the House in this debate engaged in a purely political exercise, and in many cases their speeches were devoid of any consideration of the Committee's recommendations. None of them took into account management procedures or how better use could be made of that terminal. Nobody adverted to that. It is symptomatic of the spendthrift approach of those in opposition; that is why they will stay in opposition for years to come. They know only one thing. They want to spend more money and build more buildings. They do not want to know how to manage things better or how to get better service and better efficiency. Those things are totally alien to those in the Opposition to whom my comments pertain. One or two Opposition members did not pursue that line. In the main, all the speakers from the other side engaged in a political exercise and ignored studiously that approach to the use of existing facilities.

The proposed work will provide progressive improvements throughout the three-year construction period as various elements of the project are completed and put into service. If no improvement works were carried out to the existing terminal it would be at least 1991 before a new terminal could be commissioned. By then the existing problems would be even more acute. They are already totally inadequate. Those on the other side of the House have said: `Leave that as it is. Let it get worse. Let the whole thing become absolutely unmanageable. We will wait for five years and then try to build.' Those are the comments that have come from the other side of the chamber this afternoon. As I have said, if no improvement works were carried out on the existing terminal, it would be at least 1991 before a new terminal could be commissioned. Just to make sure that the message penetrates, I repeat that by that time the terminal and existing facilities would be unworkable. Indeed, some stricter control of aircraft schedules could be necessary which would have an adverse effect on Sydney's tourist trade. I therefore disagree with the Committee's conclusion that congestion will not be alleviated to a significant extent.
The Committee's third and fourth conclusions state:
The Committee does not believe the proposed work at an estimated cost of $20m will be the most effective use of the money to be expended.
The Committee concludes it is not expedient for the proposed work to proceed.

I put it to the House that it is not clear from the Committee's report how it has reached those conclusions. I have read all of the report. In many ways the conclusions do not line up with the considerations in the body of the report. I want to say to honourable members that there have been discussions with Qantas Airways Ltd on the most appropriate ways of utilising the $20m proposed for improvements. Qantas has considered adequately a number of alternative schemes and it has agreed that the work as originally proposed is the best solution.

I want to put paid to some of the nonsense said about that consultation and the utterly unfounded attacks upon the Minister for Housing and Construction. He has the carriage of this motion. He is not responsible for considerations of the aviation advice provided to him or for the evidence given to the Committee by the Department of Aviation; I accept that responsibility. It was a pretty puerile kind of exercise to chiack from the other side of the chamber and to indulge in personal abuse of the Minister for Housing and Construction when it is not he who will respond to this matter. It was a quite personal and quite political exercise; let me make that quite clear. Year after year I have sat through similar reports coming forward from committees. I heard and saw what the Fraser Government did with them, and I will come to that a little later in my contribution.

As my colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction has pointed out, the cost of possible new terminal developments could involve expenditure considerably in excess of $20m. The Government must therefore reject the Committee's conclusion that the expenditure of $20m is not the most effective use of the money to be expended.
The Committee's fifth conclusion states:
Planning for the provision of a new or substantially expanded international terminal building should commence immediately.

In view of the forecast growth and the likely timing of the need to increase terminal capacity in about 1991, the Government proposes to commence planning for a new terminal. The Department of Aviation will be asked to collate all current information on the need for planning and development of a new international terminal for handing over to the Federal Airports Corporation. The Federal Airports Corporation will be requested to consider urgently the planning and development of a new terminal. But none of that will deal with the existing problem or the problem that will develop, and be exacerbated, in the intervening years. The Committee's sixth recommendation stated:
Improvements recommended to relieve present congestion at the international terminal are:
(a) Commonwealth Authorities should provide staff to process passengers at maximum attainable levels.
(b) The length of the curfew should be reduced by one hour in the morning.

I have already initiated action on the first of these recommendations with my colleagues the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). In regard to recommendation (b), all members of the chamber are fully aware that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, after inquiring into aircraft noise, made recommendations concerning the curfew. They are aware also that this report is still under consideration by the Government.

For reasons which are apparent from my comments, the Government does not accept that the proposed works should not proceed. Not proceeding would result in intolerable demands being placed on the terminal facility and staff and the industry for a further five years. The Government believes that the work will provide both short and long term benefits. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning, design and construction can proceed in accordance with the proposal presented to the Public Works Committee.

I want briefly to run through the matters raised by individual speakers on the other side. The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) said that the Committee had no point of significant demur with the case put forward for the development. That is why it is hard, when one reads through the body of the report, to establish how the Committee reached the conclusions it did. He said that the Department of Aviation submission was a plan for a new or substantially expanded terminal, and that the provision of a new building adjacent to the existing terminal at a cost of $15m to $19.5m had been discarded because of cost. He would be aware from the comment of the Minister for Housing and Construction that the proposal for a terminal beside the existing terminal, on further costing and elaboration and on an understanding of what was really involved in the proposal from the Department of Aviation, runs to a figure of at least $75m, maybe up to $110m. So there is a significant difference there.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to fight for your funds.

—Everybody sat through the honourable member's speech quietly. I ask him to accord me the same courtesy. He said that the Department of Aviation had started from the wrong end, from the financial restriction end. I have to say to him that those are the rules of today. The old days-such as the time of the Brisbane Airport exercise, when the then Government spent money like people without arms-are gone. The public of this country will not cop that approach any longer. It is a case of making the best possible use of the investment, getting the best return from it. I find it utterly hypocritical of Opposition members-not the honourable member for Wide Bay; I have the greatest respect for him-to come in and to make these comments, to chiack and carry on about spending more money. Earlier in the day members of the Opposition were lecturing the Government on how it should be reducing expenditure-in fact, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said there should be a reduction in expenditure of several billion dollars-while, at the same time, they say that this project, the Darwin to Alice Springs railway, high speed trains, you name it, should go ahead. The more it costs, the more they are likely to support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Those days of airport madness are over. There will be a scrupulous, responsible approach to the expenditure of public moneys by this Government. The honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) wanted a new terminal, he wanted a second runway. That is symptomatic of the Opposition. It cannot get its hands out of taxpayers' pockets. Money, money, money; spend, spend, spend; more, more, more-that is the philosophy they follow, without regard to the return on investment or the value of such expenditure to taxpayers. I was rather disappointed by the contribution of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). He was more inclined to heap abuse on the Minister for Housing and Construction than he was to make an overall contribution to the debate. The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who came into this chamber priding himself on his responsible approach to financial investment and a responsible career in commerce--

TALK.START.PARA: —And successful.
—Unsuccessful, the honourable member for North Sydney says.
—I said `successful', which is more than can be said for your side.

—I thought the honourable member said `unsuccessful'. The honourable member for Deakin complained that nothing had been done to improve Sydney Airport. He should talk to the people sitting beside him. They will tell him why nothing has been done to improve Sydney Airport. Sydney's problems did not develop when this Government came to office; its problems had been evident for years, throughout the term of the Fraser Government. One thing it could not do was make up its mind about what to do with Sydney Airport. It wanted changed curfews, second Sydney airport sites, other runways and all sorts of things, but the one crystal clear fact is this: It could not make up its mind.
—It was blocked by the New South Wales Government.

—It was a Labor government in that State, and there was no way that the Fraser Government was going to spend a dollar on improving that airport. That was the idea. It was able to find $400m for Brisbane Airport, but all the industry said that it did not want that airport dealt with in that way. The Fraser Government could find the money for Brisbane Airport, but it did not want to spend a dollar on the major airport of this country. That is who is responsible-the honourable member's colleagues in the former Fraser Government. (Quorum formed)
—Order! The Minister's time has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish briefly to wind up this debate, which has gone on for longer than I expected. In the timewasting exercise inflicted upon the House by the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), and his misled comrades and colleagues on the other side, I was simply appalled by some of the arguments put. Let me deal first with their arguments as far as they apply to fiscal and macroeconomic policy. We have heard a lot from this shadow Minister in the past about the need to trim our sails, to reduce the deficit, to be frugal in regard to fiscal policy in order to get the deficit down, to take pressure off interest rates and give the private sector room to move, and so on.
