He is fully aware of the need to take pressure off the public sector borrowing requirement and he is fully aware of the pressure on Commonwealth and State public works as a result of the current economic situation, yet he comes into this place and seriously puts up a proposal to spend $110m when we are assuring the House that, following investigatory work undertaken by the Department of Aviation and the Department of Housing and Construction, we can obtain better value for our money by spending $20m instead of $110m to improve and increase the existing capacity of the international terminal building at the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Another point on which I take issue with the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction is simply this: Again and again in this House we have heard the honourable member for Deakin urge the Government to give more work to the private sector.
—You could give the whole job to the private sector. You could construct a new airport through the private sector. Have you thought of that?

—By the honourable member's very interjection he declares to the House his abysmal ignorance of the way the Department of Housing and Construction carries on its construction business. Of course the contracts for construction will go to the private sector. They always do. There is no in-house construction capacity in the Department. There is for major projects a repairs and maintenance and a design and documentation capacity. Approximately 50 per cent of the design and documentation work is farmed out to contractors and in-house temporary consultants who are hired from the private sector by the Department. So in the area of both fiscal and macroeconomic management-in the sense that it wants to spend $110m in instead of $20m-and in its understanding of the operations of the Department of Housing and Construction, the Opposition is remiss.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us restate the nature of the works proposed. The improvement works as proposed to the Joint Committee on Public Works and to the House cover the expansion and rearrangement of the departures hall, including the rationalisation of check-in counters to provide more space and decrease congestion, the construction of a new lounge for transiting passengers, the provision of two additional aerobridges and links to the passenger concourses, the expansion of the arrivals area to provide more space and additional queueing positions at the Immigration-Health-Customs primary line, the provision of new and increased capacity baggage conveyors and expansion of the baggage reclaim area to alleviate congestion and reduce waiting time in the baggage reclaim area, the provision of additional taxi queueing space and a covered bus station and the modifications and upgrading of existing building services to complement modifications to the terminal building and the concourses.

The Public Works Committee report has attempted to address cost effectiveness by noting that in these proposed works the floor area of the international terminal building will be increased by only 13 per cent. However, the Public Works Committee report missed the point. The figure of 13 per cent is not a useful measure as the terminal building includes large areas allocated for use as airline offices, Department of Aviation administrative areas, public restaurants, bars and passenger concourses which already serve aircraft parking positions adequately. It may not have been apparent to the Opposition or to the Committee that the improvement works would increase space in all important functional areas, including the arrivals, departures, Customs and baggage handling sections of the building. They would increase the area of the departures hall by 45 per cent, the area of the Customs hall by approximately 12 per cent, the area of the arrivals hall by approximately 26 per cent, and the area of the inwards Immigration-Health-Customs primary line by approximately 127 per cent. The new transit lounge will have an area of approximately 1,000 square metres and there will be a 97 per cent increase in total concession areas, including 1,120 square metres of new duty free concession space. The Opposition and the Public Works Committee have completely missed the point, believing that the 13 per cent increase to cover the whole area is insufficient. In fact, the areas where a shortage of space exists at present are to be very greatly expanded.

I understand that there have been discussions with Qantas Airways Ltd. I understand also that Qantas has expressed support for the proposals that were put to the Committee. Since then there have been discussions between Qantas and the two departments involved regarding whether a temporary building ought to be constructed during the period the work proposed is carried out. After lengthy discussions and consultations between the Secretary to the Department of Aviation and the Chief Executive of Qantas, joint Qantas-Aviation-DHC discussions took place on 26 and 27 May. These discussions clarified Qantas's understanding of the proposed terminal building improvement program and alleviated concern about the extent of inconvenience that could occur while the works are being undertaken. At the conclusion of the discussions Qantas agreed that its proposal for a temporary building was costly and unsatisfactory in several important respects and would not be pursued further. It also agreed that the international terminal improvement works as presented to the Public Works Committee should proceed. Qantas agreed that on completion of the improvement works there will be a capacity to process 1,800 terminating and 1,800 originating passengers per hour. This represents an 80 per cent increase over the original nominal design capacity of the terminal building when it was opened in 1970, having been constructed by the previous Government. No significant change has been made to the building since that time. We are getting all this improved capacity for $20m as against the $110m urged by the Opposition. We are not saying that there will not be a need for new work in the future. Obviously, that is for the Federal Airports Corporation to assess. It will be asked to give high priority to looking at planning for new expanded international operations. But the Opposition should take it from us that such work will complement what has already been proposed. There is no way in the world that the $20m which is needed now to produce an improved terminal in three years time-not in seven years time-will be wasted.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr West's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1986 is designed: To extend existing telecommunications interception powers of the Australian Federal Police in respect of certain Commonwealth narcotics offences to cover a wider category of serious drug trafficking offences; to make interception powers available to the National Crime Authority in respect of serious drug trafficking offences; and to enable interception powers to be made available to the police force-and in the case of New South Wales the State Drug Crime Commission-of any State or the Northern Territory.

The Bill gives effect to decisions made by the Government in connection with the Special Premiers' Conference on Drugs, which was held in Canberra last year. Following the conference, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory indicated their interest in seeking interception powers for their police forces in relation to drug trafficking offences. The Bill also takes into account some of the recommendations relating to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 contained in volume one of the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions-known as the Stewart Royal Commission-which I tabled in this House on 1 May 1986.

The new provisions will provide Australian law enforcement authorities with an important additional tool in the investigation and prosecution of serious drug trafficking offences, while at the same time providing effective safeguards for the protection of personal privacy.

The whole question of telecommunications interception for law enforcement purposes gives rise to difficult and serious questions and to a need for careful weighing of competing interests. The Stewart Royal Commission has recommended that interception powers should not be limited to drug cases. Earlier, the Australian Law Reform Commission, in its report on privacy, recommended that interception should be available, subject to strict controls, in relation to serious offences, which is defined as offences punishable by at least seven years' imprisonment. The Government, in considering these recommendations, sought the views of the States on the question of extending the Act to cover serious offences.

I have received verbal advice from the South Australian Attorney-General that the South Australian Government is still considering the matter. A telex has been received from the Premier of Western Australia indicating that the Western Australian Government does not support the expansion of the category of offences to cover serious offences. The Queensland Attorney-General has sent a telex indicating that the Queensland Government does not presently favour an extension of telephone interception powers to serious offences. The Northern Territory has indicated by telex that it supports an extension of interception powers to cover indictable offences. The Attorney-General of New South Wales has advised verbally that the New South Wales Government has not yet made a decision on the question of extending the Act to cover serious offences and has said that the New South Wales Government requests interception powers in relation to drug trafficking offences for the State Drug Crime Commission of New South Wales.

I indicated in the House yesterday, in answer to a question from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), that I had received verbal advice from the Tasmanian Attorney-General that whilst he had not had an opportunity to consider the Bill, in answer to my request as to whether the Tasmanian Government supported the Bill, I was of the impression that he said that he did not think the Government would in respect of serious offences; and that Tasmania would want only telephone interception powers in respect of drug offences. However, he sent me a telex this afternoon in which he said that I did not understand what he had said over the phone. I am prepared to say that that certainly might be the case if he thinks that is the position. I think I should read into Hansard parts of the telex message sent as a media release. It states:

`Mr Bowen was advised by me on 22 May that the matter would only be considered by Cabinet after the Federal Government had passed its own legislation empowering the various States to adopt all or any part of it.

I make the point that I had sent the Attorney-General a copy of the legislation and I asked him whether the Government of Tasmania agreed with telephone interception powers being extended. I accept the view expressed by the Tasmanian Attorney-General, Mr Bennett, when he says: `We are not going to make any decision until such time as the Commonwealth passes the legislation'. I interpolate that I think that will mean that the Committee the Government proposes to set up will need to take some evidence from the Tasmanian Government as to whether it wants this legislation or not. The telex goes on further to say this:

`I further advised Mr Bowen that once Federal legislation was passed, it would be considered by Cabinet and a policy decision made insofar as Tasmania was concerned. As the legislation has not been passed by the Federal Government, the Tasmanian Government has not adopted a stance at this time'.
Mr Bennett said phone tapping was a complex, and in some quarters, a very emotional issue which requires widespread consultation in Tasmania and careful consideration.
`I would hope that Mr Bowen would take the opportunity to properly represent the situation as far as Tasmania is concerned'.
Aboriginal Land Grant Bill 1986

I think I have done that. I have left it in the position that Tasmania has been unable to give an answer as to whether or not it favours the legislation. However, the Government would like to know Tasmania's position before the Committee completes its deliberations. Having said that, let me return to the matters before the House. The Government now believes that the questions arising from an extension of telecommunications interception powers for law enforcement purposes, including whether such powers should be extended beyond drug offences, call for thorough parliamentary consideration. For that reason, I shall be moving a resolution to establish a joint select committee to examine and report on the Bill, with particular emphasis on the question of extending the interception powers to cover serious offences, on the appropriateness of the proposed legislative safeguards and controls and on the feasibility of having a central Commonwealth agency to carry out interceptions for other authorities. The Australian Federal Police already has interception powers under Part IV of the Act for the investigation of certain Commonwealth narcotics offences, as defined in the Act. These powers have proved a valuable investigative tool.

The Bill extends the existing interception powers of the Australian Federal Police. In addition to those narcotics offences in respect of which it already has powers, its powers will be extended to cover serious drug trafficking offences, which are defined as a narcotics offence and any other Commonwealth or Australian Capital Territory offence involving narcotic drugs that is punishable by imprisonment for life or for a maximum period of not less than seven years. The Bill also amends the provisions at present applying to the Australian Federal Police by including new provisions enabling interception warrants to be obtained on applications made by telephone, instead of in writing, in urgent circumstances. The Australian Law Reform Commission in its privacy report recommended provisions of this kind. The provisions should go some way towards ensuring a speedier system in urgent cases.

There are three further changes. First, judges will be required, in considering whether to issue a warrant, to be satisfied that the information sought is not readily available from another source. Secondly, the maximum period of effect of a warrant issued to a member of the Australian Federal Police is to be reduced from the present period of six months to 90 days. Thirdly, the Attorney-General will be required to report annually to the Parliament on the number of warrants issued to Australian Federal Police members during the preceding year and, in terms that do not enable the identification of any person, on the use and communication of information obtained pursuant to those warrants. These changes are based on recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission in its privacy report. The Government also considers that the important role of the National Crime Authority in the investigation of serious trafficking offences requires that it be given telecommunications interception powers in relation to any such offences that are under the subject of an investigation by the Authority under its Act. The Bill therefore inserts a new Part VI into the Act conferring on the National Crime Authority telecommunications interception powers similar to those that apply to the Australian Federal Police.

The provisions require judicial warrants, which will be available only where a serious trafficking offence that is the subject of an investigation by the NCA is involved. Applications will normally be required to be in writing, supported by information on oath. In cases of urgency, however, a warrant can be issued on an application made by telephone. A warrant may be granted in respect of a telecommunications system situated anywhere in Australia and will remain in force for a maximum period of 90 days. It will authorise approved persons to intercept, that is, listen to or record, communications passing over the service specified in the warrant. The Bill provides that a warrant will not authorise any entry upon premises and will authorise interceptions to be carried out only through Telecom. Where the Chairman of the NCA is satisfied that the grounds upon which a warrant was issued have ceased to exist, the Chairman will be required to revoke the warrant and take immediate steps to ensure that interceptions pursuant to the warrant are discontinued. The Chairman will also be required to ensure the destruction of all records or copies of intercepted communications in the possession, custody or control of the NCA if the records are not needed for the purposes of lawful use or communication by the NCA.

The National Crime Authority will be required to inform the Managing Director of Telecom of the issue and revocation of each warrant and to provide the Managing Director with a certified copy of each warrant and instrument of revocation. It must retain in its own records copies of all warrants and instruments of revocation. The Chairman will be required to furnish reports to the Attorney-General on the issue and revocation of each warrant and on the use and communication of information obtained pursuant to warrants. The Attorney-General will be required to report annually to the Parliament on the number of warrants issued during the preceding year and, in terms that do not enable the identity of any person to be disclosed, the use made of information obtained pursuant to those warrants.

The Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interception has recommended that interception powers should be extended to State and Territory police forces. The Government had already announced its agreement, following the Special Premiers' Conference on Drugs, to extend telecommunications interception powers to the police forces of those States and Territories that requested such powers, subject to stringent legislative safeguards. A significant number of investigations of drug trafficking offences are solely within the jurisdiction of the States. As State police have major law enforcement responsibilities in this area, they should have the benefit of properly controlled interception powers to assist them in discharging those responsibilities. At the same time, the Government is conscious of the need to balance the legitimate requirements of law enforcement agencies with the proper protection of privacy. In the case of State and Territory police forces, a combination of Commonwealth and State legislative safeguards will ensure the necessary control and protection. The aim is to impose direct responsibility on State and Territory authorities and Ministers for the proper conduct and oversight of intercept activities while at the same time ensuring that the Commonwealth Government is able to discharge its overall responsibilities in this area.

The State and Territory police forces are covered by the new Part VII which the Bill will insert into the Act. Interception powers in relation to serious trafficking offences against State and Territory laws will be made available only to those police forces declared by the Attorney-General, by notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, to be declared authorities. A declaration will be made only at the request of the relevant Premier or Chief Minister and if the Attorney-General is satisfied that the State or Territory in question has legislation that provides satisfactory safeguards. The States and the Northern Territory have been informed of the proposed safeguards and I have been given an opportunity to comment on them, and I have already referred to those comments.

The safeguards will include provisions for reporting on the issue and revocation of warrants to the relevant State or Territory Minister; for the proper maintenance of records by the State or Territory police force; for the regular inspection of those records by an independent authority and for the reporting by that authority on the extent of compliance with statutory requirements; for the destruction of irrelevant records; and for regular reports by the relevant State or Territory Minister to the Commonwealth Minister. The legislative safeguards will be at least as stringent as those that apply in relation to interceptions by members of the Australian Federal Police under Part IV of the Act. In addition, the State or Territory concerned will be required to enter into an agreement to pay all expenses incurred in relation to the issuing of warrants and the carrying out of interceptions by its police force.

The Attorney-General will be empowered to revoke a declaration if requested to do so by the relevant State or Territory, if the necessary legislative safeguards are not maintained or if compliance with those safeguards or with the requirements of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is unsatisfactory. By means of these provisions, the Commonwealth will be able to ensure, as far as possible, that there is a continuous monitoring and control at the State or Territory level of day to day activities by State or Territory officers. The issue and revocation of warrants, the scope of the authority conferred by warrants, and the communication of information will be controlled directly by the provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act.

Under proposed Part VII, warrants will be issued by State and Northern Territory Supreme Court judges in relation to serious trafficking offences against the laws of the relevant State or Territory. Telephone applications may be made by specially approved members of the State or Territory police force in circumstances of urgency; otherwise a written application supported by information on oath will be necessary. A warrant will be available only in respect of a telecommunications system that is situated within the State or Territory concerned and will remain in force for a maximum period of 90 days. It will authorise interceptions by persons approved pursuant to a law of the relevant State or Territory. As with the National Crime Authority, warrants will not authorise entry on to premises or any interception other than through Telecom. In addition, the equipment used in interceptions will be required to be approved pursuant to a law of that State or Territory. The Commonwealth Attorney-General will be required to report annually to the Parliament on the numbers of warrants issued under the proposed Part VII and on the use made of information obtained by virtue of those warrants. The annual reports will be based on information received from State and Territory Ministers and from Telecom.

At the request of the New South Wales Government mentioned earlier, the Commonwealth Government has also given consideration to the extension of telecommunications interception powers to the State Drug Crime Commission of New South Wales. The Commission was established by the State Drug Crime Commission Act 1985 of New South Wales. Its principal functions are to investigate matters relating to a drug activity referred by its Management Committee; to assemble evidence for the prosecution of drug offences; to report on illegal drug trafficking and recommend changes to the law; and to disseminate investigatory, technological and analytical expertise. The Commission has liaison and co-operative functions with the National Crime Authority and a member of the National Crime Authority is represented on its Management Committee.

In view of the functions of the Commission and its links with the NCA, the Government considers that telecommunications interception powers should be given to the Commission, at the request of the State Government, in relation to serious trafficking offences that are being investigated by the Commission pursuant to its Act. The new Part VII which the Bill inserts in the Act deals with the Commission's powers in the same way, and makes them subject to the same conditions and legislative safeguards, as are applicable to State police forces.

The important matter of regulating the use and communication of intercepted information is at present dealt with in section 7 of the Act. Extensive amendments of the present provisions are necessary as a result of the extension of interception powers to the National Crime Authority, State and Territory police forces and the State Drug Crime Commission. Amendments are also necessary as a result of the decision of the High Court in Hilton v. Wells, at page 58 of Australian Law Reports 245, that the present provisions relating to the use and communication of intercepted information do not cover illegally obtained information and do not make such information inadmissible in any court proceedings.

The Stewart Royal Commission has recommended that the Act should be amended to make it an offence to possess, communicate, divulge or record unlawfully intercepted information. The Government accepts this recommendation. The Royal Commission goes on, however, to recommend that the provision should not prohibit the possession, use or copying of such information by police or certain other authorities. The Government does not accept that such information should be able to be used except for the purpose of establishing a contra- vention of the Act. The Royal Commission also recommends that the admissibility of unlawfully intercepted information should be determined by the common law. The Government does not accept that recommendation.

The Bill amends the present section 7 and includes new provisions dealing separately with the prohibition of unauthorised interceptions, the regulation of the use and communication of intercepted information and the admissibility of such information in evidence in proceedings. The most important effects of the new provisions are as follows:
(1) it will continue to be an offence to intercept communications passing over a telecommunications system except pursuant to a warrant or as otherwise authorised by the Act;
(2) it will be an offence to use, record or communicate to a person or a court or tribunal material obtained in contravention of the Act, except for the purpose of establishing that contravention;
(3) it will be an offence to use, record or communicate to a person or a court or tribunal material that has been lawfully obtained, except in accordance with the Act;

(4) communication of lawfully obtained material will be permitted between the Australian Federal Police, State and Territory police forces, the National Crime Authority and the State Drug Crime Commission and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, where the material is relevant to their functions;

(5) it will be possible to give lawfully obtained information in evidence only in the proceedings specified in draft section 7AB. Information obtained in contravention of the Act will be inadmissible in all proceedings except to establish the contravention. This exclusionary rule is, however, subject to a discretion in the court to admit information where the contravention is due to an insubstantial defect or error in cases where a warrant has been obtained.

It is not intended to prejudice proceedings that have been commenced before the legislation comes into operation. Accordingly, the Bill will be amended as necessary to ensure that it will not prevent intercepted material from being admitted in evidence in proceedings commenced before that date.

I shall deal briefly with the remaining recommendations of the Stewart Royal Commission relating to the Act. The Commission recommended that the power to issue warrants should be restricted to judges of the Federal Court and of the Supreme Courts of the States and Territories. The recommendation is consistent with the present law as far as the AFP is concerned. The Bill will require warrants to be issued by Supreme Court judges in the case of State and Territory police forces and the State Drug Crime Commission and by Federal Court judges or Supreme Court judges in the case of the National Crime Authority.

The Commission also recommended that a judge issuing a warrant should be able, in appropriate cases, to authorise a direct interception without recourse to Telecom. The Government has not accepted that recommendation. As indicated already, the Government has taken the view that the powers to be conferred on State authorities and the National Crime Authority should be exercisable only through Telecom.

The Stewart Royal Commission also recommended that judges should be required to take into account the gravity of the matters being investigated, the extent of likely interference with the privacy of any person and the extent to which the prevention or detection of the offence in question is likely to be assisted. As the Bill defines `serious trafficking offence', there is no need to involve judges in the assessment of the gravity of particular offences. The legislation itself, by limiting the availability of warrants to those offences and by building in a range of safeguards, achieves a proper balance between privacy interests and the requirements of law enforcement. It would not be desirable to involve judges in a case-by-case assessment of this matter. The legislation will require a judge to be satisfied that an interception is likely to assist an investigation in each case. To require, in addition, a judge to attempt to assess the extent of such assistance would be undesirable and, indeed, in many cases impracticable.
Financial Impact Statement

The provisions relating to interception powers for State and Territory authorities include a requirement that the States and Territories concerned agree to pay all expenses incurred in carrying out interceptions pursuant to warrants issued to those authorities. As far as the extension of interception powers for the Australian Federal Police and to the National Crime Authority is concerned, there will be financial implications. It is impossible to predict with accuracy the amounts likely to be involved. The amount payable in any year will depend upon the number of interceptions carried out. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON TELECOMMUNICATIONS INTERCEPTION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen) agreed to:

That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1986, prior to its second reading, being referred to a joint select committee appointed for the purpose of examining and reporting on the Bill.
Appointment
Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen) proposed:
(1) That a joint select committee be appointed:

(a) to examine and report upon the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1986 and, in particular, the appropriateness of the mechanism for conducting interceptions and the safeguards for their authorisation, recording, transcribing, dissemination and retention, and

(b) to examine and report upon the recommendation contained in Mr Justice Stewart's report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions to the effect that the power of interception be extended to cover all serious offences.

(2) That the committee consist of 9 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.
(6) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(7) That the committee have power to send for persons, papers and records, and to move from place to place.
(8) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(9) That the committee present its final report as soon as possible.
(10) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(11) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of regret that today we have before us in this House a motion which effectively amounts to a cop-out of decision making by this Government. We were told by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on 1 May 1986:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will give urgent consideration to the recommendations.

He was there referring to the Stewart recommendations in the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions. We are now told that what will happen is that the main part of the Stewart recommendations is to be referred to this Joint Select Committee. Apparently the Government finds it impossible to understand the issues that Mr Justice Stewart has raised or to inform itself on the matters which are concerned in those issues. It is inconceivable that the Government could find itself in that position. It must understand very clearly what the issues are and it is not as though we are coming to this question for the first time.

I remind the House how long this matter has been before it and go back three years, and indeed to what I said in this House on 2 May 1986. Telecommunication interceptions and the use of telecommunication interceptions for serious organised crime are a known feature of detection of organised crime. I remind the House of what was said by Mr Justice Stewart in February 1983 in his report on the Royal Commission of Inquiry into drug trafficking where he criticised the narrowness of the interception powers and recommended;

A judge should be empowered to issue warrants for the interception of telephone conversations where the activities of persons are such as point to the likely existence of a criminal scheme or conspiracy involving organised criminals. It should not be restricted to the commission of certain narcotics offences as presently provided. . .

What happened is that Special Prosecutor Redlich recommended amendments to enlarge interception powers in his report of 7 September 1983. What has happened to those recommendations? Nothing. They are under what this Government calls `active consideration'. So, at the very least, during the time that this Government has been in office it has had three years to consider recommendations that telephone interception powers should be enlarged and it has done nothing. Now, reportedly because of a Caucus revolt-not doubt from the Left-we find the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) coming into this House to present a Bill that is to be examined by a committee set up by this House. This kind of approach to the fight against organised crime is reminiscent of an answer given by the Attorney-General to this question asked by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp):

Are Australian law enforcement agencies still unable to apprehend and hold transiting passengers carrying illegal drugs? Did the Minister last November call for a report on the Taillon case, which highlighted this serious anomaly with the aim of closing this gap in our drug defences? Why has nothing been done and how does this gross negligence square with the drug offensive and the claims made as recently as yesterday by the Special Minister of State that the Government is doing all it can to fight the drug menace?

We heard, immediately before the Minister answered that question, his answer to a friendly question put to him from his side of the House, when he referred to the great work that the Government was doing: It had supported a resolution at an international conference; it had many things under consideration-active consideration, passive consideration; it was thinking about these issues; and, it was not blind to these issues. What has it done? Nothing. What do we get? We get an enlargement of intercept powers in relation to drug trafficking offences and the balance of the recommendations are to be examined by this Committee. Can anyone tell me-can the Attorney-General tell me-the logical reason for saying, on the one hand, that it is right that there should be power to intercept conversations relating to serious drug trafficking offences but, on the other hand, that without an inquiry it is not possible to say that it is right to extend the intercept powers to, for example, contract murder?

We have a Bill which is now to be referred to this Committee. I do not anticipate debate upon this Bill but, according to the second reading speech, the result of the Government's approach will be that, if at the one time one hears over the telephone evidence about organised drug trafficking and one has obtained a warrant for that purpose, that evidence is admissible; but if during the same conversation between the same people one finds that a contract murder is set up, that evidence is not to be as admissable; nor is any other kind of illegal activity that one can think of, no matter how dangerous, how vile, or how many people are affected-including, I suppose, terrorist activities such as a plan to put a bomb in Parliament House. It was said that Guy Fawkes was the only person who approached Parliament with the right intentions. If one came across that kind of evidence in the course of a telephone call, that apparently is not the sort of thing that should be considered without the sanction, at the very least, of this Committee looking at it.

There is no need to refer such matters to a committee. What can members of this House, or of the Senate, tell the Government that it does not already know? What wisdom are they going to give to the Government that it does not have? Does the Government really tell us that it cannot inform itself on these matters? Does the Attorney-General really say that he is unable to make a decision upon the subject? I suspect that the Attorney-General would favour the broad implementation of the Stewart proposals. He cannot say that, because he is Attorney-General in a government and must represent that government's point of view. But where is the justification for this exercise? What is the consequence? The consequence is that this Bill will not go through this session. What is the further consequence? The further consequence is that the whole question of enlargement of the powers to intercept is to go to a committee which, whilst it is required to report as soon as possible, will report one knows not when. What is the future consequence? That report itself will be under active consideration.

We have no commitment by this Government to implementing the Stewart recommendations. We have no voice by this Government as to what it thinks about those recommendations. We have had no attempt by the Attorney-General, on behalf of the Government, to analyse the recommendations that say that the powers should be extended and to put the case, if there is a case, against those recommendations. If the Government does not want to do it it should say so, but it should not adopt this delaying device and this cowardly compromise of setting up a committee to defer the day when it has to come back here with a recommendation.

Let me put to the House very clearly what the Opposition's position is. It is, as I said earlier, to support the Stewart recommendations. There are safeguards that can be built into the use of those recommendations and into their implementation. Safeguards should be built in, but the time has come to stop approaching organised crime with the kind of sense of direction and speed displayed by a mating tortoise. When are we really going to come to the conclusion that the legislation should be implemented? When are we going to have legislation to confiscate assets; to confiscate not just the assets of organised crime but the assets of people who act as criminals on a business basis? To pick up a question asked by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), when are we going to have a national criminal code?

It is no use going back to what took place more than three years ago. It is no use the Government saying: `You were in government then, what did you do'? Members opposite are in Government now. The public perceptions of the dimensions of organised crime have increased very greatly. Our general concern about the dimensions of organised crime must have increased and our knowledge has increased very greatly as a result of the final Costigan reports and the kind of work that Mr Justice Stewart has done; so we will no doubt participate in this Committee, but we participate in it with a very clear commitment to implement the broad thrust of the Stewart recommendations in pretty much the terms that Mr Justice Stewart has put them up.

It passes my understanding why this Government says again and again that it has got to have a committee, it has got to have further consideration, it has got to have active consideration. One does not have consensus when it comes to dealing with organised crime. One takes hard decisions, implements those hard decisions and approaches the criminals in the only way that they can be approached; that is, by using the toughest measures available in a democracy. Otherwise, make no mistake about this, not only are we losing the war; we will in fact lose the war and have to start again. Those who think that organised crime is merely a minor manifestation of life in our society should look to the facts and should understand that it is a major manifestation, that the profits are extraordinarily high and the risk of apprehension and detention is extremely low.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — in reply-I wish to reply briefly to what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has said. Let me rebut the suggestion that there is any cowardly compromise here, or that the Government has gone soft. I make the point that Mr Justice Stewart recommended that there should be an extension of the powers and, of course, it would relate to the States as well; so a draft proposal was sent to the States indicating that the powers could be extended. It is a matter of record in this Parliament that at this stage Western Australia and Queensland-they may change their mind-do not wish an extension of power. The question of how we would deal with this matter has been raised because crime covers not only Federal matters but also State matters and to some extent can be intertwined.

SPEECH.PARA: The first offer of this power to the States was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the narcotics conference last year; it was not requested by the States. The Government took the initiative on that issue. When the offer was made, the Premiers, I suppose understandably, felt that they had to give it further consideration. The distinguished Attorney-General for Tasmania is even worried that I may have misrepresented him-perhaps I did. He thought that the States had to make a decision about the matter before the Government passed the legislation. I want the honourable member for North Sydney to agree with me that here is an opportunity for all the States to come before the proposed committee and clearly indicate what they will do, assuming we pass the legislation.

That brings me to the second point, which is that I cannot find out the position of the States, because they do not want to make decisions at this stage. Clearly, they are not prepared to make a decision until we pass the legislation. Honourable members should bear in mind that we are talking about this matter on the basis of what we can agree on following from the narcotics conference, at which all States and all Premiers were present. The Prime Minister made the offer to them; it is his offer with which we are now dealing. I would have thought that the States would have been able to make up their minds by now. I am not criticising them. I think a committee has value in that it would ascertain from them what they really want.

Another matter which is causing concern-I have a point of view about it but many others have different points of view-is what control mechanism Telecom Australia will have if it intercepts communications and what use will be made of the material. What control will there be over the material that is collected? It is a Federal authority but the material would have to go to the States. Will we allow the States to do this? The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1986 proposes this. The alternative now being put up-I can see that there would be some legitimate argument about it which the committee might unravel-is whether we would want a Commonwealth agency to do this for the States. I can see that that is an argument. I do not know whether we will reach any clear finality unless we have some further discussions with the States on the detail of how this is to be done. The States all admit that they will have to pay the cost of it. Some States certainly take the view that they want the Commonwealth to do this for them. That is the present position. I do not think that gives uniformity of approach. The view I put forward in the Bill is that the States can do this subject to adequate legislation being passed in their own parliaments. They have to grapple with this situation. That is where the role of the Committee would be. At least we would find out from the State authorities what they would do about the proposals which are clear in black and white. On that basis the committee would be able to take evidence from the States on whether they want to extend the powers, the best mechanism of control over the information that is gathered, the way in which it will be extinguished if it is of no value, the way in which it will be extinguished after it has been used, the reporting mechanisms to the appropriate Attorneys-General or Ministers who are appointed, and the appropriate mechanisms for reporting us? They are the issues which are being debated at the moment.

That is preferable to having argument all around the continent on whether the States will use it and, if so, on what basis. If they do get it do they want a national authority-which some want-or will they do it themselves? Those matters have still to be brought to finality. That is my view. A committee would do that because it would take evidence and come up with the recommendations. I am pleased to note that the Opposition will participate in the committee. This is an important matter.

Let me also rebut some of the allegations which the honourable member for North Sydney is prone to make about where the Government is going in relation to crime. It is no good saying that I cannot talk about events that occurred before 1983. Let me make the point that all the illegal intercepts that took place took place when the Opposition was in government. Not only that, but a most outrageous thing happened. The Australian Federal Police, under the control of the Liberal and National parties, went to the State police who were doing the illegal intercepts and got copies of the tapes from them and paid money for them. Honestly, as a distinguished member of the legal profession, why did the honourable member for North Sydney not take some action about that matter? Was he that blinkered, hoodwinked and mute that he did not know the Federal Police had this information? Did he not know that they had paid for it? Did he not know that they had copies of the tapes? Did he not know that the police spoke to Commissioner Woods about it? What sort of Ministers were they in those days? I exempt the honourable member for North Sydney. I know that he would have made a marvellous Minister and he would have cut right through that dreadful swath of inefficiency and incompetence. But it is no good his coming in here and saying that it is no use my referring to illegal events that occurred prior to 1983. They all happened under the previous administration. One hundred and forty police-a whole organisation-were cavorting around in New South Wales, tick-tacking to the Federal Police and they were getting paid 200 bucks for the information. Where is the Opposition's honesty, where is its integrity in this respect? On that basis I am telling the Opposition that it knew of these matters. The Liberal-National Party Ministers must have known of them. Can the Opposition not go back to its previous Attorney-General?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Neville? Do you say that Premier Wran knew about these things?

—I know that the honourable member is trying to shout me down in desperation. He is frightened that he will be noticed by his former Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), or his former Attorney-General, Senator Durack. The honourable member must protect them and do his best, but really they are as guilty as can be. They were administering the law of this country; the inviolate integrity of the communications system was torn to shreds by the former Government's Federal police and it knew nothing about it. In future if anybody wants to come forward with information it will have to be information obtained legitimately by a judicial warrant. If people want to come forward with information they got illegally, they will be up for the penalty which the honourable member for North Sydney wants increased-and I agree with him. We will do something about that.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time I have at my disposal I wish to rebut what the honourable gentleman has been most anxious to put forward-that under this Government is the only time that something should have been done. I am saying: What happened beforehand? The Opposition need not worry about all the crooks who have got away. We are still trying to get them back but we still have to get many more extradition treaties because the former Government did not have any.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you extradited anybody since you have had your extradition treaties?

—Await developments. The honourable member will be pleasantly surprised. It will be because of our initiative and our extradition treaties that the honourable member will see the action flowing. It did not happen when the Opposition was in government. The honourable member for North Sydney makes out that crime has burst on us all of a sudden since 1983. He should look at the Nugan Hand operations, the bottom of the harbour operations and the crook passports of the fellows whom we are still trying to catch and who left this country when the Liberal and National parties were in government. We are still trying to get them back. How did they get out of the country? One must ask oneself what sort of law administration we had at that time.
—How did they get out?

—How did they get out of the country? It is recognised that they left with passports which were not even in their own names. They left when they knew that they might be asked to face up to some of the problems. The Opposition has the audacity to say that the Government has gone soft, that we have not done enough or that we have come up with a cowardly compromise. I know that the honourable member for North Sydney personally is innocent.
—You have lost me again.

—I know that the honourable member appears to be innocent. I do not want to lose my colleague; he is a valuable man. The Opposition should not come up with the statements that all the crime has happened in the last couple of years. The Taillon case, to which the honourable member referred, was a really bad legal interpretation. I have asked that we have a good look at why we should withdraw the prosecution should the situation happen again. I would be very keen to see that we go ahead with the next prosecution.
—Since November last year.
—We do not find too many people coming to Australia with that stuff in their luggage.
—Change the law then.
—I have recommended that the law be changed if there is a defect in the law. I have recommended that.
—And you are still waiting to be told.

—Well, it does take a little while to get matters through the bureaucracy. The honourable member knows that. That would be no surprise to anybody. But I do not want people to think that we did not face up to the issue. In fact we were amazed to think that somebody would not be prosecuted. I made the point here in Question Time today. But, quite seriously, it is a matter in which we require the support of the State authorities and the law enforcement agencies right across Australia and also internationally. We will not be limited to the issue of intercepts. That will be only a small part. We must follow the movement of money across the world and we will require the co-operation of other governments. We are entering into mutual assistance treaties. We are entering into extradition treaties. The States will have to co-operate with us because the information that may be required under mutual assistance treaties will need to be available from the States. I am sure that they will co-operate. So we have a fair amount of momentum at last in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the honourable gentleman will be pleasantly surprised at the amount of legislation that will be introduced in the Budget session dealing with the forfeiture of assets and also some new ideas. People who appear to have assets may be asked to explain whether they obtained them on a legal basis or otherwise. In other words, the onus of proof may shift. We will be leading the world in that field. On that basis, I thank the honourable gentleman for his doubtful support, in some respects, but I welcome the fact that the Opposition will participate in the Committee. I am sure that the Committee will do a very worthwhile job in determining what is the national responsibility in a telecommunications interception system and how we might best draft a piece of legislation that will satisfy not only us but also the State governments and the Government of the Northern Territory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
