SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

There are three amendments. One reduces the rate of tax on motor vehicles. The second one exempts public benevolent institutions from the tax. The third one is a minor technical amendment to ensure that the remote travel concessions go to all of those who qualify. All of these have been well canvassed in the community. They are well known. They are the result of negotiations with honourable senators. The changes are just marginal changes. I suppose we must expect about 15 minutes of rhetoric from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) on this subject. Of course, we must be patient while he goes on with his rhetoric.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rhetoric? He just happens to represent Australia.

—To suggest that he is representing Australia, as I have just heard in an interjection, is just incredible when one thinks of the general support in the community for getting rid of these tax rorts that exist.

SPEECH.PARA: This fringe benefits tax is the final stage of a tax reform that is vital. For too long payments have been made in kind which, if they had been paid in cash, would have been taxed. The employer who was giving those benefits in kink would have also paid the tax equivalent because the employee would have expected the net amount in his hands, that is, the amount that otherwise would be taxable. It has been a rort that has not been corrected until this time. We have now said: `All right. If employers are paying these things in kind, they will have to find the tax anyway'. So be it. Of course, the way of the reformer is difficult when we have people such as the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) who tries to stop all reform in this place. But I repeat that there is broad community support for what we are doing and I commend these amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since we are talking to the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, I must say that the little turn put on just now by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) reminded me of a review on the London stage in the 1960s which was called Beyond the Fringe. In that Peter Cook, Dudley Moore, Alan Bennett and, as I recall, Jonathan Miller, had a number of hilarious sketches portraying people carrying on in the manner in which the Minister just carried on, and with just as much sense. I will not recall those to the House because we have a very serious matter before us.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that from the Senate, basically because the Australian Democrats have totally failed to support the Opposition in its attempt to defeat this iniquitous measure, we have a couple of the tiddlers thrust back to us by way of amendment. One of the amendments, relating to charities, was moved by the Opposition, supported by the Democrats and not voted against by the Government-but after some grudging remarks from the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, which I shall mention shortly.

The first of the amendments concerns the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles. I just say that absent from any of the amendments is any provision relating to fringe benefits on farms. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visited Canowindra last weekend, when he promised to look into this matter and claimed that he did not realise how badly the fringe benefits tax impacted on farmers. He said that he would come back and talk it over--

TALK.START.PARA: —What have his rural members been telling him? What did the honourable member for Rankin tell him?

—Indeed, no doubt the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) had been telling him that there were squeals in the bush about the fringe benefits tax, and quite correctly. But the Prime Minister went to Canowindra and in a tear-jerking performance agreed that these measures are very serious and will have a severe impact that he said he had not realised would be the case. Heaven forbid! He heads the Cabinet which examined and passed the legislation and pushed it through both Houses. But he said that he did not understand that it was so bad and that he would come back here and see what he could do about it. We know what happened. This week we asked him questions as to what progress he was making with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in changing the Bill while it was still in the Senate in order to remove these iniquitous and burdensome provisions on farmers. He indicated in an abject fashion that no changes would be made to the Bill. So these amendments do not cover any changes for farmers. The Prime Minister's Canowindra meeting was, as usual, an empty public relations exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the fringe benefits tax on cars, the motor industry, supported by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, by the South Australian Premier Mr Bannon, by the Vehicle Builders Union, by a Melbourne research institute commissioned by the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, argued very strongly that the imposition of the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles would bring about a loss of some 10,000 to 20,000 jobs in the motor industry. This industry was already very sorely affected by two other Government policies: firstly, the policy of high interest rates which had hit this industry particularly badly; and, secondly, the combination of policies which led to the serious devaluation of the dollar, particular against the yen, where devaluation was by some 50 per cent.

This industry was hit by those two policies, and also by the introduction of lead-free engines and by a one per cent increase in sales tax on motor vehicles. According to analysis, the industry could have weathered that storm. The resulting drop in sales could have been borne by it without loss of employment; but, on top of that, the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles, hitting as it does so severely fleet purchases, has put this industry into severe recession with cuts in sales of some 20-odd per cent and a projected loss of 10,000 to 20,000 jobs.

The Government claimed that the total fringe benefits tax would yield a net revenue of $540m. It claimed that $370m of that would come from the tax on cars. The industry has estimated-again I emphasise that these estimates have been supported by Senator Button and by the Labor Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon-that the tax would probably net $570m. It said that the Treasury had made a gross underestimation of the effect of the tax. Apparently that has been argued out between Senator Button and the Treasurer and also between the Australian Democrats and the Treasurer, neither side conceding the argument. Under a deal done between the Treasurer and the Democrats, the Democrats have moved an amendment which scales back to a degree the fringe benefits tax on cars. It has altered the rates at which the tax is levied for certain numbers of kilometres travelled per year, and it is estimated that this will reduce the take by about $200m-from $570m back to the original $370m estimated by the Treasurer.

If this rather grubby deal done between the Democrats and the Treasurer works, all it will do is scale back the tax revenue take from the industry to what the Treasury said it was going to be in the first place. Therefore, all the Democrats have done on this fringe benefits tax-the people of Australia had better understand this-is to allow the Treasurer to collect all the revenue he expected he would in the first place. It will still have a substantial impact on the motor vehicle industry. Jobs will be lost, and the Democrats will share the responsibility for that with the Government. Incidentally, they will also share the responsibility for the whole of the fringe benefits tax.

We will not oppose this amendment. It does ameliorate the effects of the tax, but let me say this: It is a pathetic little deal done by the Democrats. It has been a pathetic operation on their part. I also inform the House that last weekend when there were by-elections in New South Wales the Democrats candidates were approached by individual voters and attacked severely because of their supine attitude in the face of this dreadful measure. The Opposition wants to make it clear that not only what is left of the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles, which is still the most substantial part of the measure, but the whole of the fringe benefits tax legislation, will be removed from the statute books immediately we get back into office. I emphasise that for everyone all around the country.

The second matter I want to deal with is the proposal to tax charitable and non-profit bodies. Honourable members will recall that in the statement of 19 September the Treasurer made some kind of promise to exempt these bodies, or at least to ameliorate the effects of the tax on them. A number of religious, charitable and non-profit bodies wrote to the Treasurer and to other members over a number of months seeking advice on how these exemptions would be implemented. They received correspondence back from the Treasurer which made it clear that he had no intention whatsoever of exempting these bodies. The pressure has been kept up. The Opposition has been pressing the Treasurer very strongly on this matter, and when the Bill finally got to the Senate we moved an amendment to exclude from the effects of the fringe benefits tax public benevolent institutions. I refer to the definition of such an organisation quoted to the Senate by Senator Peter Baume. An organisation is legally defined as a public benevolent institution if it satisfies the following tests:
Its object is the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, destitution or helplessness;
it is carried on without purpose of private gain for particular persons;
it is established for the benefit of a section or class of the public; and
relief is available without discrimination to every member of that section of the public which the organisation claims to benefit.

(Extension of time granted) The amendment moved by the Opposition and supported by the Democrats, and therefore passing through the Senate, will cover the major charitable bodies. I am told that the term `charity' could not be used in the amendment because it had a much wider definition, so the definition of public benevolent institution is the one followed. Senator Grimes, representing the Government, was scathing in his remarks about the amendment. He said:

This amendment will make things clearer for St Vincent de Paul and all the great organisations in this country. As sure as eggs the money that is contributed by donors to organisations in this community will be used to provide, say, a car for private use for the manager of a sheltered workshop in this community. It will be done over and over again. We do not oppose the amendment because, firstly, we can count--

in other words, Senator Grimes saw that the Democrats were supporting the Opposition on this amendment, and although the Government would have liked to vote against it, it knew it would not win on the numbers--
and secondly, we have some concern for simplicity. In this case simplicity runs across equity and in a year or two we will be back amending the legislation again.

So Senator Grimes has made it quite clear to the Australian public and to these charitable bodies that in a year of two-if he is still in office; if it is one year, maybe, but certainly not two years-the Government will be back amending the legislation again. So that is the threat from the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, who had the carriage of this Bill through the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another hit list?

—As my friend the honour- able member for Forde points out, another hit list is being prepared by Ministers to be put back into this measure. The Opposition tried also to introduce an additional clause providing for the exemption of employees of scientific, charitable or public educational institutions, where those institutions provide a benefit. That would have included such bodies as schools, which are not exempt under the legislation as proposed. That proposal was defeated by the combined votes of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. I make it quite clear to the Committee and to members of the Australian public that the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats voted against an amendment proposed by the Opposition to exempt schools from the fringe benefits tax. This means that schools providing residential accommodation for teachers or other employees looking after students in boarding schools will not be exempt from the fringe benefits tax. That was raised in the House by you, Mr Deputy Chairman, in your Party capacity. You asked a question of the Treasurer on this matter, and it was a matter of notoriety that the Treasurer was not able to assure you, acting on behalf of your constituents, that these bodies would be exempt. They are not exempt. We moved an amendment to try to have them exempted and that amendment was defeated by the combined vote of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. That is disgraceful.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the miserable story of this measure. There is another relatively minor amendment-the third amendment put up by the Government relating to holidays for people living in remote places when they are not under awards. We are not against that amendment. However, I make it quite clear and put beyond any shadow of doubt that although the Opposition is supporting these amendments, the whole of the fringe benefits tax legislation will be repealed when we get back into office. It is an extraordinary tax. People are finding out day by day exactly what its ramifications are. The 56-page booklet has gone out to every employer in the country-there are hundreds of thousands of them-and Opposition members are being flooded with requests, firstly for information as to whether or not this is real-they can hardly believe it-and secondly for assistance in trying to interpret the document, which is very obscure. People wonder how it could possibly be that tax reform could actually result in legislation of this kind. We accept these amendments, tiddlers though they are, from the Senate-they make some reduction in the burdens of this dreadful tax-but we make it clear that we have in mind removing the whole of the tax from the statute books on our return to office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I said in my opening remarks that we would have to be patient while the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) had his 15 minutes of fun. He kept to his 15-minute agreement. We have been patient. This reform will now become law. It will be very worthwhile being able to say that, in future, taxation on benefits of kind will be at the same rate as taxation on cash benefits, cash remuneration. That is a worthwhile reform. The Government is pleased to see these minor amendments go through in order for that reform to be complete.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND GRANT (JERVIS BAY TERRITORY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon break today I was emphasising the fact that the Opposition does not oppose the granting of a title to the 403 hectares proposed by the Government to be given to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community. However, we cannot support the granting of a title on a freehold basis which will do no more to assist the Wreck Bay community to have a sense of ownership than would a perpetual lease, the form of title available to all residents of the Australian Capital Territory. By offering the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community freehold title, we are most concerned that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has only added to the already serious rift which is developing between Aboriginal Australians and the wider community. As I said previously, for various reasons, most of which are closely related to the hype generated as a result of the Government's policies on Aboriginal welfare, there is a concern that the gulf between Aboriginal Australians and the rest of the community is getting wider. This will make the achievement of equality of opportunity that much more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: The system of land title in the Australian Capital Territory and the Jervis Bay territory, as is well known, is leasehold. By offering the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community freehold title, the Minister is giving them a title which no other person in the Australian Capital Territory or Jervis Bay can enjoy. Negotiations were conducted under the Fraser Government with the Wreck Bay community on the basis of a perpetual lease. This would have ensured the community a secure title to the land which they currently occupy with the extensions that are proposed by the Government and which we support.

With the exception of the Northern Territory, all mainland States have given, or are in the process of negotiating, perpetual leasehold titles with Aboriginal communities which traditionally have lived on what were previously missions or reservations. Having failed to achieve the Government's policy of national land rights, and it is fortunate for the well being of the two communities that that is so-a land rights policy, incidentally, which included the concept of freehold title to Aboriginal land across Australia-the Minister should now face the fact that a policy of equality of opportunity, which I believe must be the basis of any sensible approach to Aboriginal welfare, cannot be achieved by further damaging inter-racial relations, which may well be the result of giving the Wreck Bay community freehold title which is denied everyone else.

The Minister should be well aware that on the south coast in recent months, as a result of the New South Wales Government's establishment of Aboriginal land councils, considerable friction and ill will has been developing. Unfortunately, the action of this Government, in bringing the legislation before the House in this form, will do nothing to reduce that ill will and, I fear, will only exacerbate it further.

The whole issue of land rights has bedevilled the Parliament and the Government for some time. We have seen its rise until the passage of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act in 1976. That was a landmark piece of legislation which, in the fullness of time, we believe will need to be changed. I have no doubt that my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham), who will be speaking in this debate, will elucidate that issue much further. Many of the issues which were raised at that time and which have bedevilled the development of the Northern Territory and significantly affected in a negative sense the relationship between Northern Territory Aboriginal Australians and the rest of the population resulted finally in this Government being prepared to consider a range of amendments to the legislation. It is a matter, therefore, of profound concern to me and to the Opposition that, while the basis of the reforms which the Minister proposed to bring into the Parliament were not all that were wanted, at least they were a step in the right direction.

Unfortunately, the Minister failed to get the support of the Caucus or of his backbench committee. Because of his concern about the reaction it could have at the forthcoming July National Conference of the Australian Labor Party, he decided not to proceed with land rights reform in terms of the Northern Territory legislation. The Minister failed to bring his draft amendments to the Parliament after they had received the general endorsement-that is all I can say of them-of the Northern Territory Government, the mining community and the Cattlemen's Council of Australia. Unfortunately, perhaps, the Northern Territory land councils did not support these proposals. However, at least he had the basis for establishing an improvement in inter-racial relations in the Northern Territory while at the same time ensuring that a methodology was put in place which would give Aboriginal communities greater flexibility and greater opportunities to develop whatever economic resources may exist on the land which has been assigned to them-their traditional land.

The Government promised to introduce amending legislation during the Autumn session. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made that commitment to the Northern Territory, as did the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. That commitment has now been broken. The current legislation, which is long overdue for review, is having a serious impact on Northern Territory development. The legislation effectively has frozen mining development as well as severely limiting the ability of Aboriginal communities to use their land. Access to land for the provision of services to Aboriginal communities and the excessive powers awarded to land councils under the original Act clearly need urgent reform. Commitments have been made by the Minister that he will bring back those reforms to the Parliament in the Budget session. I wait to see that. There is a very real risk that at the July ALP Conference the existing policy on Aboriginal land rights will be reaffirmed. In that event, I do not see how the Minister will be able to keep his commitments, commitments which he freely entered into and which to date have been broken.

The whole issue of land rights, therefore, is of profound importance. This legislation-although it relates only to some 160 Aboriginals-is important because those Aboriginals are the last remaining community in Australia who have not been given access to a secure title. We support the concept of giving them that right, but with great regret we cannot support this legislation because of the fact that it is giving them a freehold title which is not available to any other resident in the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a delight to be able to wholeheartedly welcome the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Bill 1986. The Bill grants 403 hectares in the Jervis Bay Territory to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community. That community is to be given inalienable freehold title. The Bill also establishes the framework for government in the community by establishing a community council to be known as the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council. It is to the Council that the title to the land will be granted. The Community Council will have the power to lease the land to the residents for housing or for other purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Passage of this Bill will complete a prolonged stage in the development of the Wreck Bay community. The community includes mainly descendants of tribes in the Jervis Bay and Shoalhaven areas and other parts of the south coast and of the Monaro. Negotiations about this transfer have been under way for about 13 years, commencing in 1973 with the proposal for a perpetual lease. The Fraser Government made an offer of a leasehold block but those discussions also stalled. The present Government recommended negotiations in 1983 with a larger offer for the area included in this Bill and made it an offer of freehold rather than leasehold title. The Opposition is proposing that the grant be on a leasehold rather than on a freehold basis.

There are many reasons why this is inappropriate, and I will mention just six. First, an offer of leasehold by the previous Government was unacceptable to the community. This is a negotiated settlement so it is important to take account of its opinion. The rest of my constituents, I am quite sure, would be strongly supportive of this Bill. Secondly, the members of that community, as distinct from the Opposition, have a commitment to justice. Thirdly, the previous Government legislated for freehold title for Aboriginals in the Northern Territory, against prevailing leasehold tenure systems, so arguments that we cannot depart from prevailing leasehold systems in the Australian Capital Territory are spurious. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) accepted that. Fourthly, freehold grants are consistent with Government policy in respect of granting land rights to Australia's indigenous population. Fifthly, it is entirely reasonable for Aboriginals, given past injustice of dispossession and dispersal to be afforded a more secure title than the rest of the population. Sixthly, in any case, there is other freehold in the Australian Capital Territory. I think the honourable member for Bradfield is mistaken about that. There are a number of blocks in the Australian Capital Territory which were freehold from the very earliest days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pre-1915 titles.

—Indeed, pre-1915. Of course, the Aboriginals were here long before 1915, so it seems to me to be absolutely logical that they should have freehold title also. It seems that the Opposition is opposed to justice for Aborigines. It is proposing what is simply a symbolic weakening because, in fact, there is very little practical difference between leasehold and freehold.

SPEECH.PARA: The delays since 1983 in the negotiations for this transfer have been caused by division within the community. Some community members in Wreck Bay consider that a larger grant would be appropriate, based on traditional and historic usage. Last year the Government made a determined effort to achieve agreement on this proposal through extensive consultation between officials and community members, and through a visit by the Minister to the community. After these discussions and the presentation of detailed proposals and their implications, a ballot was held. Out of about 80 people eligible to vote about 35 did, and 33 supported the proposals. This is not a satisfactory mandate for going ahead with the proposal if the abstention of the others could be clearly perceived as an expression of opposition. However, it seems as though many factors were involved in the abstentions, including simply an unwillingness amongst some of the community members to express an opinion. In view of the length of the time the discussions have been going on and of the importance of taking this step, it is important to go ahead with this Bill now.

There are many reasons why the Bill is important. I will mention three. The first reason is that the Government should have legislation for Aboriginal land rights in its own Territory. Land rights for Aborigines is the principal requirement for correcting the injustices of the past and establishing a sound basis for freedom and development in the future. The Opposition does not seem to accept that. The second reason for the Bill is that there is a passionate pressure for a land grant from some members of the community, though others do not seem to be particularly fussed about the issue. The third reason for the Bill is that it is essential to clarify the ownership of the land so that uncertainty about titles to housing on the land--
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr and Mrs Alex Harding-Australian Ambassador to UNESCO-Nobel Peace Prize Lecture `Prescription for Hope'-International World Peace Conference-Bulgaria-Political Philosophy-Brisbane International Airport-Adjournment Speech by the Late Arthur Calwell-Kakadu National Park: Illegal Campers

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the House's attention to a most unfortunate situation within my electorate of Forde. The situation I am about to describe highlights the bureaucratic indecision which has become the trademark of this Government. It also represents just one more attack in a long line of attacks on the aged by this Government. I refer to the case of Mr and Mrs Alex Harding, who are residents of the Sinnamon Retirement Village at Seventeen Mile Rocks. For more than 50 years, Mr and Mrs Harding had enjoyed a happy marriage and a fulfilling life. Mr Harding had worked as an administrator with the Postmaster General's Department and Mrs Harding had made her career as a school teacher. Between them, I am sure they could teach this Government a thing or two about the need for forward planning to cater for future needs. Like so many people in our aged community, they deserve to be known as great Australians. They are just two of the many people who worked hard to make Australia a great nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr and Mrs Harding, at the ages of 87 and 86 respectively, did not expect to be deserted by the Australian Government. But this is virtually what happened, thanks to a severe case of bungling ineptitude. Age catches up with everyone and the Hardings are no exception. After living together in the hostel section of Sinnamon Village, Mrs Harding's health reached a point where nursing home care was required. However, there was no room at the Village. There are 305 hostel residents and a further 42 residents in self-contained units at Sinnamon Village. A large proportion of them will require nursing home care in future years. But many will be disappointed, as there are only 30 nursing home beds available.

Sinnamon Retirement Village is operated by the Wesley Central Mission of the Uniting Church in Australia and I am sure that all honourable members would agree that it is a caring organisation. The church is not to blame for the chronic shortage of nursing home beds at Seventeen Mile Rocks; the fault lies entirely with this Government. If the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) approved the church's long-standing application to add an extra 30 nursing home beds to the complex today, work on the project would probably start tomorrow. It is this scandalous delay in approving the application which has caused Mr and Mrs Harding so much heartache and which continues to threaten the future happiness of many of their fellow residents at Sinnamon Village.

Because of the shortage of nursing home beds, the Hardings were separated for a period of six months. The administrative staff at Sinnamon Village found a bed for Mrs Harding at another Uniting Church institution within my electorate-the Bethesda Hospital at Corinda. After more than 50 years of happy marriage, Mr and Mrs Harding were separated by the incompetence of this Government. Thanks to the ever willing kindness of the staff at both Sinnamon Village and Bethesda, they were able to see each other for a couple of hours every second day. When their plight was brought to the attention of the Minister for Community Services by the Brisbane Sunday Mail, a spokesman for the Minister was quoted as saying: `There's really not much we can say; it's just a sadness'. What a way to thank two people who have given their all for Australia. And to think that this was the work of a supposedly caring Government! Everyone knows that it is a caring Government because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), his Ministers and his back benchers keep telling us it is. The Government kindly reminds us how caring it is by publishing plenty of glossy booklets and by hiring expensive billboards on highways. I doubt whether all this nonsense from the Government would impress the residents and staff at the Sinnamon Retirement Village. I am certain that it would not impress Mr and Mrs Harding.

Happily, Mr and Mrs Harding are back together again as a result of a vacancy which came up in the nursing home section. This allows Mr and Mrs Harding to spend most of their time together. I am sure everyone who was aware of the Hardings's separation would be delighted for them. However, to get them back together again, the administrators had to make a tough decision of bypassing 19 of their hostel residents and 16 of their patients in other nursing homes who were waiting to get into the nursing home beds at Sinnamon Village. Anyone who has visited the complex will understand why there is a waiting list of people to enter the home. It is a first class facility, staffed by first class people and it is on a first class site adjacent to the Brisbane River. But its capacity to handle current and future needs is certainly not a first class priority of this Government.

The existing 30-bed nursing home was completed in 1981 on the understanding that consideration would be given for a further 30 beds at a later time. It is interesting to note that the Prime Minister visited the complex during the 1984 election. I understand he was sympathetic towards the situation. But election sympathy by the Prime Minister is simply one more thing to disregard. The Hardings's situation should never have arisen and we should not be faced with an inevitable repeat of it due to Government bungling. Let us look after the people who built Australia with genuine initiatives rather than shallow advertising campaigns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The adjournment speech made by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) on 29 May should be seen for what it is-namely, an attack on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. Honourable members should be aware that that attack will intensify this year as forces of the Right try to obtain Australia's withdrawal from the world body. The speech was also an attack on Australia's Ambassador to UNESCO, the Hon. Gough Whitlam-not only an exceptional Australian but a person who has raised Australia's standing in the world body and in the developing world. I am embarrassed that I, an ordinary back bencher, should seek to speak to defend the Ambassador, but that embarrassment is tempered when I think of the right wing political lightweight who has dared to question the actions of the Ambassador and who has pathetically attempted to discredit him. It is interesting that the honourable member should have based his information on an article in News Weekly, a publication that has long since ceased to be on the reading list of most objective thinking people in Australia or other countries. The article was written by Peter Samuel, a hack of the right wing Heritage Foundation, the activities of which I have raised in this chamber before. I have a copy of the article here and a reading of it illustrates the bias of the author.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue to which the honourable member referred is related to an initiative of the Geneva Group, comprising members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which each contribute more than one per cent of the budget of the United Nations specialised agencies. A meeting of the Geneva Group on 20-21 March 1986 agreed on the principle of an Australian proposal that there should be a limit of two terms on the tenure in office of the heads of specialised agencies and other United Nations bodies. The Government's interest in this matter is spelt out clearly in an answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to a question asked by the honourable member-No. 2388, in Hansard of 29 November 1985, at page 4268. In view of the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 28 May, I am amazed that the honourable member for Wentworth should make the speech that he did on 29 May.

After the meeting of 20-21 March, a further meeting of the Geneva Group on 11 April agreed that the proposal should be taken up formally by the Co-Chairman of the Group with the agency head. The question of when this would be done was deferred pending further Group consultations on 30 April. Reflecting Australia's concern that the Geneva Group's proposal should be discussed with the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr M'Bow, before the UNESCO Executive Board and special committee meetings beginning on 28 April, Mr Whitlam convoked meetings of Western UNESCO delegates on 16 and 22 April and indicated at the latter meeting that it was his intention to pass on to Mr M'Bow a copy of the Geneva Group proposal and to circulate copies to all Executive Board members.

On 23 April he called on Mr M'Bow and gave him a summary of the decisions of the Geneva Group meeting. He also wrote to all Executive Board members on 24 April. Madam Speaker, there is no secrecy about this letter. I have a copy of it and I am happy to table it. Indeed, I can supply a copy of the letter to anyone who wants it, or, as the Ambassador will be in Australia this week, I suggest that those who are so interested should ask him for a copy of his letter of 24 April. The claims made by the honourable member for Wentworth have no foundation at all. This was spelt out by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 28 May. I am sure that the honourable member for Wentworth was too thick to understand the position, but, given his bias and his right wing associations, I suppose we should not be too surprised. I have said before that the forces of the Right will do everything in their power to discredit UNESCO and, indeed, our Ambassador. I totally reject the claims made by the honourable member for Went- worth, as indeed, would all thinking Australians.

Mr Whitlam's action was not a breach of confidentiality, since it had always been intended that the tenure of Directors-General and other Geneva Group concerns would be discussed with all the heads of agencies, including Mr M'Bow. The action was not contrary to instructions from Canberra given the concern that had been expressed that Mr M'Bow should be briefed on the proposal before the Executive Board meeting. I suppose the honourable member for Went- worth wants to reassure the Right, not only in Australia but throughout the world, of his credentials before he leaves this Parliament. I find it unbelievable that the honourable member for Wentworth should persist with this fiction that the Ambassador to UNESCO somehow leaked information, and, as offensive and unpalatable as it might be to the honourable member for Wentworth, the Sydney Morning Herald headline of 29 May is true-`Whitlam did not leak UN documents'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the honourable member for Throsby seeking leave to table a paper?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.
—Is leave granted?
—I have to see the document before I can give leave.
—Perhaps the honourable member for Throsby could show the document to the honourable member for Bradfield while I call the honourable member for Wentworth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the document is tabled; anything coming from the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) is worth a good laugh, so I hope it gets tabled. I am disappointed in the honourable member's speech. It was a pitiful effort. The honourable member had the courtesy to advise me that he was going to give that speech-and I thank him for that-and I hoped that he would have been well briefed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) or possibly by Ambassador Whitlam and that he would have something interesting to say. The honourable member established only that he was incapable of reading the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to my question, in which the Minister plainly confirmed that Ambassador Whitlam has made an unauthorised disclosure, unauthorised by the Geneva Group, to Mr M'Bow. The Minister for Foreign Affairs said that; that is the only possible reading of his answer. I will refer further to that matter in a moment. The poor old honourable member for Throsby was incapable of reading and interpreting correctly the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Before making further comments, perhaps I may say, Madam Speaker, that I consider the honourable member's attacks on personalities in the course of his speech, and on publications, contemptible as well as pitiful. To refer to a very widely and justly respected journalist such as Peter Samuel as a hack is disgusting. To refer to him as somehow or other a hack of the `right wing'-to quote the honourable member-Heritage Foundation is stupid, because he is an employee of News Limited. He is the Washington-based correspondent for the Australian newspaper. While the honourable member may despise the Australian as a newspaper, nevertheless, the person who is the Washington-based correspondent of that newspaper is a person to be taken seriously and respected for what he says, and, indeed, he is respected for what he says-unlike the honourable member for Throsby, who is the laughing stock of his own electorate as well as this Parliament.

The honourable member for Throsby also saw fit to bucket the respected weekly magazine News Weekly, which is published by the National Civic Council and edited by Peter Westmore and, of course, associated with that great Australian Mr Bob Santamaria, whose contribution to the history of this country is great and will be seen to be even greater as the years pass and the history of this period gets written.

I come to the follies of the honourable member. I assume, by the way, that Peter Samuel submitted his article to the Australian, and the Australian saw fit to use something else, and he therefore submitted it, as an alternative, to News Weekly. News Weekly published his article, which referred to an incoming telegram message received at the State Department addressed to the Unites States Secretary of State, George Shultz, from the United States Mission in Geneva, which said that the United States Mission has been told by the United Kingdom Co-Chairman of the Geneva Group of Western Ambassadors that the Australian Ambassador to the Unites Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation had made unauthorised disclosures of decisions of the Geneva Group to Mr M'Bow. I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs to confirm that. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) preferred to delay and to leave it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister for Foreign Affairs came back and gave the answer on 27 May.

The answer referred to the following order of events. The Geneva Group had met on 20 and 21 March and agreed on an Australian proposal to limit to two years the terms of Mr M'Bow and other heads of agencies. They had another meeting on 11 April at which they decided that this proposal should be taken up with Mr M'Bow. I correct an error, arising as a result of speed reading: They also decided that the question of when this would be taken up with Mr M'Bow would be deferred pending further group consultations on 30 April.

One week before the important meeting on 30 April, and this is what the Foreign Minister said, Mr Whitlam, the ambassador called on Mr M'Bow and spilt the lot. There is no suggestion of secrecy; he did not make any secret of it. If by `leak' one insists on something furtive and secret, which is a reasonable way of using the word `leak', it was not a leak in that sense because it was not secret. Mr Whitlam made no secret of the fact that he intended to make an unauthorised disclosure-unauthorised by the Geneva Group-and that is what he proceeded to do.

On 23 April, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs said, he called on Mr M'Bow and gave him a summary of the decisions of the Geneva Group meeting, when the Geneva Group, according to the Foreign Minister, had decided that there would be no meeting with Mr M'Bow until the date had been settled one week after Mr Whitlam spilt the facts to Mr M'Bow. So, for whatever reason, he decided to make an unauthorised exposure to Mr M'Bow.
The point in my raising the matter is that as Mr Samuel reports the matter:

At least one United States Department officer is outraged that Australia through Ambassador Whitlam has been leaking information about confidential Western decisions and breaching understood Western arrangements--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to continue reading into Hansard a passage from the New England Journal of Medicine Nobel Peace Prize lecture `Prescription for Hope' and I trust that honourable members will all listen carefully:

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the signal accomplishment of the Inter- national Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War has been the broadbase, free-flowing dialogue between physicians in two contending power blocs. We heed Einstein's words: ``Peace cannot be kept by force. It can only be achieved by understanding.'' In a world riven with confrontation and strife, the IPPNW has become a model for cooperation among physicians from East and West, from North and South. Paranoid fantasies of a dehumanized adversary cannot withstand the common pursuit of healing and preventing illness. Our success in forging such cooperation derives largely from an insistent avoidance of linkage with problems that have embittered relations between the great powers. We have resisted being sidetracked to other issues, no matter how morally lofty. Combating the nuclear threat has been our exclusive preoccupation, since we are dedicated to the proposition that to ensure the conditions of life, we must prevent the conditions of death. Ultimately, we believe people must come to terms with the fact that the struggle is not between different national destinies-between opposing ideologies-but between catastrophe and survival. All nations share a linked destiny; nuclear weapons are their shared enemy.

We must hold fast to the dream that reason will prevail. The world today is full of anguish and dread. As great as the danger is, still greater is the opportunity. If science and technology have catapulted us to the brink of extinction, the same ingenuity has brought humankind to the boundary of an age of abundance.

Never before was it possible to feed all the hungry. Never before was it possible to shelter all the homeless. Never before was it possible to teach all the illiterate. Never before were we able to heal so many afflictions. For the first time, science and medicine can diminish drudgery and pain.

Only those who see the invisible can do the impossible. But in order to do the impossible, we must ask, in the words of Jonathan Schell, `not only for our personal survival, we ask only that we be survived. We ask for assurance that when we die as individuals, as we know we must, mankind will live on.'

When questioned about his approach to sculpture, Michelangelo replied that he simply cut away the stone surrounding his vision. We in the physicians' movement will not grow discouraged as we chip away at the granite massif that obstructs our vision of a world freed from the spectre of nuclear war.

If we are to succeed, this vision must possess millions of people. We must convince each generation that they are but transient passengers on this planet earth. It does not belong to them. They are not free to doom generations yet unborn. They are not at liberty to erase humanity's past or dim its future. Only life itself can lay claim to sacred continuity. The magnitude of the danger and its imminence must bring the human family together in a common pursuit of the peace that has been denied throughout this century. On the threshold of a new millenium, the achievement of world peace is no longer remote, for it is beckoned by the unleashing of the deepest spiritual forces embedded in humankind, when threatened with extinction. The reason, the creativity, and the courage that human beings possess foster an abiding faith that what humanity creates, humanity can and will control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just returned from attending an international world peace conference held in Sofia, the capital of Bulgaria. About 200 delegates attended from 85 countries around the world, and I was honoured to be asked by the Bulgarian Agrarian Party, which sponsored the conference, to represent the National Party as Australia's representative. The Bulgarian Agrarian Party, which is guaranteed 25 per cent of the seats in the Bulgarian Parliament, works almost as one with its majority colleague, the Bulgarian Communist Party. However, the Bulgarian Agrarian Party is partly concerned with the activities and welfare of people from the rural areas.

SPEECH.PARA: It may seem odd to some that a political party would go to the expense to host such a peace conference. However, the genuine concern of the Bulgarian people for peace was evident throughout the country. In fact, one of the things that struck me was the magnitude of the concern that European people in general have for peace, and in particular their fear of the consequences of a nuclear war.

Of all the communist countries in the world, Bulgaria would be the closest to Russia. The historical connections between Bulgaria and Russia have much to do with this. All Bulgarians are taught that in 1878 Russia laid down 200,000 lives in helping Bulgaria free itself from 500 years of Turkish rule. That happened of course under the rule of the tsars. In 1944, Russia was again instrumental in helping release Bulgaria from the grip of the unpopular fascist influence. It is of interest, too, that two Bulgarian brothers, Cyril and Methodius, invented the cyrillic alphabet in 1853. This is always used in Bulgaria in preference to our alphabet and has of course been adopted by Russia. I believe Serbia in Yugoslavia is the only other part of the world where the cyrillic alphabet is in use. Add to that the fact that Bulgaria does 70 per cent of its trade with Russia and one can see the close ties between the two countries.

Russian flags fly from buildings in every direction one turns in Bulgaria. In one parade I witnessed hundreds upon hundreds of Russian flags flying beside the white, green and red Bulgarian flag. One would have to go to Canada, to see United States flags flying there, to witness anything remotely comparable with that in the West.

Bulgaria is an unknown country to many Australians. At 110,000 thousand square kilometres in area, it is over 10 per cent less than the size of my own electorate, Parkes. Its population is over nine million. Today it has a standard of living probably the highest of any communist country, though still much lower than ours. The average wage is equivalent to about $60 a week. However, some of the basic things are ridiculously cheap. For example, public transport costs only about 6 cents a ride and State-sponsored holiday housing is but a few dollars a day. Like most communist countries, there is little on sale to buy apart from the basics.

Though the country is developing a degree of light industry, Bulgaria is still basically an agricultural country. Due to the presence of large areas of fertile soils, it produces ample food and most people eat well. However, mechanisation in many areas is poor and it is a common sight to see rows of peasant women with their backs bent weeding the fields. Of course all adults, including all women, have to work in Bulgaria. Much of the grass is cut with scythes and pitchforked onto little carts pulled by donkeys to storage areas for winter fodder. Unfortunately, the Chernobyl radiation disaster meant that high proportions of this year's crop grown outside hothouses had to be destroyed. Bulgaria has much beauty, verdant forests, snow-capped mountains, ancient monasteries and fertile fields. Unfortunately, a photochemical smog seems to hang over much of the country, reducing visibility of such breathtaking wonders.

Most of the several hundred delegates and observers at the international peace conference were from hard left or left-wing organisations. A few were from the centre parties, such as the West German and Luxembourg delegates, and I guess I was the only genuine right-winger present. Naturally, at such a gathering many anti-American words were spoken and many pro-Russian ones, too. My own thoughts, for example, on the horrors that Russia is perpetrating in Afghanistan did not win much acceptance. However, the conference brought home to me the need to work for peace wherever practically possible, and the genuine desire for peace of most people in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear support from the Labor benches. The President of the World Peace Council, Romesh Chandra, spoke twice to the delegates present. Not only is he a committed member of the Indian Communist Party, but his loathing of the United States shone through his every word. I found his bitter, one-sided rhetoric completely unacceptable for a person in his position. The man talked of hate, not of love. He left the conference a day early to fly to Moscow. I can only suggest that, if the World Peace Council wishes to be taken seriously about peace and is not just a left-wing mouthpiece for Russian propaganda, it rid itself of this biased person in place of a more even-handed leader.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Earlier in the adjournment debate, the honourable member for Throsby asked leave to have a paper tabled. Leave has been refused.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I want to speak tonight on a topic on which I have not spoken for a long time; that is, the death of political philosophy, especially in the Liberal Party in this country. When I wrote my book five years ago I talked about the Liberal Party as a coalition of conservative and liberal philosophy. Unfortunately, since then, especially in recent times, one can say quite clearly and categorically that, except for about half a dozen people here, liberalism is dead within the so-called Liberal Party. There is no more a liberal philosophy arising in Australia. As I said, there are about half a dozen isolated individuals left on the Opposition side who have some belief in the traditional principles of liberalism as espoused by John Stuart Mill and others, but the vast majority now, I think, can be classified only as big `C' Conservatives-ultra-right wing conservatives in their philosophy, a conservatism not of the traditional kind, but a conservatism defined in more recent terms by American writers such as Milton Friedman, Ayn Rand and others who have adopted extraordinary ideas in the resolution of problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just go through some of these ideas and how different they are from traditional liberal concepts of the past. People such as Ayn Rand and Milton Friedman have openly stated such principles as the promotion of inequality being itself a good thing. To sum it up more crudely, if the poor get poorer and the rich get richer, then everyone is better off. That sort of principle is, unfortunately, now penetrating the highest echelons of the present leadership of the Liberal Party.

In my view it is a very serious development in Australian politics because it is a promotion of what is clearly an immoral philosophical perspective. A philosophical perspective which entrenches inequality, which entrenches these sorts of principles, can lead only to a dangerous division in society and the very kind of class hatred that the Opposition, when in government, used to be very fond of accusing the Labor Party of promoting.

There is no doubt whatsoever that the non-liberal philosophy, the big `C' Conservative philosophy that now dominates the misnamed Liberal Party, is a philosophy that is promoting a morality that must be unacceptable to the vast majority of Australians who believe in the principles of egalitarianism, who believe in principles of fairness. These developments in the Liberal Party are not only a serious worry for the members of the Liberal Party, but indeed a serious worry for all those who are concerned with the historical development of Australian democracy. What we have seen in recent times is a situation in which the Opposition has moved so far to the right that it has become a dangerous instrument, a dangerous opposition. The policies we have heard leaked from the Opposition in the last few days, notwithstanding the fact that they have been discredited by all the Ministers here, are nevertheless dangerous policies because they are extremely divisive and are based, as I have said, on the abandonment of the traditional liberal principles on which the Liberal Party was founded.

The Leader of the Opposition had the gall to appeal to the spirit of Robert Menzies, would you believe, in his remarks. If one looks at the foundation principles of the Liberal Party when Robert Menzies formed it and looks at what he rejected and at what he accepted, one sees very clearly that what Robert Menzies rejected were the very points and principles John Howard is now promoting. He made it perfectly clear that the new Liberal Party would be different from the previous conservative party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight about the Government's decision not to proceed with the international terminal at Brisbane Airport. Whilst this airport does not lie within my electorate now, it did when I was in the Senate. The matter of entry of international tourists into Brisbane is one that is very important to my electorate, which looks forward to a large number of international tourists in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) has made many statements on this subject. Most latterly, on 24 April, he is quoted in the Courier-Mail as saying that the present international terminal is adequate. He continued:
The Brisbane international terminal is quite able to meet the needs of the community for some years to come.

It is statements such as those that make me wonder who is advising the Minister and, indeed, whether he has ever set foot in the terminal certainly whether he has set foot in it lately. Earlier this year he wrote a letter to the Queensland Tourist Industry Association in which he made the following statement:

Extensions and modifications . . . have proved to be adequate to meet the needs of international air travellers . . . The present terminal is capable of handling 890 arriving and 890 departing passengers in each hour.

That letter contained many assertions and statements, but the one about 890 people coming in and 890 people going out really is breathtaking. The statement that the extensions and modifications have proved to be adequate to meet the needs of international travellers flies in the face of all the statements and complaints received about the international terminal in Brisbane. Very recently, a representative of Japanese tourists complained about the inadequacies of the terminal, and yet the Minister says that there are very few complaints.

Let me return to the arrival system and the number of people this terminal can handle. On 15 April 1986 the Courier-Mail printed an article which detailed the actual time taken to go through the procedures on arrival at Brisbane international airport until leaving the terminal. It detailed the story of one tourist who took nearly an hour and a half from the time his flight landed at Brisbane until he actually stepped outside the Customs area. As someone who has had occasion to arrive and depart from Brisbane when travelling overseas, I assure the House that that is an average sort of experience, taking into account that it takes about 15 minutes from when one's flight lands until one is allowed off the plane, because of quarantine regulations. So the story is no exaggeration.

However, the Minister's statement that the terminal is capable of holding 890 arriving and 890 departing passengers each hour is a wild exaggeration. The Minister should take to task the people who put these sorts of words into his mouth or into letters he has to sign. Anybody who is familiar with that terminal, which is simply a converted machinery shed, would boggle at how it could possibly hold that number of passengers, let along their relatives and friends. My information is that the concourse has a total of 509 seats; so for those people who are going to be arriving at the rate of 890 an hour and who are leaving at the same rate a really hopeless situation would arise. I put this to honourable members: That number of arriving and departing passengers amounts to approximately three nearly full Jumbos arriving and departing per hour; that is one either arriving or leaving every 20 minutes. There is not room for that number of people to stand shoulder to shoulder in the Brisbane international terminal, let alone go through all the formalities they have to go through. In the article to which I have referred the Senior Assistant Collector of Customs in Brisbane, a Mr Mark Kerwick, said:
We have an ideal processing time for jumbos . . . one minute per passenger at each primary officer in the arrival hall is what we aim for . . .

My calculations tell me that means that, at the rate of one minute per passenger, 60 passengers will be processed per officer per hour under optimum circumstances. Mr Kerwick went on to explain why that always goes awry. Eight hundred and ninety passengers would need 15 Customs officers working at full speed under optimum circumstances and there are five Customs desks in the entire terminal. It is not physically possible for the officers to handle that number of people, even at maximum speed.

Anyone arriving can expect friends and family to wait at least an hour before one comes through the doors. As I have said, the sort of crowding that that would lead to is mind-boggling for anyone who is familiar with this terminal. It is absolutely absurd for the Minister to be given silly information such as that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to some statements made by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman). In his pathetic defence of the extreme right wing of Australian politics he had the gall to describe Bob Santamaria as a good Australian. I would like to quote a really good Australian who would have had a better knowledge of the Bob Santamarias of this country. I refer to an adjournment speech of the late Arthur Calwell on 23 February 1972. He was more fortunate than I am; he had 10 minutes in which to speak. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I have made a lot of mistakes in my life and I have gone on record as saying that half the problems that I have encountered in life I have created for myself. I do not think I have to make any more concessions to my political enemies than that. But I made a great mistake on this occasion and I want to put the record straight because apparently the Department of Defence cannot find any of the records nor can the Department of Labour and National Service. In 1942 I was approached by the late Archbishop Mannix of Melbourne through his Vicar-General asking me to obtain exemptions from military service for Messrs Santamaria, Mitchell and Maher on the grounds that they were members of the secretariat of Catholic Action and that their work was equivalent to that of a minister of religion. I agreed to do this. Had I known what was to happen in the future I would not have done it, but I accept the responsibility for what I did. I had a fondness for the late Archbishop Mannix and I say unashamedly that I actually wept when I knew he had died. I saw him arrive in Australia and I saw him die.
In the same adjournment speech Arthur Calwell went on to say:

I want the country to know that 3 men who have been pestering, opposing and demonstrating against the Australian Labor Party for the last 30 years dodged military service-even though I was responsible for it-and others had to take their place. I hate the fact that these people who benefited from an act of generosity on the part of the Curtin Labor Government lived to become vicious opponents of the Labor Party in the Vietnam war and supported the conscription of Australians to fight in that filthy, immoral, indefensible, genocidal civil war. I regret too that the people who benefited from our generosity did not beget any children who went out to fight in the war in Vietnam which we described as immoral. Their sons were exempted, all of them, because they were employed in reserved institutions as were their fathers.
At this point the then honourable member for Hindmarsh, Mr Clyde Cameron, interjected:
Were they of military age at the time?
Arthur Calwell responded:

Of course they were. None of these breeds served in any war to defend Australia yet they are standing over this Government and saying: `Do not let the Russians come into the Indian Ocean because they can menace the security of Australia. We have no right to tell the Russians, the Americans, the Japanese or anybody else where they shall deploy their fleets. I do not like the idea of a Japanese fleet again in the Indian Ocean but I am not going to associate myself with any attempt by anybody to tell the Russians that they must not deploy their fleet or any of their ships in the Indian Ocean. I would welcome the Russians to the Indian Ocean because in the world of today I would rather see in the Indian Ocean powerful people who might be friendly to us than make enemies of them so that they will be opposed to us in the future. I do not want war. I do not want violence. I always want peace and I think it behoves me, in conscience, to tell the truth about these particular creatures whom I have mentioned tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we had heard the last of the sort of sectarian rubbish that we have just heard from the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), but it is obviously still alive and galloping well in the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. I wish to bring to the attention of this House a couple of incidents which graphically illustrate that since 7 March 1984 all Australians are no longer equal before the law, at least those laws administered by this Federal Labor Government. Of course, 7 March 1983 was the day when Mr Hawke took over as Prime Minister of this country and solemnly promised us a government for all Australians. It appears that he meant to say: `A government for all Australians who voted Labor and preferably who also held high office in a militant union'. The rest of us could make our own arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The incidents to which I refer involve infringements of Federal laws and regulations governing access to Kakadu National Park, the Canberra controlled park which so far covers 14,000 square kilometres of the top of my electorate. One incident involved four university students and a single overnight camping episode. The other is an episode rather than an incident as it involved a score or more of people and systematic breaches of the law continued, despite the full glare of publicity, for more than 100 days.

On 16 May last year a student from Armidale University and three companions camped in Kakadu without appropriate authority and in a place reserved, in the parlance of the park's Commonwealth administrators, `for authorised persons only'. Next morning a ranger came upon them, read the riot act, noted that there was no damage to the camp site and said that they could probably expect a letter of warning over the incident. One of the students, Colin Campbell, did not receive his letter of warning. He must have been picked out as a good man to make an example of. Late last year a policeman from Lightning Ridge drove to his parents' property near Collarenabri and hit young Colin Campbell with a summons to be answered in Darwin's Magistrates Court on 8 February this year. Colin Campbell wrote to the court asking for leniency. He explained that it was his first brush with the law and the financial impracticability of a university student returning all the way to Darwin to plead his case. This was all to no avail. For trespassing in the Commonwealth's National Park for just one night Colin Campbell was fined $500.

Colin Campbell and his three mates were not the only people camped illegally in Kakadu National Park on 16 May last year. Just up the road, outside the Mudginberri abattoir lease, were between 20 to 30 illegal campers. By 16 May they had been there a couple of weeks and they stayed for another three months or so. Everyone knew they were there-the park rangers, the Australian Federal Police, the nominal owner of Kakadu, Professor Derrick Ovington, and also his boss who is, of course, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen). I can guarantee that Minister Cohen knew because I and Ministers of the Northern Territory Government told him in a series of telexes and letters, just in case he somehow missed the story in the national media. These illegal campers did not just trespass in Kakadu overnight during a sightseeing tour; they set up a semi-permanent camp and lit fires for cooking. I am not too sure what they did about rubbish and toilet facilities, but I do know-so does everybody, including the Minister-that they broke just about every rule in the book during their occupation of this environmentally sensitive park.

The difference is that these campers carried union tickets issued by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and were carrying out union orders to close down the Mudginberri abattoir, even though that abattoir was working under an industrial court approved award. This illegal picket line was operating outside the laws of this country and for more than 100 days it flagrantly breached the environmental laws in Kakadu which Professor Ovington and Minister Cohen are charged to uphold.

The illegal campers were not charged during their long occupation of the park. They were not even warned off the area or told to put out their fires. No $500-a-day prosecutions were launched against them by this Government. The situation stinks. I am embarrassed, as member for the Northern Territory, that on vast tracts of land in my electorate, controlled by the grubby fingers of this Government, there is one law for the political friends of the Minister even when they are bent on industrial sabotage--

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the operations of Cabarlah Army Base Queensland.
(2) Have its operations changed in recent times.
(3) Are there any proposals to shift the base to another site.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 7 Signal Regiment and 72 Electronic Warfare Squadron are located at Borneo barracks Cabarlah. 7 Signal Regiment is an army communications unit conducting a variety of communications related tasks including operating a radio receiving station. The role of 72 Electronic Warfare Squadron is to provide electronic warfare support to a division.

(2) No. However a review of the long term operations of 7 Signal Regiment has been conducted in part because of the question of continued operation in an environment of increasing radio interference. It concluded that provided the rate of growth of man-made interference in the adjacent area is not significantly accelerated the Regiment's activities can be adjusted without major detriment to Australian Defence Force operations.

Also 7 Signal Regiment has been tasked to provide some communications related training to RAN, and possibly later, RAAF trainees. 7 Signal Regiment already conducts this training for Army students. RAN instructors and students are being phased in at the 7 Signal Regiment. They are making use of existing facilities at Cabarlah.
There is no change to the role of 72 Electronic Warfare Squadron.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Defence Force (ADF) Have any responsibility to assist the Australian people in emergencies such as major fires, floods, or cyclones or damage to Australian towns and cities by enemy action: if so, does the ADF have (a) contingency plans, (b) forces and (c) material to carry out that responsibility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The provision of assistance to the Australian people in emergencies such as major fires, floods or cyclones or damage to Australian towns or cities by enemy action is the responsibility of the authorities of the States or Territories concerned. This assistance is provided in the first instance by the professional service of the appropriate State or Territory, backed up by local volunteer organisations. The Australian Defence Force (ADF) may be requested to assist by the provision of personnel, equipment, facilities or equipment to perform tasks which are the responsibility of these civil authorities or organisations, and for which they lack the necessary equipment or personnel.

The ADF has a contingency plan and instructions which outline the procedures to be followed to assist the civil community in the event of a disaster. Specific plans relating to damage caused by enemy action have not been prepared.

The ADF does not have specific forces or material earmarked for this assistance. In the event of assistance being required by the civil community, ADF personnel and material are diverted from their normal function.
